PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit our opposition to the announced imposition of Sales Tax of 12% on basic hardware and building products by the Federal Government from July 1 1995. The petitioners note particularly that:

1. This new tax will directly affect ordinary Australians in the form of rising prices of building, maintaining and improving their home and by consequential job losses and company closures in an industry which has faced many economic pressures over recent years.
2. The new tax offers no net benefit to Australia and should be abandoned.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners request that the Senate should not pass this legislation when it is presented and/or work to prevent this taxation measure from being implemented by the current Federal Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain residents of the Australia respectfully showeth that the tax on selected building products, proposed in the May 1995 Budget, will place an unwelcome burden on all Australians planning to build a new home or carry out alterations and additions, or repairs/maintenance to existing homes. Moreover, it is considered that the tax is iniquitous in that, when introduced, it will apply retrospectively to people currently building homes, who had entered in good faith into `fixed price' building contracts.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject the extension of proposed wholesales sales tax to building products.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens strongly urge the Government to accept the Democrats' proposal to drop the intended tax on essential building materials.

We believe the proposed tax—adding between $600 and $1,200 on the cost of a medium-sized home and up to $3,000 over the life of a mortgage—will make it more difficult for Australians to buy their own home, increase maintenance costs and rents on existing houses, and hinder growth in the building industry.
We call on the Government to droop the tax on essential building materials.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
Forest Protection Petition for the permanent protection of remaining native old growth, wilderness and other high conservation value forest areas in Australia.
This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate Federal Government intervention, to comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in cooperation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp, cane etc.

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oil, and other nutritional and medicinal resources.
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practice.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

`Observe the United Nations Convention of the Rights of the Child and grant all children social justice and equity in relation to a pre school developmental program which will provide the foundation for a quality education and future employability, by removing the 12 hour (or 1 day) child care assistance restriction for long day care based on parents marital and employment status'
Your Petitioners ask/request that the Senate should:
`remove the 12 hour (or 1 day) child care assistance restriction for long day care children based on parents marital and employment status'.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney Olympics 2000
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:

PARA.TAB: Urges the Federal Government to bring down legislation that all merchandise bearing the Sydney Olympics 2000 insignia shall be made in Australia from material made in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
To uphold, defend, protect and retain forever Australia's historic Constitutional Monarchy:-

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia strongly support Australia's Constitutional Monarchy as successful, positive historic and enduring and reject totally any thought of a republic and its insidious companion, creeping republicanism, as divisive, devious, extremist, and without merit.

The Constitutional Monarchy has served Australia well, overviewed our impressive growth and undoubted prosperity, reigned continuously with pomp and circumstance from our first settlement and national foundation, guided our national development in both war and peace, ensured and protected our liberties while delivering peace, order and good government, and rightly denies to evil men those powers which could be used to enslave us.

The Constitutional Monarch is Australia's head of state by tradition, law and right, and, sitting as the Monarch does, at the apex of our Constitution, presides over a Constitution designed for Australians by Australians by some of the wisest constitutional designers to grace our national stage.

We therefore look with trepidation at the antics of a few unwise individuals who would replace proven substance with unproven rhetoric and in doing so threaten the freedoms of all Australians and as loyal Australians hereby petition that the Senate, swearing allegiance to our Queen do live up to that oath by upholding, defending, protecting and retaining forever Australia's historic Constitutional Monarchy.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray: God Save the Queen!

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on the investigatory powers of the Australian Securities Commission, together with submissions and a transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report that I have just tabled is the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee report into the investigatory powers of the Australian Securities Commission. On 27 May 1993 the Senate resolved to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for report on the following matters: firstly, the exercise of the powers of officers of the Australian Securities Commission to interview witnesses, including, one, the manner in which those interviews are conducted, two, the power to take transcripts of interview and the treatment of those transcripts and, three, the power to compel production of books and records; secondly, the exercise of the powers of the ASC to bring applications against corporations and individuals including, one, the bringing of applications during the course of investigation and, two, the process by which applications are brought.

PARA.TAB: Broadly speaking, the reference was to look at how the Australian Securities Commission went about investigating corporations and the corporate area of the community generally. The committee received some 147 witness submissions and held public hearings in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. A number of these submissions were extremely lengthy and much of the evidence was of a highly complex nature. The committee received submissions and heard evidence from a number of persons who felt aggrieved by the actions of the ASC, in particular, by the way in which investigations had been carried out by that body.

The committee wishes to thank all those persons who gave their time and energy in providing the committee with the benefit of their experiences. It also wishes to thank the Australian Securities Commission for its cooperation.

I would like to thank my fellow members on the committee, in particular, Senator Spindler from the Democrats, Senator Cooney from the government, and Senator O'Chee from the National Party who caused this matter to be referred. I should also mention Senator McKiernan and Senator Neal, who has joined the committee of late. I thank all members of the committee for their assistance in this matter and for the work they put into it.

The central issue for the committee was to resolve the difficulty in balancing the need for effective corporate regulation against the right of the individual to certain procedural safeguards in the investigatory process. During the course of the committee's inquiry it became clear that there was an imbalance too far in favour of the Australian Securities Commission and that this imbalance was contributing to an atmosphere of antagonism between the business community and the Australian Securities Commission. In the committee's view, this antagonism of itself is not conducive to efficient regulation of the corporate sector. While the Australian Securities Commission enjoys some favour in that sector of the community, a number of grievances were put to the committee which could not be overlooked.

In its recommendations, the committee has sought to protect the rights of individuals and to alter procedures only where, in so doing, there are tangible benefits for the business community, the Australian Securities Commission and individuals at large. For example, in recommendation 15, the committee has recommended that legal professional privilege be available for all parties in investigations carried out by the Australian Securities Commission. Presently, due to the High Court's decision in Yuill, legal professional privilege does not exist for client to lawyer communications in relation to investigations initiated by the Australian Securities Commission.

The committee was concerned by evidence given in the course of the inquiry that the lack of access to legal professional privilege may prompt company officers to act without legal advice or on the basis of imperfectly understood oral advice. The rationale is that if people are fearful that by going to a lawyer they will not enjoy legal privilege, they will not seek that advice in the first instance and will embark upon a path which is hazardous to say the least.

The committee found that there were sound reasons both from the perspective of corporate governance and individual liberties to reinstate legal professional privilege for all parties in ASC investigations. Much of the committee's time was concerned with the ASC's right to compel persons under investigation to participate in oral examinations. This power is derived from section 19 of the ASC law and the committee found that the compulsory oral examination is a key investigatory tool for the ASC and should remain part of the ASC's investigatory powers.

But it was also evident to the committee that there are deficiencies in the present examination procedure, in particular in relation to protection for examinees against the misuse of procedures and powers enjoyed by the ASC. In recommendation 4, for instance, the committee has recommended that when personal assets are frozen, and when that action has been found subsequently to be entirely without merit, the individual who has had his or her assets frozen has a right to claim costs. In this instance I refer to the Aust-home example which was put to us by many witnesses. That was a case where people had their assets frozen in such a manner pending investigation.

The committee has also made a number of recommendations touching upon the compulsory examination powers of the ASC, and briefly they are: that the ASC law be amended so that summonses for such examinations should be issued by district registrars of the Federal Court on application by the ASC rather than being a purely discretionary matter for an ASC officer; furthermore, that the ASC law be amended so that the power of the ASC to exclude a particular lawyer from a compulsory examination be only exercisable on application by the ASC to a court. The onus should be on the ASC to prove that the exclusion of a particular lawyer who would represent the person under investigation is necessary so as to avoid any prejudice to the investigation. Furthermore, the examination should be stayed during any such application by the ASC.

The committee has also recommended that transcripts be available, that access be available to documents seized by the ASC, and that there be training for ASC investigatory officers. In total, there are some 15 recommendations, but time does not permit me to address them in detail. Suffice to say that the committee believes that it has struck the critical balance between the protection of civil liberties on the one hand and the protection of the community from unlawful practices on the other. Wherever government bestows upon quasi-government bodies—or anybody for that matter—investigatory powers, one has to look very closely at how those powers are exercised. The Australian Securities Commission has had a good many powers bestowed upon it. The committee did not say that this should not have happened because the excesses of the 1980s had to be addressed but, nevertheless, we, as a Senate, have to scrutinise such powers and ensure that they did not go too far and infringe the civil liberties that I have mentioned. There are a good many other good recommendations in this report and I commend it to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Economics References Committee on improving the tax treatment of small business, together with submissions and a transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 October 1994, the Senate referred to the Senate Economics References Committee for inquiry and report the matter of the tax treatment of small business. This matter arose following concerns about the appropriateness of the level of the provisional tax uplift factor that the government was proposing to apply to provisional taxpayers for the 1994-95 financial year.

PARA.TAB: While the uplift factor was the catalyst for the inquiry, the Senate referred a broad range of taxation matters affecting small business for examination. These included the impact of the timing of the payments of the various taxes on the cash flows of small business; changes in the overall burden of tax by and since the 1993 budget; the potential for reducing compliance costs for small business through the improvement of tax payment arrangements; and whether the tax system can be improved to prevent tax falling due before income is actually received.

The committee received 69 submissions to the inquiry from small businesses and their representative peak bodies, accounting firms, tax agents, public sector organisations, consultants, academics and other members of the public. The range of concerns expressed in evidence to the committee during its hearings clearly illustrates the extent and sheer complexity of tax law affecting small businesses—hundreds of thousands of whom are sole traders, family businesses and small partnerships. All of this, of course, is exacerbated by the seemingly never ending changes to tax and the need for small businesses to somehow keep track of it all.

Not only are small businesses faced with the practical daily challenges of running their business affairs but, by necessity, they find themselves spending a great deal of time and effort keeping abreast of and complying with some very exacting tax obligations, or else they are paying their accountants to do so. Furthermore, in some cases, tax payments are often due not only before taxable income is received but even before it is earned. This is why the committee's first recommendation is for the due dates of quarterly provisional tax payments to be put back by two months—one month to at least give a small business a chance to earn its income for the quarter, and another to receive at least some of what is due.

The basic approach taken by the committee in this report was to continue to follow many of the issues raised at the time of the 1990 Beddall report, which made many recommendations in relation to the taxation of small business. The committee heard from small business throughout Australia and came to the conclusion that the objectives which guided the Beddall committee's recommendations remain unfinished.

This report has framed its recommendations with the view that small businesses could benefit from some affirmative action to balance the economies of scale which are available to large businesses. As the title of this report expresses, it is a question of balance as to the extent that the disadvantages of being a business that is small can be neutralised in the face of the natural advantages enjoyed by large businesses.

The most complex issue that the committee had to deal with was the provisional tax uplift factor. Of all of the issues raised by small business in the inquiry, it is fair to say that the uplift factor was almost universally considered unfair, not the least because most small businesses do not experience a growth in income as great as the uplift factor expects them to. This is why the committee majority recommends that the uplift factor be set at a level no higher than the current or expected annual movement in the consumer price index. The committee did not settle on this recommendation easily. Its merit is that it is simple and fairer than the current system, which is complex, unfair, inappropriate and probably meaningless.

The committee suggests that the government examine and evaluate the main alternative that was canvassed during its deliberations—that of an individual uplift factor that is derived from the particular circumstances of each provisional taxpayer. It is possible that setting a single factor to apply to a fundamentally disparate group of over 1 1/2 million provisional taxpayers is a completely wrong approach, particularly when it becomes obvious that the fluctuations in their individual and aggregate incomes from year to year are often anything but small.

Other key recommendations include extending the option to pay sales tax on a quarterly basis to more small businesses, to ease compliance costs and give them a chance to receive more income before the tax is due; reviewing the messy and complex sales tax exemptions and classifications regime and establishing a process where new products can be quickly and easily classified; exempting small businesses from the annual FBT liabilities of less than $200 from FBT on car parking, compulsory award obligations and child care provided by small businesses in some cases; and deferring the capital gains tax on the capital gain of a small trading business which the vendor rolls over into another small trading business.

It is a quirk of life in this country that small and medium enterprises have been largely responsible for the growth in employment in the 1990s and for many of their expanding export opportunities at a time when our larger enterprises have been preoccupied with rationalisations, downsizing, re-engineering and other measures which may increase their efficiencies but do not contribute much to employment or export growth. The measures recommended in this report are designed to give our small businesses a much fairer go.

I want to place on record my thanks to the committee secretariat for their work throughout the whole of this entire reference and during our deliberations and their involvement in compiling this report. I particularly mention the secretary, Rob Diamond, and Merrilyn Pyle and Pippa Carron who were involved in the compilation of this report and in the running of the committee. I would particularly like to mention the work of James Satrapa who has provided a tremendous amount of expertise and knowledge to both myself and the other members of the committee in helping to understand the complexities of the tax problems that we were trying to overcome.

I would also like to compliment all committee members for the manner in which the deliberations were conducted. It was a complex and difficult job to consider all of the submissions that were presented to the committee. At the end of the day there were differing political and philosophical positions on what were the appropriate ways to address the many complexities confronting small business in relation to taxation matters. The goodwill that existed during the determining of our final recommendations—you, Mr Acting Deputy President, were one of those members who were part of those deliberations—meant that we were able to come up with more unanimous recommendations than might have otherwise been the case. I commend my coalition colleagues on the committee, Senator Spindler from the Democrats and the government members of the committee, particularly Senator Murphy who was involved in the final deliberations, for the manner in which we were able to arrive at our final report.

I urge the government to look closely at the recommendations of this report as they represent a widespread variety of views from small businesses around Australia. The very fact that we had so many submissions and the enthusiasm of the people who gave us evidence at public hearings only highlights the complexities that currently exist. Anything that we can do to help to improve the plight of small businesses or the efficiency of small businesses can only be in the best interests of Australia. I strongly urge the government to look very closely at the recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words on behalf of the opposition before these appropriation bills are passed. They have to be passed this week because they provide the appropriations for the running of the affairs of government for the forthcoming financial year and are, in essence, the government's budget bills. I want to say a couple of things about the processes that we here in the Senate are now required to go through as a result of the change in timing of the introduction of the budget, because the change last year to bring the budget in in May, to have effect from 1 July, rather than the previous long-standing practice of introducing it in August, with effect from 1 July, was seemingly desirable and sensible. It has led to some very difficult administrative and processing problems for the parliament, particularly for the Senate through the estimates processes.

PARA.TAB: The main scrutiny of the government's budget is done in the Senate through the Senate estimates processes. That has always been the case and it has become increasingly important in recent years as the Senate's committee system has developed greater sophistication and the ability to cope with the complexities of the legislation that comes before it, including budget legislation.

When we had the budget being brought in in the third week in August, that required supply bills being passed towards the end of the preceding financial year. It meant that the budget did not have to be passed until about the end of November or early December. So, under the old system, we had about three months—indeed, it could be stretched to 3 1/2 months, some 15 weeks—between the introduction of the budget and its eventual passage. That allowed the Senate much greater time to examine the details of the budget. So we had the budget introduced in the third week in August.

We commenced estimates hearings in late September or earlyish October. Sometimes then we would have additional estimates hearings or supplementary hearings, depending on the questions and issues that had arisen out of those initial estimates hearings. Matters could be fully considered and outstanding questions could be answered adequately in time by government departments. Despite all that, the budget was still being passed in quite adequate time by late November or early December. So there was a period of up to 15 weeks to do the whole of the budget process.

Now the budget is introduced in the second week in May. Because of that, there are no supply bills passed to enable the funding of government beyond the end of that financial year. Therefore, the budget bills introduced—I am referring particularly to the appropriation bills introduced in the second week of May—have to be fully passed by, at the very latest, the last week in June to enable the services of government to continue into the start of the new financial year.

We have a maximum period of about seven weeks for the parliament to examine the budget in detail. In other words, it is half the time that existed before. That has posed some very considerable problems for the Senate in its consideration of the budget. It means that the first estimates hearings cannot really take place until late May. That is only a couple of weeks, or three weeks at the maximum, after the budget has been introduced. So there has been less time to examine the content of the budget in detail. By the time those hearings are held and considered by senators on the relevant estimates committees and answers are supplied to questions taken on notice during those hearings by government departments, the supplementary estimates hearings that may be required based on the responses of those questions cannot be held until the third week in June. Then we will pass the budget within a matter of a few days and, in some instances, a few hours after that. Indeed, an estimates committee sat last night—

TALK.START.PARA: —Till 1 o'clock.

—Till 1 o'clock this morning. Yet nine hours later we are being required to pass the appropriation bills. I do not know the answer to this, but it is a matter of serious concern and causes serious difficulty in the proper processing and consideration of the budget. It is something that the parliament will have to look at, as will the government of the day, if we are to feel confident that the parliament is able to do its job in terms of the proper examination and processing of appropriation bills.

PARA.TAB: I think the process is a difficult one. Despite that, I think the Senate has done excellent work in the last few frenetic weeks in examining the budget. Those estimates processes have certainly revealed and exposed many of the basic flaws contained in this quite phoney, fraudulent and fudged budget of broken promises. This is a budget of massive tax increases. The increase in revenue forecast in this budget for the forthcoming year is the second highest increase in revenue—the second highest tax rip-off of the Australian public since those infamous Whitlam years, where we had budget policy which absolutely wrecked the Australian economy for years and years after that.

Since then, this budget is second only to the disastrous first budget of the Hawke government in 1983-84. The first Hawke budget had a massive increase in revenue. If you take the budgets of 1994-95 and 1995-96 together, the increase in revenue in those two years will be far and away the greatest increase since the Whitlam years. Therefore, we have ratcheted up into yet another high taxing economy, an economy which makes it very difficult for the average Australian wage earner to get a job. We still have three-quarters of a million people officially unemployed, and you can well and truly double that when you take into account the underemployment in the economy. The government through its high taxing policies has made it extremely difficult for Australians to get a job in the first instance. Once they have a job, they are then battered right, left and centre with a whole raft of massive taxes—taxes of a nature that make Australia increasingly uncompetitive in a highly competitive world relative to other countries.

It is all very well for the government to say we are more competitive than we were five or 10 years ago. That comparison completely ignores the fact that, against many of our major trading partners with whom we have to compete if we are to maintain and build our living standards, we have become less, not more, competitive. To the extent that we have narrowed the gap at all—and we have only done that in rare circumstances—has largely been done as a result of the short-term expediency of a progressively declining exchange rate. That, in itself, poses major problems for the economy.

The budget does nothing at all to address in the short, medium or, I would argue, the longer term the fundamental problem facing Australia, a problem which is recognised in the rhetoric by the government—that is, the chronic lack of savings in Australia. The budget, having recognised that rhetorically—the Treasurer (Mr Willis) did that in his second reading speech—does nothing at all to tackle the problem. Indeed, through the raft of massive new taxes and tax hikes, it has made that problem much more difficult.

The government would say that it has started to tackle the problem as a result of its proposals for compulsory superannuation. But it has done two things in that regard. It will pay for those at some distant time by a deferral, indeed a breaking, of its tax promises before the last election to give major tax cuts to every Australian taxpayer as from 1 January 1996. Those tax cuts have now been taken away from the Australian taxpayer. Indeed, as a result of that, he or she will be paying more tax, not less. At the same time the government, through its policies, has lessened the range of choice available to Australians in terms of their savings opportunities and incentives.

So the budget has worked in quite the wrong direction with regard to the fundamental problem that we face in our economy—that is, the basic lack of savings. It is that fundamental problem which is reflected in the current account deficit, the deficit in our external accounts. The deficit this year is of the order of six per cent of our total national production. That is the worst figure for any industrialised country in the world.

In terms of the problem we have with our external accounts, we are now even worse than Mexico. That is something that just a few short years ago would not have been considered even vaguely conceivable. Worse still, the government in its own budget forecasts projects no improvement at all in that current account deficit over the year ahead. It will come in at $27 billion this year, 1994-95, and the government is forecasting another $27 billion deficit in 1995-96. It is very likely that on Friday, in two days time, when we get the monthly balance of payments figures for May, we will see the highest ever deficit in our external accounts. At a time when the government is trying to argue that its policies are designed to correct the problems in the Australian economy, to tackle the fundamental problems, it is a cruel indictment of the mismanagement of this government over many years in terms of its economic policy.

These are matters that we have been pursuing and will continue to pursue in some of the other budget related bills, particularly the taxation bills which are to be debated in the next two or three days. In particular, I urge the government to look at my comments in terms of the budget process so far as the Senate's consideration of the budget is concerned, because we have some serious difficulties of a timing nature which, if we as a Senate are to feel confident that we are doing our job, do need to be addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short mentioned that one of the estimates committees sat till one o'clock this morning. There is no doubt that during the estimates different people, different senators, pursue different avenues of investigation. One of the reasons that we were delayed in this process was a particular matter I was pursuing and had been pursuing for some four years. When we had the supplementary estimates last Friday, I had 140-odd questions that were outstanding and some of them had been outstanding for 12 months.

PARA.TAB: At the estimates hearing in which I was involved querying Telstra, the answers to my questions were given to me at nine o'clock—and the hearing started at half past eight. In other words, it was impossible for me to ask any questions. Representatives from Telstra were brought along and had to be sent home. This happens on many occasions. It is of concern that we do not seem to be able to get the estimates processes correct.

I want to put on the record, as briefly as I can, the result of this four years of work I have been putting in on behalf of what I class as a battler and a person who was the subject of an independent inquiry held by Ken Marks QC. This particular person, Mr Geoffrey Marr from Sydney, was stood down on 4 July 1990, charged with the misuse of six Cabcharge documents after having alerted the public to some 137 counts of misuse of overtime by some employees of Telecom, or Telstra as it is now known.

I can tell you that it has been a long, drawn-out process. Some of the things that have come to light make me really wonder how big corporations and big government departments work in this country. I have said this in this place before, so I will be brief: this particular employee who was unfairly dismissed, as it has now been proved, had three lots of private investigators pursuing him; his telephones were tapped; his brother's telephones were tapped; and a friend of a friend's telephones were tapped, for what reason I would not know and no-one else does either.

In answers to some of the questions that I obtained last week, I have ascertained that Telstra had an internal inquiry which cost them something like $80,000. In total, they admitted that so far they have spent $322,000 pursuing this particular person.

After the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) was made aware of this by me and Mr Marr, the minister found a fair amount of sympathy for this particular case because it had been going on for so long. It was because of our actions that Michael Lee organised this independent inquiry—and there are the results of it. It really shows that Mr Marr has been treated unfairly. It recommends that he be reinstated, be paid back pay, holiday pay and all the rest of it right back to when he appeared before a disciplinary appeals board.

He went to the ombudsman and the AAT. He went through all the processes he possibly could trying to receive justice for himself. Then we unearthed all these improper dealings. As far as the disciplinary appeals board was concerned, Mr Marks found that evidence was withheld and that Mr Marr had been denied natural justice. The bottom line is that Telstra admitted to spending something like $322,000 pursuing this person on what would appear to be four or five charges amounting to $37.

What really summed up for me how far people will go in trying to deceive or in trying to get the results they want is an internal memo, along with heaps of other material, that came into my possession. This is an internal memo from the Director of Corporate Affairs, Gillian Welshe, to Gayle Hill, dated 27 September 1994. This was about the time I was waiting for Mr Lee, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, to contact me to see if we could organise another avenue for Mr Marr to try to clear his name. The minister was very sympathetic and was making inquiries about the matter. The memo says:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject—MARR—Feedback from Minister's office last Friday
Attention Gayle,

The Minister is still keen to find an avenue to help Marr. The Trish Cavanagh advice of Tuesday did not seem to work. The Minister's office is now asking the Department for further details regarding an Audit Report that was apparently favourable to Marr in some respect.

Not sure where this is going but we need to do more. Can you advise because W. Frank Blount is likely to speak to the Minister about this today. Please look at this and get Trish Cavanagh to tell us what the results were from the Minister's meeting.

Here they were, on their own admission, deliberately trying to find an avenue to discredit Mr Marr and to try to mislead the minister. The lengths that people have gone to and the things that have happened absolutely stagger me. This little memo—and there are many more like it—sums up the lengths, the time and the expense. Commonsense would say that $37 worth of cab charge documents really are not all that great and do not warrant spending this amount of money or going to all this trouble. I would have thought an organisation such as Telstra would have just paid up and shut up and got on with the job it is supposed to be doing.

PARA.TAB: But this matter is still going on; I still have questions on notice awaiting answers. No doubt the matter will drag on for another 12 months because Telstra will not admit that it is wrong. This memo shows everybody in the Senate what is going on behind our backs. The minister here was trying to help this particular person but the advice they had used to try to get him `did not seem to work'. I seek leave to incorporate this memo in Hansard. I have already spoken to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, about it and he has agreed.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —By convention senators do not take the time to speak on the third reading of appropriation bills. However, I do so only briefly to raise a very serious matter for the attention of the Senate. It arose from my questioning on the amounts being allocated through AusAID to UNFPA, particularly my questioning of AusAID on 23 June 1995 which appears at pages 247 to 252 of the Hansard of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee. I draw that matter to the attention of honourable senators because it indicates how little is being done by Australia, and indeed by some other countries, to assess the gross violations which are occurring daily in the People's Republic of China in the implementation of that country's fertility control policy.

PARA.TAB: What was most worrying, and why I bring this to the attention of the chamber, was the apparent acceptance by the official of AusAID that the implementation of that program is not regarded as coercive, apart from the suggestion that it was the result of actions or the administration of local officials. I particularly draw attention to the fact that, on page 251 of the Hansard, I asked Dr Helen Ware, an official of the department, a question based on a statement in a cable by DFAT from China. It was a report of a discussion between a DFAT official and the Executive Director of the Family Planning Commission in Shanghai. That cable said:

SPEECH.PARA: According to Liu, if for some reason there is a second pregnancy, the first step is education which in practice appears to be counselling to have an abortion. However, parents may insist on having the child, they will have to pay the state a fee of three times the yearly family income, payable over six years.
I asked:
Is that not coercion? Is that not said by an official, the Executive Director of the Family Planning Commission? Where are the zealous officials? Is that not coercion?
Dr Ware said:

In the Chinese view, if couples wish to have more children than is the government policy, given that they are provided with a very wide range of services for free under the Chinese system where there are not individual charges for almost all health services, for education services, where accommodation is subsidised and the like, it is the Chinese view that these very heavy imposts constitute a payment for the services which will subsequently be rendered to that child.
Is asked, `Is that accepted by AusAID?'. Dr Ware replied:

Though there is a range of exceptions, there are two levels . . . of what is imposed upon people who are in government employ and what is the practice in relation to the rest of the population who are not in government employ, and the very heavy fines, for example, what is imposed upon those who are in government employ as a payment, as I say, for the very many services that are provided to their children.
I asked, `Are you going to the Beijing conference by any chance?' Dr Ware said:
The delegation has not been officially announced, but it is my understanding that AusAID will be represented on that delegation.
I said:

It is very important when it comes to the question of Beijing. Here, if the woman does not have an abortion, the family is fined a fee of three times the yearly family income payable over six years—not my words, the words of the Executive Director of the State Family Planning Commission in Shanghai.
Dr Ware said, `Yes.' I continued by asking:
Official. Is that not coercion? Is that not saying, `You have an abortion or you starve'? Is that not coercion?
I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to what the response of Dr Ware was:

The time over which that fine has to be paid is negotiable. As I say, as that cable itself indicates, they are the conditions under which the rules relating to a first child, a second child or even subsequent children are imposed.

To my mind, and I believe to the mind of any reasonable person, that is horrifying. An officer of a government department refuses to accept that that is coercion. That person is likely to represent Australia at the Beijing conference on women.

PARA.TAB: This is a matter of human rights. I believe that this matter will gain a great deal of attention between now and the Beijing conference and probably at the Beijing conference itself. We in Australia must be clear on where we stand on this matter. Try as I may, I could not get a response out of the department—I believe that this should have been its response—that this is official coercion. Such coercion should be condemned by every human being, particularly when it is directed at the women in China. Together with the culture of the Chinese, it results in a gross distortion of the number of female and male babies born. There is gross discrimination against females.

I have raised it here today. I have placed a number of questions on notice. I asked a number of questions at that meeting. I expect that those answers will be forthcoming as a matter of urgency. It would be in the government's interests and in the interests of humanity itself for those questions that I have asked to be properly and urgently responded to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.
