SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Modification (Excise) Bill 1995 and associated bills will alter the sales tax law to give effect to the government's announcements in the 1995-96 budget. These bills continue a pattern of behaviour by this government which can only be described as typical because, in every budget of this government since 1983, amendments have been made to the sales tax arrangements in this country.

PARA.TAB: Some amendments have been reforms to the avoidance provisions within the acts. Some amendments, particularly in the early years of the government, were to reduce sales tax rates where it was deemed inequitable for goods to be taxed at particular rates. Most of the changes have been to remove exemptions and to raise the rates of sales tax applying and to alter the classification structure of goods to bring more goods into the higher sales tax bracket.

The government even added new items to the sales tax net to overcome what it perceived to be anomalies—cases where there was no logical reason why one good should be taxed and another should not. This is a most interesting point to remember and I will return to it a little later.

Given all these changes it should not be surprising to anyone to have to debate these tax changes today. It is not surprising that this government should increase sales taxes on certain products or for this government to remove exemptions. The government has form. It has a record—a record of continually adjusting the sales tax legislation, a record of continually adjusting the tax laws to raise more and more revenue from indirect taxes.

Budget Paper No. 1 provides an interesting analysis of the trend of government revenue obtained from sales taxes over the period of this government. In 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser government, sales tax returned $3.4 billion to total revenue, or 8.4 per cent of taxation revenue. By 1989-90, just before the recession, sales tax had risen to $10.1 billion, or 11 per cent of taxation revenue.

In the first financial year under the leadership of the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), sales tax raised $9.2 billion, or 10.3 per cent of tax revenue. For the next financial year, 1995-96, which starts on Saturday, should these bills be passed in their current form, the government will obtain $14.16 billion from sales tax, or 11.8 per cent of the total taxation revenue. To say that there has been a broadening of the application of sales taxes would be an understatement.

If government is to obtain its funds through taxes on the consumption behaviour of citizens, at the very least it should provide over a period of time for those citizens with the necessary income to make those purchases. Increasing direct taxation at the same time as increasing indirect taxation is to institute a double blow to the taxpayer. It would mean that individuals would have less money in their pockets after tax and would have to pay more for their sales tax loaded goods. This double tax is unfair; it is a tax grab. This double tax grab is unreasonable. This double tax grab has been the policy of this government ever since the current Prime Minister took office.

In 1992-93 the government raised $47.5 billion in revenue from income tax on individuals. In the next financial year, the government has forecast, it will raise $62.2 billion. Contrast those numbers—$47.5 billion at the start of Mr Keating's prime ministership and $62.2 billion next year. To paint an analogy: while this government has planted one hand firmly in the wage pocket of every Australian, in its other hand it has scissors actively cutting a yawning hole in the very same pocket. While wages disappear faster and faster through an ever-widening hole in the pocket, the tax bucket gets fuller day after day.

A distinction between the manner in which the government and the coalition treat indirect taxes is a very basic one: a principle. It is a principle upon which the coalition will stand proud and oppose these particular tax measures. It is a principle that we hear the people say they want from their politicians.

It would be wrong to suggest that honesty is an easy principle. It would be wrong to suggest that honesty should be a tradeable principle. If any member of this chamber would stand before any schoolroom at any level in our education system and have the audacity to advocate that honesty is a flexible principle, I dare them to say so. It is true that to be honest can sometimes hurt. To be honest will sometimes mean saying or doing things that cause suffering or hardship. Regardless, being honest is a principle that only those who want honesty can treasure. For those who do not believe in the need for honesty there is no value in the principle: they will mock those who treasure it and ridicule those who advocate it, but you will never hear them decry the need for honesty.

These bills which we debate today are not honest. They represent deceit, betrayal, and above all else they represent a pattern of behaviour that has resulted in the character of politicians being rightly abhorred by our fellow citizens. When this government attacked the coalition in 1993 for proposing the joint broadening of the indirect tax base and, at the same time, the reduction in direct taxes, the Prime Minister and his sycophants used ridicule and deceit. They portrayed the coalition as parties of higher taxation and greater government greed.

The fact of the matter was that this government had already determined that it would introduce higher indirect taxes without offsets. It had decided that it would increase direct taxation without any trade-off to the Australian taxpayer. It had decided that it would devise a false and misleading charade for Australians to admire and to contrast it with the difficult but necessary truth in the coalition's honesty. After the election the charade would be forgotten and the power of government would again be exercised to ruthlessly increase taxes.

The people of Australia must not forget. When the Labor Party hustlers come hocking their wares at the next election the Australian electorate will know that what they are selling is deceit, fraud, humbug, empty rhetoric and more false dawns. The Australian people will know that it was the Labor Party that not only proposed but introduced legislation to impose a 12 per cent tax on their hardware and building materials. The Australian people will remember that it was the Labor Party that increased taxation on the family car by 30 per cent. The Australian people will remember that it was the Labor Party that tried to tax the family home, not only as it was being built, but every time it was going to be repaired.

Every time an Australian enters a hardware shop he will remember that it was this Labor Party government that will tax all nails, plaster and putty in the shop. Come the next election, the Australian people will need to listen long and closely to the promises of the Australian Labor Party. If words such as `promise', `law', `guarantee', `assurance', or even `cross my heart and hope to die' are uttered from the mouths of the Prime Minister or any of his posse of amigos the Australian public will know that they are being wound up, led on, and probably deceived.

I strongly believe that the Australian people have heard this government cry wolf just once too many times. The government's excuses are not just thin, they are absolutely threadbare. Believe this government only if you like a good whack around the ears.

The government even has the audacity to blame the Senate and the opposition parties for potentially causing interest rates to rise. Even though it is the Labor government that has been in government for 12 years; even though it has been the Labor government that has been in charge of the economy for 12 years; even though it is a Labor government which for 12 years has had the entire public service at its disposal, including the economic talents of the Treasury and the departments of Finance and industry et cetera; even though for 12 years it has been the Labor government which has pulled the levers, manipulated the market and run the Reserve Bank—the government now accuses the coalition and the Australian Democrats of controlling interest rates. What bunkum, what nonsense, and what a cop out! If those ministers opposite are unable to manage the Australian economy with a potential reduction of less than one per cent of revenue it is time they surrendered, admitted their failure and total incompetence, and got right out of the kitchen.

While we are on the subject, let me knock down once and for all the myth that what the coalition is doing in opposing the government's new tax measures is somehow unique. Let me point out to those in the media who may have missed this point that the coalition will not oppose all the measures in this bill. Where those measures involve the modification of a currently existing parliamentary mandate, the coalition will not oppose the government's actions. Where the government is merely acting to clarify an existing law, the coalition will not oppose.

Indeed, it was a member of the coalition, the member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), who moved to amend the legislation to extend the definition of eligible disabled persons in schedule 2 of the bill. If the coalition is so negative, why would it actually move to amend the legislation to make it fairer? To the government's credit, it acknowledged the merit of Mr Hall's amendment and supported the change. The coalition does not seek to be politically expedient or to grandstand; it merely seeks to do what is right by the Australian people.

It will remain the responsibility of the government to justify to the Australian people why their musical instruments are taxed in the manner that they will be and why their scaffolding, racking, shelving, safes and recycled paper are taxed as they will be but, in any regard, the coalition will not oppose these government amendments to the sales tax acts. These changes involve the clarification of the current arrangements, and the coalition acknowledges the government's right to take action.

In regard to the coalition's opposition to those measures which raise sales tax on motor vehicles and impose sales tax on certain building materials, I quote, in part, the words of a currently influential Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . these measures represent a repudiation of a pledge made not to broaden the indirect tax base, they will have an adverse effect on the living standards of Australian families, they will affect the equity of the tax system in a quite regressive away and they will most certainly add to the inflation rate.

Do you think these words are of a rampant Liberal, hell-bent on forcing up interest rates? Maybe they are the words of an angry, economically manipulative Democrat. No, they are the words of the current Treasurer of Australia. They were the words of Ralph Willis, when he and all the Labor Party voted against the tax changes introduced by John Howard in 1981.

PARA.TAB: The Labor government is simply two-faced. In fact, it is more than that. I quote from another senior Labor parliamentarian of the time, who argued that the coalition's 1981 proposal could be rejected by the Senate, because:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there can be no question of a mandate of any kind for these particular sales tax Bills—direct or indirect, specific or general, implicit or explicit. As I have said already, the possibility of more indirect taxes either as a supplement or as an alternative to income tax simply was not floated at the time of the last election . . .

Which election are we talking about? In which election did the government of the day fail to float the possibility of raising indirect taxes, not to mention direct taxes? In fact, again, the quote is from 1981 and comes from the current foreign minister, Senator Gareth Evans.

PARA.TAB: Does anyone remember the Labor Party talking about raising taxes at the last election? I do not think so. Does anyone remember the Labor Party ever floating taxes on building products during 1992 or 1993? From where does the government draw its mandate to raise these taxes now? The fact of the matter is that this government set the rules in regard to how to handle sales tax proposals in the Senate. The government set the precedent and the government will now have to live by its own standards.

I would like to conclude by quashing one of the further myths that the government would like the media to run with, to distract from its incompetence with regard to the current budget. The Labor Party will say that the opposition is hypocritical because, when it comes to government, it may not remove the impositions proposed by the government but would use the revenue for its own budgetary purposes. Once again, the government in this instance has form. To discover this form, we must go back 12 years to the start of this government. When it entered government, did it abolish the previous government's taxation initiatives which it had voted against previously? Not on your life!

Any future government must start with the revenue base it is left with by the previous administration. Where the coalition differs from the government is that any changes which the coalition may introduce in government will be part of a comprehensive taxation and expenditure program. What the government is proposing in these bills is merely a further extension of the sales tax base from the sanctuary of government. If the Labor Party wants a mandate to increase taxation, let it propose that to the Australian people at the next election.

This brings me to a point I made earlier. If this government wants to impose a sales tax on certain building materials, what is there to stop it from extending the tax to all building materials after the election? Nothing but the Australian people at the next election. If the government is so confident of its mandate to introduce this tax, let it take it to the Australian people. Let it be clear to all Australians at the next election that the Labor Party wants a mandate to tax its building materials. I look forward to seeing the Labor Party's slogan for the next election. Perhaps I could propose one—`For a tax on your home, vote Labor'.

I remind honourable senators again of Prime Minister Keating's 1993 election promise, when he said, `What I am promising is not to put up tax.' We in the opposition therefore oppose the tax increases on motor vehicles and building materials. I give notice that in the committee stage I will be moving amendments to that effect. What we have said all along is that we will oppose any tax increases against what the government promised in the lead-up to the 1993 election.

In conclusion, I reiterate that as the government of the day, it is this Labor government which must take responsibility for the budget and what it contains. The only good thing about this budget is that it ensures that the Labor government will not be the government of the day for much longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important package of bills. It puts in place much of the government's $700 million of increased sales taxes via the budget. That is in addition to the extra $600 million of sales tax to be collected because of the automatic one per cent rise that has flowed on since John Dawkins's 1993 budget. That automatic increase begins on 1 July. The combination of that measure in the 1993 budget and this one actually means that the government raises over $14 billion in sales tax. That represents an increase of over 50 per cent on the $9.2 billion collected just three years ago.

PARA.TAB: We have avoided the ongoing debate since Australians said no to a GST, but we are still collecting an awful lot of tax via indirect tax measures. I think the wholesale tax regime is preferable to the goods and services tax at this point. Nevertheless, we really should be talking about the merits of broadening the tax collection in this way.

The extension of the sales tax on building materials, in the Democrats' view, represents a breach of faith between this particular government and the electorate, but particularly home buyers. It was this government which promised, prior to the last election, that it would not increase taxes on building products, yet here it is doing exactly that.

We all remember what was quite an hysterical anti-GST campaign. We saw the dozens of claims made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and others about the impact of the GST on housing. As a matter of fact, the Prime Minister wrote to all builders in 1992 warning that the GST would add $4,000 to the price of a $100,000 home and that under his tax legislation, building materials are completely exempt. He further said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that there be no drastic changes of policy which would choke off economic activity.
In question time on 4 November 1992 the Prime Minister said, quite clearly:
The Government is not about taxing the building industry.

In talking about extending the sales tax base, we are really reminded of the Prime Minister's unequivocal comments. In that respect, they do represent a breach of faith. This is the second time this government has tried to tax building. In 1986 Paul Keating proposed a broad-based consumption tax. That does not mean that the coalition does not have a record which is not worthy of scrutiny: it does. In 1981, when John Howard was the Treasurer—

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the Democrats' record?

—We have been totally consistent and have voted against it each time, which is more than we can say for any of the other parties. As I was saying, when John Howard was Treasurer in 1981, his government tried to tax building. Again, in 1993, we saw a proposed GST on building. The Democrats have always believed that shelter is one of the necessities of life. You can draw a distinction with expensive granite tops in kitchens, but a kitchen cupboard in a kitchen is part of essential shelter. For 15 years we have been consistent on this issue of sales taxes on the necessities of life.

PARA.TAB: This package of bills does four things. First, it seeks to broaden the sales tax net to cover a wide range of building materials that were previously exempt; and, second, it seeks to restore the rate of tax on passenger motor vehicles from the concessional rate of 15 per cent to the general rate of 22 per cent. It is claimed that this reverses the anti-recessionary concession granted in One Nation in early 1992. We have talked to industry. It is true that the industry has recovered—and the Democrats will be supporting this measure.

The third thing in the package is a number of measures designed to protect the sales tax base. That includes scaffolding, safes, racking, shelving, musical instruments and model aircraft. The Democrats will support this extension. The fourth thing the package seeks to do is increase the rate of sales tax on recycled paper from zero per cent to 22 per cent. The Democrats strenuously oppose this. Senator John Coulter will speak to this in detail.

As I have stated, extending the sales tax net across building products is a breach of the government's pre-election commitments. Further, we believe the timing of such an extension is ill-judged and inappropriate. We have had a high interest rate policy under this government and we have the highest real interest rates in the OECD.

The building industry is in free-fall at the moment. Housing commencements are down 34 per cent on their August peak. Unemployment in the construction industry has risen by 10,000, with Australia's largest builder, A.V. Jennings, putting off 30 per cent of its work force since March. In 1996-97, commencements are expected to drop below 130,000, well below the anticipated demand of 152,000 recently set by the indicative planning council.

This collapse of confidence in the industry is starting to bite. It is noticeable in the rental market where investors are simply refusing to invest in new stock. The result has been a slump in vacancy rates and a rising trend in rents. The vacancy rate in Sydney has halved in the last 12 months and, at 1.4 per cent, it is close to the worst point reached in the 1980s. Melbourne's vacancy rate has fallen from five per cent at the beginning of 1994 to 2.4 per cent. In Perth it is down from 4.5 per cent to 2.9 per cent, while Brisbane and Adelaide are trending downwards at a slower pace. That rate usually means higher rents. In Melbourne, rentals are up 10 per cent in a year and Sydney agents are predicting a similar rise.

We should not forget that the safety net is leaving renters behind because, in this budget, the government has cut funding for public housing. It has cut $6 million from rental assistance. Public housing starts are already down from 12,000, three years ago, to fewer than 7,000 this year. Waiting lists are rising; they are up by 37,000 in the last three reported years. That is a bit of a gloomy picture.

On top of that, the government proposes a tax which would add about $1,000 to the cost of an average new house and about $700 to $800 to the cost of an average kit home in the $70,000 to $80,000 price range. I think it can be argued and demonstrated that, in this debate, the government has deliberately sought to underestimate the impact of this tax. Its $215 million revenue estimate has been shown to be wrong, while its price impact has also be shown to have been understated. For those reasons, the Democrats will be opposing this tax.

I turn briefly to the issue of recycled paper, because I think the government's policy in this area is in an absolute shambles. Australia, by international standards, has a fairly good recycling record. It could be better. There remains strong consumer resistance to recycled products in stationery. Many types of office equipment, such as photocopiers, are still not able to take recycled paper without adjustments, and there remains a significant cost differential between recycled paper and paper made from virgin pulp. Despite all of this evidence, the government is determined to dampen demand for recycled paper products by making them more expensive. The government proposes to spend $4.5 million to persuade consumers to pay more for recycled paper and to persuade offices to collect more paper waste for recycling. There will be little or no point encouraging the collection of paper waste if there is no market for the product at the end of the day.

We are told that, in removing this exemption, we are levelling the playing field on paper products. We keep being told about level playing fields across the board, but this is particularly incorrect. There is no level playing field on paper products. Virgin pulp products carry a very high environmental cost in terms of energy consumption and the pressure that they place directly and indirectly on native forests. As we have pointed out before innumerable times, the timber industry, especially in the logging of native forests, is propped up by massive government subsidies. The accumulated debts of the various forest services exceeded $5 billion. That is public money. A lot of our virgin pulp is still imported, exporting our environmental problems to other countries. If waste paper is not re-used, it adds to our own waste disposal problems. I really think a sound economic case as well as an environmental case can be put for supporting concessional tax treatment of recycled paper.

The final issue I want to deal with is the role of the Senate with respect to budget bills. This week we have seen a constitutionally dubious attack from the Prime Minister on the role of the Senate in dealing with budget matters. Let me take this opportunity to answer him in a couple of respects. I need to point out to him that history has brought significant changes since 1975, and one is the existence of the Democrats. The Democrats do not support the blocking of supply. While we have the balance of power in the Senate, supply will not be blocked. There will not be a repeat of the 1975 constitutional crisis.

The second point I need to make to the Prime Minister is the difference between taxation bills and supply bills. I am sure that he knew he was making an over-the-top claim. Nevertheless, I point out to him that the current Treasurer (Mr Willis) joined with the Democrats to block this same tax on building materials. That provoked our current Senate leader, Senator Gareth Evans, to give an excellent exposition to the Senate at the time on the difference between taxation bills and supply bills. Perhaps the Prime Minister needs to be reminded of these differences. In 1981 Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: The relevant distinction . . . on the one hand Bills which are crucial to the survival of a government, and . . . on the other, those which do not satisfy that description. In the former category are undoubtedly those major supply and appropriation Bills . . . perhaps also in that category of packages of Bills . . . are some major taxing Bills, for example, Bills to establish the whole system of personal income tax . . . In the latter category are included those lesser money Bills which impose fees or fines or make particular appropriations of perhaps a few hundred thousand or even a few million dollars for some particular purpose, or Bills which impose taxes, generally speaking, and do not satisfy the description of being measures which are essential to the survival of the Government.
The sales tax legislation . . . is undoubtedly in the latter category of lesser money bills which cannot be regarded on any analysis as essential to the survival of a government.
He went on:

It is not . . . unacceptable . . . for this Senate . . . to oppose the passage of Bills in respect of which the Government not only lacks an explicit mandate but also in respect to which, given its pre-election commitments, it has been profoundly dishonest and hypocritical.
We could not say it better ourselves this time, could we? All of those arguments still stand.

PARA.TAB: The denial of the $215 million extension to the sales tax via building materials will affect less than one-sixth of one per cent of the government's $124 billion revenue haul. It has had a negligible effect on interest rates. It will not affect the government's declared bond issuance target of $3 billion to $4 billion. It is quite clear that the government's policies which have caused a $27 billion current account deficit have a more significant impact on interest rates than the amount of $215 million. As a matter of fact, since the Democrats announced our position on the building tax two weeks ago, interest rates and bond rates on the financial markets have fallen further. So it was just a first stage in the psychological warfare that has been going on around this budget. Far from the Senate overplaying its hand, I think we find in this case that the government has overplayed its hand.

The Democrats have had discussions with the government on alternative revenue options. The Treasurer sensibly says he will wait and see what happens to the budget at the end of this week before wishing to pursue further discussions. As I said, I think that is totally understandable. It also indicates to me, though, that it is not a huge issue at this point. I think the government has no mandate for taxing building. Also, it has no good economic argument to support the extension of that sales tax. As a result of the combined vote of the Democrats and the coalition, the government will have no building tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today a package of bills relating to sales tax which are directly linked to the 1995-96 budget. As Senator Gibson and Senator Kernot said, the government did not listen to the very early messages that were sent with regard to this legislation and certainly made some shocking judgments in putting together the initial budget.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased that in his response two nights after the federal budget the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made it patently clear that the federal opposition would not be a party to the impact of the sales tax on building materials and home ownership throughout Australia. It is good news that two weeks ago the Australian Democrats reached that same position and made their announcement.

The budget implications that I will address today are confined to the aspects affecting building materials and home ownership. I suggest to people that they go back a week or so and look very carefully at the situation that surrounded the resignation of Mr Howe as the Deputy Prime Minister. There is a lot to do with this piece of legislation that has affected Mr Howe's career and his status within the Labor Party. In coming months we will see his demise as the Minister for Housing and Regional Development as a consequence of these issues. Of course, we know that he is exiting the parliament at the next election.

But I would argue that there was a budget collusion between the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, the Treasurer, Mr Willis, the Minister for Finance, Mr Beazley, and the housing minister, Mr Howe. That is very interesting when you look at the budget figures in this particular area. The amount of money allocated for the better cities mark 2 expenditure and the amount of money to be collected from this wholesale sales tax on building materials is strangely coincidental and almost identical—some $230 million to $240 million.

This particular budget has been blatantly manipulated. I would love to have been a fly on the wall for some of the considerations that must have taken place because, as demonstrated to our estimates committees recently—and I will come to that a little later—there was no real proper consideration of how the estimates for this wholesale sales tax on building materials was calculated. There was no proper and appropriate assessment between the Department of Housing and Regional Development, the Department of Finance and the Australian Taxation Office. That was obviously not properly done and not properly constructed—and that has now become very obvious.

This year, the government set out on a politically motivated budget—it set out to do no more than manipulate a so-called budget surplus. The inner sanctum of cabinet traded funds between certain programs knowing the gamble that it was taking—and that gamble is not paying off as was planned. Look at the interest rate philosophy—if you can call it that—of this government: it is nothing more than a series of inconsistent statements and there is no underlying principle whatsoever.

A few moments ago, Senator Kernot referred to the way in which this government is handling the current account deficit and the lack of policy in that area where we are seeing the impact on interest rates that again have such a disastrous effect on housing. Of course, talking about deficits, we need only to look at this government's asset sales strategy to see that it is not going to be a budget that is going to result in a surplus. If anything, it will be a billion dollar plus deficit this year. It is a real shame that in so many of these areas on which the deficit impacts—housing affordability, rents and public housing waiting lists throughout Australia—the government is seeking to blame the opposition or the Australian Democrats for any adverse effects on interest rates. What a load of bunkum!

I hope historians will have the opportunity to quiz Mr Howe who was then Deputy Prime Minister and housing minister to see the real effects and the strange deals that were done in putting together the patchwork mosaic of this year's budget. No wonder Mr Howe has had to resign very early after the budget from his position as Deputy Prime Minister and give notice that he is on the way out in the other areas.

The sales tax legislation proposes to modify sales tax law to remove the exemption from a range of certain building materials which, if the bill is passed in the Senate, will become taxable at a rate of 12 per cent from 1 July 1995. Thankfully, that looks like not happening. As Senator Kernot said, the bill is certainly a breach of faith that has been established against this government, against Mr Keating and his previous statements and against the intent of the housing minister, Mr Howe. Again I ask: why has Mr Howe walked away since February this year in the preparation of a major housing initiative statement to this parliament? It has been deferred month after month after month and is yet further evidence that he was shafted by the economic ministers in cabinet and was not able and is still not able to bring forward the housing initiative statement.

The coalition's position in opposing these bills has been well documented since the government's announcement on budget night. The proposed wholesale sales tax raises financial barriers to home ownership and will add, as we have seen from the industry group representations made to many of us, about $1,000 to the cost of building a home. That is not to mention what it will add to the very extensive programs of renovation that most existing home owners throughout Australia engage in from year to year or the effects that it will have on people renting in both the public and private sectors. We have seen well-documented figures in that area.

I would argue very strongly that low income earners, younger households and, at the other end of the spectrum, pensioners and retirees will be particularly hard hit if this legislation is to pass. There are no offsetting measures to compensate low income groups. The compensation deals that Mr Howe did were all in the better cities program and are all related to a totally different area, so they would not have a direct co-relationship. There have been some strange deals in that particular regard.

This package of bills was referred to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, which met last Friday. At that public hearing industry bodies gave evidence about the detrimental effect that this tax will have on Australian home buyers, on those people who wish to maintain or renovate their existing homes and on the building industry in general throughout Australia.

It is interesting to note that the whole committee, including the Labor members, stated that it had to draw the attention of the government to, firstly, the effect of sales tax on off-site manufacturing of bathroom and kitchen cabinets which may result in less efficient construction on site, thus negating the efficiency gains achieved by the industry; and, secondly, the need for transitional provisions relating to stock on hand in the building industry and more precise definitions for builders' hardware. That was in the majority report, and that included the input of Labor members who were being critical of the government in that area.

I will also turn to the excellent minority report that was put forward by my colleagues Senator Panizza and Senator Crane. They knew and were able to accept and see the more important issues that arise here. Both Senator Panizza and Senator Crane suggested that industry expected job losses resulting in skilled labour within the building industry diminishing; that the level of rental assistance would have to be increased to compensate low income earners for the sake of the new tax; and, thirdly, that for every worker losing his or her job with the building industry, one other in the supply manufacturer line would also lose his or her job. So Senator Panizza and Senator Crane very rightly pointed out that there were a lot of flow-on consequences that were going to be brought about by this particular legislation.

The tax proposed by the government is a blatant attack on Australian home owners, home buyers and so many other people throughout the community. It will have a very wide effect across the entire community. I was absolutely staggered when Senator Cook, in his summing up at last Friday's committee hearing, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not aware of any convincing evidence that persuades us to in any way change the estimates we have given.
He also said:
. . . it is not simply a matter of imposing a tax, it is a question of improving the tax regime.

Senator Cook obviously sat through last Friday's hearing with his ears closed. Obviously he was not listening to any of the evidence that was presented. His statement smacks of the same rhetoric wheeled out by Mr Keating when Treasurer back in 1988 when he was justifying extending the sales tax on bathroom fittings to adjust a couple of anomalies.

PARA.TAB: The ministers of the government, whether it be the Prime Minister, Mr Howe or Senator Cook, obviously had a fixation with the deals that were done in the anterooms to budget cabinet. The coalition and the industry have continued to question the methodology used by the Labor government both for the estimated increased price of a home and for the revenue raised by the impost. The government has continued to refuse to reveal its calculation or its methodology on revenue raising. On the other hand, the housing industry has put together its calculations and its methodology and has put it on the table for scrutiny by all concerned. Senator Cook just waves it aside with the brush of a hand.

The government appears to be unconvinced—not unconvinced, just damned ignorant. It is not prepared to accept good argument when it is put forward. The Treasurer, Mr Willis, has now admitted that he understated the tax on a new home. He had previously stated the tax would add up to $400 to the price of a new home, and, in parliament on 6 June, he admitted the figure was more likely to be $800 on a median home. They are his bodgie calculations, not related to any of the decent material that is obviously available. Senator Ian Macdonald in the Senate yesterday, when raising a question, produced evidence from a quantity surveyor in North Queensland that established that considerably higher costs would result in this particular area.

The 1995-96 budget estimates that the revenue gain will be $215 million, $235 million in a full year and $245 million in 1996-97. It is strange that they are so widely different from what the industry is saying. The industry estimates that the revenue grab will be at least $576 million per year—2 1/2 times the government's estimates. We must surely question the methodology used by the government and Treasury.

Let me take you back to the estimates hearing of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee of 5 June 1995. The Australian Taxation Office was asked about its involvement in estimating the revenue effects of this tax. The ATO stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in relation to this specific initiative, this matter was entirely in the hands of Treasury.

The ATO was given very short notice—only a matter of days—of the prospect of some changes. Perhaps this was part of what Mr Howe was doing with his better cities trade-offs around the corridors of budget.

PARA.TAB: The ATO did not have sufficient information at its disposal to fully estimate precisely all of the elements. Treasury went with its own estimates on these specific initiatives. There is no mention anywhere of any discussion or arrangement with or advice from the Department of Housing and Regional Development that ought to have been advising Minister Howe. Obviously, figures were plucked from the whiteboards of the budget cabinet.

The Australian Taxation Office revealed that, in the area of sales tax: `Treasury is increasingly relying on its own revenue estimating models.' The Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Treasury are obviously out of whack with each other and are not being properly consulted by the processes of budget cabinet.

I would argue that these answers by the ATO reveal that the last minute manipulations of budget estimates now appear very well established and evident; that the Treasury had no intention of consulting either the Australian Taxation Office or industry on its methodology, and it certainly cannot be proven to be effective; and that the partnership between the ATO and Treasury of coming together and comparing their information, of generally agreeing on consistency between different techniques, has sorely broken down.

The reason the ATO has been left out in the cold is purely political. I would ask: where was Mr Howe's department in this process? There is no evidence whatsoever. Mr Howe has obviously been so frightened off by this entire escapade that he has resigned as Deputy Prime Minister and he has put in the never-never basket the major statement on housing initiatives.

What have we seen lately in terms of the impact on housing? We have certainly seen the government's inconsistent and stupid policies with regard to interest rates having a huge impact on home buyers throughout Australia. We have certainly seen the effect on housing affordability and the cost of housing. This legislation will force up the cost of housing even further; that point is well-established and demonstrated. It would force up drastically the cost of renovation and improvement to homes. I argue that the people who would feel the effect of that most are Australia's ageing population. Self-funded retirees and pensioners generally at that point in life make either major improvements to their home or change their home dwelling situation. The costs would be disastrous without any offsetting compensation.

I do not believe I need to remind the chamber that, if implemented, this proposed new building tax will hit more than three million Australian households per year. Home ownership would be affected. Housing tenants would have to suffer the consequence of increased rentals. Public housing would have to face increasing pressures as more and more people enter the waiting lists. There would be pressures on state and territory governments.

There would be so many consequences that it is patently obvious there is no alternative for this Senate but to reject this measure. I am pleased to see that the Australian Democrats have agreed with the initiatives of the coalition. On budget night and in Mr Howard's response to the budget we outlined what we would do from day one. The government has cheated on the Australian public with regard to these proposals.

The new sales tax on building products is totally unfair and unnecessary. This legislation ought therefore to fail, just as this government will surely fail in the eyes of the electorate when it next faces the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure to take part in this debate on the sales tax legislation. I take part in all debates on sales tax bills and tax bills generally in this place. Firstly, I want to address the sales tax on building materials. Let us go back to recent history—2 1/2 years ago—around the time leading up to the last federal election. Mr Acting Deputy President, you could probably remember the cry that went up from the Labor government of the time at our suggestion that we would impose a GST on building materials. If you remember back that far, you will know that there was going to be a 15 per cent GST on building construction. But that did not include labour. I forget by how much that was going to put up the price of a house at that time, but I remember that it caused a great furore. The government made sure that it told a lot of lies about our intentions.

PARA.TAB: Two and a half years down the track, what has this government decided to do? It has decided to do exactly the same thing and apply a sales tax to building materials. Perhaps it can get away with it for the moment—I will address this in my speech before I finish—by saying that the effect of its increases will be a lot less than what we had intended. Our rise might have involved costs in the vicinity of $2,000 to $3,000.

When I questioned the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) the other day at a legislation committee hearing dealing with sales tax, I pointed out these things to him. I pointed out what the Labor government had to say at the last election. I asked him for a good reason why it should bring the building industry into it by adding a sales tax to building materials. All he could say was that housing in Australia has never been more affordable.

I have not often agreed with Senator Kernot but I think she blew that argument out of the water just 20 minutes ago. On the figures that she has, housing is nowhere near as affordable as the minister told me the other day. Senator Kernot also has figures to show that the vacancy rate has gone down. If housing, new or otherwise, is as affordable as the minister told us, you would think that rental vacancies would be higher. That is what normally happens.

I remember the situation in 1985-86 when there was a big boom in building and a lot of young couples, just as they did in 1983-84, moved into houses. I am involved in rental units in Perth and I recall that at that time the vacancy rate in Perth went up to six or seven per cent and that rent went down.

Senator Kernot pointed out that rent is going up and that, nationwide, the vacancy rate is down to an average of 2.5 per cent, while in Western Australia it is down to about two per cent. So how could the minister have sat there last Friday and told us that housing has never been more affordable?

He was not right but let us suppose for one minute that he was because that would put the lie to how well this government is going. If houses are more affordable, if the cost of construction is coming down because of demand, that means people, especially young people, have no confidence in the future, particularly of this government.

The minister told us that there was an overrun in the building of new houses. If you take that together with this supposedly greater affordability, you would think that people would be moving into first houses left, right and centre, but they are not. You cannot have it both ways. Either people have no confidence in the government and in its economic future or houses are not more affordable.

The government's impact statement said that this new measure would add only $400 to the cost of building a new house. There is plenty of evidence to the contrary, and Senator Tambling has just contributed to that. We had a submission from the Housing Industry of Australia and the Master Builders Association to the effect that this measure would add 1.1 per cent to the cost of a median house. A median house is presently costed at $95,000 by averaging the cost of the cheapest kit home up to the so-called luxury homes.

By my calculations, using the estimate of an additional 1.1 per cent, that adds up to an extra $1,400 on the cost of a new home. Yet we were told by this government that this measure would add only $400 to the total cost, raising $215 million in revenue in 1995-96 and $249 million in 1996-97. That is totally wrong. The quantity surveyors have evaluated the situation with regard to the median house and have shown that this measure will raise a far bigger revenue figure than even I have estimated. The government's figure is a total lie.

A circular was sent to all Labor members of parliament—not to us, of course—in which it was admitted that the rise in the cost of a house because of the sales tax increase would be around $1,200. The Labor Party members were also told how to explain it away. We have received evidence from the Housing Industry Association and the Master Builders Association of Australia. Builders employ quantity surveyors and are in a better position to tell us the facts than the people from Treasury who appeared before the committee last Friday. The government tells us that this measure will raise $249 million in a full year but we have evidence that it will raise $576 million.

It is not going to be any different from any other new tax. At the last election this government told us that there would be no new taxes and no increased taxes. We can go back to the days when this government introduced the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. The estimation of revenue from those taxes was very much at the low end but it was doubled and trebled in good time. This government has a history of underestimating the revenue received from new taxes.

The coalition's proposed GST may have caused the price of a house to rise by something like $2,000. When this government admitted that the increased cost of a house was around $1,200 it left something out. I believe it was left out by design because it comes under a different bill—the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill. This concerns the diesel fuel levy. We are about to be hit with another massive increase in taxes. The rebate on diesel fuel used in the mining of clay for bricks and for firing the bricks when the clay is in the furnace will be removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is going to be the cost per house?

—I was coming to that. I am glad you reminded me, Senator Tambling. When the legislation goes through the manufacturers of clay bricks will no longer have the diesel fuel levy rebate. The same situation applies to those who mine the clay.

PARA.TAB: I do not read out a lot of letters that I receive from industrial unions in Australia, but I will read out one that I have here because it seems to stick out. It is a letter from the Federated Brick, Tile and Pottery Industrial Union of Australia. The letter was sent to the minister, but it was drawn to my attention as well. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We understand that the Budget will result in a withdrawal of diesel fuel rebates for the Mining of Clay used in the production of Clay Bricks. As over 95% of houses built in Perth—
that includes the whole state of Western Australia—

are constructed of double brick, the vast majority of which are double clay brick, we consider the withdrawal of the diesel fuel rebates to be an unnecessary additional cost which will inevitably lead to increases in the cost of housing in Perth—
as well as in the rest of the state because we have transport costs as well—
Very clearly such costs increases will be an addition to the substantial cost increase for new home construction arising from the new 12% sales tax on builders hardware.

This letter is from one of your own unions. The letter did not have the full quotation, so I then took the liberty of ringing the union—and it is probably the first time I have rung an industrial union in my life, except when I ring them now and again to tell them to get off the backs of my employees—and I found out that the union estimates the increase is approximately $2,000 for an average house.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two thousand bucks!

—Two thousand dollars for an average house. You have $1,200 that we have pointed out already—and there is another item that I have to mention—plus $2,000, which makes the increase $3,200. We are now well ahead of what was proposed by the GST, which was lied about so much when the election was on.

PARA.TAB: There is another item that I have not mentioned yet, and this came out in evidence before the committee last Friday. When builders have to put something extra into a house or they have to make an extra charge—whether he pays on your behalf the rates or the building permits that you get from the shire council—they have to put that in their book work. Whether you are putting in an extra window, an extra cupboard or something like that that was not in the original plan, they generally charge a builders margin. The builders margin goes up and down, depending on what the state of play is in the building industry, whether or not it is buoyant. I can tell you, from my building experience, that it is 15 per cent. You have to add on another 15 per cent. If you put 15 per cent on the whole $3,000, you arrive at $3,450. In that quick summation, I have probably forgotten a few other things.

There are some figures around from quantity surveyors, and we have the figures from a quantity surveyor from Queensland. A quantity surveyor has to be spot-on—he is expected to be within two per cent with his estimation. The building industry can be rather competitive, and a quantity surveyor who is out on his quotations, I do not think, will get too many more jobs.

I have calculated already, without other things, that the increase would be up around $3,450. That is the situation as far as the sales tax on building materials is concerned. That is why the coalition decided on budget night that we would be opposing it.

I would like to mention another point, and that is the effect of the building downturn on employment—and I am sure the government is interested in employment, as it believes it is going to get employment down to some reasonable level if it does happen to be in government much longer, which will not be the case. You must remember that the building industry has a multiplier factor of two. In other words, if one person loses their job in the building industry, one person down the line—whether it is in transport, manufacture or building materials—will also lose their job.
I showed to the previous minister at the table, Senator Bolkus, two charts on the effect on employment in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate these charts in Hansard.
Leave granted.
