TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time that I have left, there are a couple of other points that I do wish to address. One is the five per cent increase in sales tax on cars. You might remember about three years ago that that five per cent sales tax was dropped to try to boost car sales. Whether that failed to bring about extra sales or not, the government has decided to—
—It succeeded.

—It succeeded, did it? It has succeeded, so now you are going to turn it around completely and undo whatever success you had at the time, plus add another one per cent. It is just like when the government—I think it was two budgets ago, or it might have been the last budget—increased the levy on leaded fuel to encourage people to change into newer, more efficient cars, which use less unleaded petrol and cause less pollution and all of that. What is the government doing now? Some people, especially young people, were saving to buy a new car. What did this government do? It put another five per cent tax on new cars, plus another one per cent because of indexation.

PARA.TAB: I would briefly like to address the matter of air safety bags in cars. The air safety bag is a very efficient way of preventing loss of life in head-on collisions. Just like any other item in a car, they are taxed. The cost of an air bag will rise from 15 per cent to 22 per cent, adding over $100 to the cost of an air bag. There is evidence relating to the cost of road crashes in Australia. A minor accident costs $6,000, a moderate accident costs $25,000, a serious accident costs $58,000, a severe accident costs $201,000, a critical accident costs $427,000 and a fatal accident costs $479,000. There is evidence to show that air bags will bring down the amount of fatalities by at least seven or eight per cent. So it is very easy to see the cost benefit of fitting an air bag into a car, especially for the driver, to prevent those fatalities which happen as a result of a head-on collision, with the head hitting the steering wheel and killing people on the spot. At least the encouragement of fitting air bags would reduce the number of fatalities in Australia in road accidents and the cost to society.

In summing up, the government stands condemned for the increase in the sales tax, especially on building materials. It stands condemned for the lies that were told about the effect of it. From what I have heard from the Democrats, that income will be denied to it, and that is what this bill deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pick up where Senator Panizza left off. It is untrue that the opposition is opposing all tax increases. The issue that I want to take up in this legislation is that the one tax increase—which is related to a very important environmental matter—that this government is imposing on recycled paper, from zero to 22 per cent, is the one the opposition is supporting. That is the point that I want to stress in my speech this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: The opposition clearly has not been supporting the interests of small businesses, which are mainly involved in the recycled paper trail. It has bent to the pressure from the large paper manufacturers—the monopoly paper manufacturers in Australia—and is therefore supporting the increase in sales tax on recycled paper because those large manufacturers do not have a great deal of interest, which I will demonstrate in this speech today, in making paper from recycled fibre. The opposition is supporting that tax increase. The government is actually proposing that tax increase and moving against a very important environmental measure.

When I spoke on the appropriation bills in this chamber only a few days ago and when Senator Margetts spoke yesterday in relation to competition policy, we were both emphasising the need to relate taxes to policy, to make taxes an instrument of policy and to use taxes as a way of guiding your society in a desirable direction so that you increase the taxes on certain activities which are regarded as undesirable—the activities that you want to discourage—and you place bounties in the way of those industries and those activities that you want to encourage. This is one of the principal ways you actually move your society in a desirable direction. Strictly speaking, it is also in accord with the proper interpretation of modern economics—as Senator Margetts, who was debating this point yesterday, said—that is, to internalise the externalities.

In the making of paper we do very considerable damage to our forests. We cut down our forests, we make them into paper, send the paper to the tip or burn it and then we cut down some more trees. There is a very significant cost involved in doing that. There is a cost in terms of loss of resources and environmental damage, consequent upon the processes which are used in the manufacture of the paper, and a considerable environmental cost in the disposal of the paper if it is not recycled. Those costs have to appear somewhere in the product so that consumers will make the correct choices.

Economics tells us that people are basically driven by greed; they will buy their goods and services for the least possible cost. While we do not accept that, that is the economic theory. If intelligent decisions according to that model are going to be made then the right price signals have to be given to potential consumers. The right price signals are the prices which include the full costs; not only the direct costs of manufacture and distribution but the environmental costs which are generally borne elsewhere in the community. Those costs include the costs of resource depletion, the costs of water and air pollution, the costs of collection of garbage and the cost of landfill in terms of the loss of amenity and space in the urban area. All those costs should be represented in a proper economic system in the price of paper.

SPEECH.PARA: What we find is that this government does not accept that as a principle. This government has totally divorced the idea of taxation from the idea of furthering policy. The government sees tax simply as a way of raising revenue wherever it can get that revenue, irrespective of the consequences in terms of the direction in which it leads our society. It sees policy as something quite separate.

Indeed, we have the ridiculous situation with respect to recycled paper in which the government is evidently saving somewhere between $5 million and $10 million depending upon the way the tax is finally rigged. Yet, it is spending approximately $5 million to encourage people to use recycled paper. If the government really believed its economic rationalist rhetoric it would recognise that if the cost of the recycled paper goes up as a consequence of the imposition of the 22 per cent tax, then it is asking people to act against their own self-interest, according to its own economic model.

PARA.TAB: The government is going to spend $5 million of our money to encourage us to do something which is against what we are supposed to be doing; that is, behaving as economically rational people by buying paper for the least cost. I have a few figures here which indicate this fact. They also indicate the way the industry—which is being encouraged by the government and the opposition—has moved recently, not only to anticipate this increase in tax on recycled paper but to positively discourage people from using recycled paper.

I have been written to by a constituent who pointed out that in his office in May 1994 recycled paper from Australian Paper was selling for $5 per ream. By February 1995 the cost had gone up to $5.81, an increase of 16.2 per cent. After the exemption is lifted, it will go to $6.91, an increase of 38.2 per cent; whereas, with non-recycled paper, just to take one example, Copyright paper in May 1994 cost $5.67. That was more expensive in May 1994 than the recycled paper, which sold for $5. By February 1995, the cost of Copyright paper had risen to $6.28, an increase of only 10.8 per cent compared with 16.2 per cent for the recycled product, bringing the prices closer together. After the sales tax exemption is lifted, it will rise to $6.28, an increase of only 10.8 per cent. In other words, it will be the same price as in February 1995.

In that case, the recycled paper cost $6.91 per ream, whereas the copyright paper cost only $6.28 per ream. Which economic rationalist—I say `which' because I would not say that these are fully human people who behave in this economic rationalist way—would pay $6.95 for recycled paper when the non-recycled product could be bought for $6.28? The $5 million which the government intends to spend to encourage recycling will be totally ineffective and a waste of money.

Some years ago, on behalf of the Australian Democrats I first moved an amendment to remove sales tax on paper made from recycled fibre. The government and the opposition combined even then to vote against this eminently environmentally sensible move. Within only a few short weeks, the government, evidently wanting a few greenie points from the conservation movement, saw the pragmatic political stupidity of such a move and introduced legislation very similar to that which it voted against only a short time before. It removed the sales tax on recycled paper.

Several years later in the 1993 budget, the government sought to reimpose the tax on recycled paper. Evidently at that stage it felt that it could do without the conservation vote. It did not genuinely care for the environment; it was simply using this as a measure to look good with the environment groups. As honourable senators will recall, in 1993, with the opposition opposing every part of the budget, the Democrats were in quite a strong position to bargain with the government. We went in and bargained with Mr John Dawkins, the then Treasurer, and we were successful in getting in place a bounty scheme which in the first year exactly equalled the sales tax. In other words, sales tax would be paid on recycled paper of 20 per cent and the manufactures would get in return a 20 per cent bounty. In the second year, that bounty was reduced to 15 per cent and in the third year 10 per cent. That bounty scheme has now ceased and is no longer available. The sales tax on certain of those products is now back at 22 per cent without any relief whatsoever. The government is seeking to increase the sales tax on those products to 22 per cent and for a range of other products which are currently totally sales tax exempt from nought to 22 per cent so that there is an across-the-board sales tax of 22 per cent on all paper, whether made from recycled material or not.

Our record in this regard is absolutely impeccable. As was the case in the building materials debate, we have been absolutely consistent that the taxation measures put in place should reflect government policy. If you want society to move towards ecologically sustainably development, you must internalise those external costs. The one way open to government to do that is through the taxation system. The taxation system must be used as an instrument of policy and as a way of internalising those externalities, those environmental costs that do not appear directly in the cost of manufacture or distribution of a good or service.

We will therefore be moving amendments when we get to the committee stage. I forewarn the Senate that we will put forward two sequential amendments. The first set of amendments—and this is our preferred position—will seek to remove the sales tax totally from all paper products made from recycled fibre. However, if the government and the opposition are not minded, as we believe they are not, to accept that amendment, we will seek to amend the legislation in such a way that there will be an across-the-board 11 per cent sales tax on all products made from recycled fibre. In other words, the concessional rate would apply to all those products which are made from recycled paper. This would still maintain a differential in the taxation between the products made from recycled paper and those which are made from virgin fibre, those products which have a very significant impact on the environment. So that there is no confusion in this rather difficult area of legislation, I foreshadow that that is the procedure we will follow. We will move one and then, if the first one is not accepted, we will move the other one.

I make an appeal to the opposition, which has claimed very loudly in the community that it is opposing all tax increases in this budget, to honestly implement what it has claimed and not to differentiate between or drag out of that claim paper made from recycled paper. It should not accept the government's increase in this area. If the opposition is seeking, as the government did some years ago, to get some support from the conservation groups, this is a very low cost way of doing it—that is, to support the Democrats' amendments, to be honest in what it has claimed and not to support this vicious increase in the tax on paper made from recycled fibre.

Of course, as far as the government is concerned, its proposal is environmentally damaging, it is irresponsible and it is inconsistent with its proposed implementation of ecologically sustainable development. But we have known for a long time that the government is really not committed to ESD. The government is committed only to the rhetoric of ESD and not to implementing the hard decisions which would underline the implementation of ESD policies, one of which is to differentiate by way of taxation between products made from recycled materials and products made from virgin materials.

I forewarn the Senate of those amendments which we will be moving. I plead with both the government and the opposition to see the good environmental sense in what the Democrats will be proposing by way of amendment and to support our amendments when the time comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to contribute to this debate on the sales tax legislation. I begin my comments by saying that I have just come back from the pork producers rally at the front of Parliament House. That industry is a good example of what happens to an industry through high taxing and high cost policies. Of course, this sales tax legislation is about putting further taxation imposts on people. We all know that the pork producers have problems with the importation of Canadian pork. I certainly believe that countervailing duties should be applied to those imports. Of course, the countervailing legislation in this country is not satisfactorily picking up those problems.

PARA.TAB: What do the problems of pork producers have to do with this legislation? If this country had a cost structure comparable to that of the Canadian producers, they would be unable to afford to get that pork over here and put it into the market, despite their subsidies. Yet, while this nation continues policies which effectively tax out of business so much of our productive sector year after year, month after month, week after week and day after day, we will continue to see these sorts of problems.

We have the ridiculous situation in this country where the `Made in Australia' label does not mean made in Australia. That also applies to the imported pork. I know that pork production is subsidised in Canada, but even when it arrives here and is put on the Australian market, it wears the label `Made in Australia'. What is going on?

Last Friday at the estimates committee hearing a number of surprising aspects of the budget were raised. I refer to the imposition of sales tax on building materials. Apart from hearing evidence on the general items of taps, cupboards, hinges, locks, doors and a whole range of other items, I found it remarkable that the government is also imposing a sales tax on such things as safety items.

The issue of sales tax on air safety bags in cars was raised by Lauchlan McIntosh of the motor car association or some such similarly named body. Why is the government taxing this safety measure? The government is also imposing a sales tax on safety locks fitted to medicine cupboards to prevent access by children and on safety locks for cots. Going through these issues, one must question the morality of the sales tax regime. Why is the government going down this path?

Then there is the vexed question of what cost the increased sales tax on building materials will add to a so-called average home. I have not seen too many average homes that sell for much under $130,000. However, we were given evidence that on a house costing $95,000, item by item, the 12 per cent sales tax would increase the price by $1,040. There would be very few places in Australia where you could actually buy a new home for $95,000. In fact, looking at a family three bedroom home, you would pay much closer to $150,000 even in the cheaper suburbs of our capital cities.

In Western Australia, Perth is not noted as being a high-cost housing place. One only has to go around and have a look at what is on the market to find that the figure of $150,000 is about the cheapest one will currently pay. One can get a one-bedroom unit for about $110,000 to $120,000, but that could hardly be classified as a family home. I challenge the figures that have been presented to us in this place by a number of ministers as they are very loose indeed. I believe they are, plainly, wrong. One can see that the impact of this measure will be much greater on a family with three or four children.

Really, it comes back to a fundamental point. One has to look at this in the total context of the budget. We find in the budget, and it is worth repeating, that the total tax take has increased from $103 billion to $117 billion in round figures. In actual fact there is a total tax increase coming out of this year's budget of $13.7 billion. The problem this government has is that it is not prepared to bite the bullet as far as expenditure is concerned. That $13.7 billion is the largest taxation increase in any one year in the history of this nation.

I put it to the government in terms of this legislation, and the coalition has made its position absolutely clear on it from day one, that this is a very ill-conceived tax indeed. Although it took them some time to get to a position, I am pleased to see that the Australian Democrats are now supporting us in this area. Other evidence given to us stated that extra revenue would be in the order of $235 million in 1995-96 and $249 million in 1996-97, but the committee received research that demonstrated that the figure could well be double that amount.

One could raise many aspects regarding this legislation, but there is one other thing I wish to raise. We need to have a fundamental change in direction regarding costs in Australia. To address that we need to look very carefully at the expenditure side of the budget. We need to take some action on the expenditure side of the budget so that the cost to industry, the cost to individuals and the overall structures under which we operate come more into line with those nations we compete with.
I am glad to see that Senator Bob Collins has come into the chamber at this particular time because, as we know, he has the responsibility for primary industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm glad somebody is glad to see me.

—I am always pleased to see you. I will repeat what I said at the start. Despite the problem pork producers have with the dumping or countervailing—and I think there is a combination in that regard—if our cost structures in this country were similar to those of Canada, the Canadians would not be able to get the pork into Australia to sell it competitively.

PARA.TAB: The taxing regime is part of the problem, the industrial and processing systems are part of the problem and our inspection arrangements are part of the problem. Those arrangements are currently being addressed, and I acknowledge that. But we have to attack all these fronts. Australia would not need to import pork if we had comparable cost structures for our producers.

The diesel fuel excise legislation will come up for debate shortly. We have managed to claw back much of what was taken away, but not all. This is an example of our adverse cost structures. When we compare what producers overseas have to pay for fuel and the impact that that has on their cost, one has to question very strongly the direction that this government has taken in recent years to lower our costs across the board. The way we will beat imports is not by technical legislation, which will be contested in the courts; we can and will beat the problem if we get a cost structure that allows us to compete at the same level as producers overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words on these sales tax bills that are before the Senate at the moment and to supplement and fully support the remarks of my colleagues who have spoken in this debate. These bills continue the lies and deceit in the whole area of taxation policy of this Keating Labor government. I am sure Australians will remember that, in the 1993 election campaign, Labor's sole campaign strategy was opposition to a new indirect tax—remember the no GST campaign of the Labor Party?—despite the fact that that campaign ignored that the introduction of a GST was to be part of a major restructuring of the tax system which would make it more modern and more efficient and would lower the overall taxation burden.

PARA.TAB: It is therefore amazing that we are today debating bills which increase and broaden the government's major indirect tax base, which is the highly inefficient and discriminatory wholesales sales tax. It should also be remembered that this is the second time in just three years that we have been debating in this place massive sales tax increases, despite the election promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in 1993 `not to put up tax'.

In these bills before us, sales tax on motor vehicles is increased. It is up from 15 per cent to 21 per cent, which is a six per cent increase. But it is six per cent on 15 per cent, which means that the sales tax is going up by more than one-third. From 1 July certain building materials, if the measure were to be passed, will be taxed for the first time, at 12 per cent. The bills also remove the exemption on certain recycled paper products, which means a further tax increase in that area. Taxes on safes, musical instruments and ornaments are going up to 11 per cent. The tax on scaffolding, racking and shelving will go to 22 per cent from 1 July. Even the tax on model aircraft will be going to 22 per cent from 1 July.

Taking the last two- or three-year period, these measures cap off almost the greatest range of tax increases in Australia's history. They certainly cap off the greatest electoral deceit in Australia's history. Everything that this government has done in the area of taxation since the last election has involved virtually breaking off all the promises that it made prior to the election and on which it was elected. The government has no mandate for virtually any of these tax measures.

In February 1992, the government cut the sales tax on motor vehicles from the then 20 per cent to 15 per cent. That cut at that time was stated quite categorically as being a permanent reduction. The government said that it would not be reversed after the election, yet it now has been. It is another broken promise from this government.

In the lead-up to the 1993 election, Labor government ministers, including, in particular, the Prime Minister, promised not to broaden the indirect tax base. They would not have a broad consumption tax in any shape or form. In fact, they already did in the form of the wholesale sales tax. But, as I said at the start of my remarks, that wholesale sales tax is a nightmare of complication and discrimination between different items. Because of its discrimination, it is unfair, inequitable and very costly for the payers of sales tax to comply with. It leads to a huge range of anomalies, which, as we know, very frequently finish up in very costly disputes with the Australian Taxation Office. Those disputes frequently end up in the courts at great cost to all concerned and the overall efficiency of business in Australia.

Having failed to get rid of the wholesale sales tax, and having done virtually nothing to improve its efficiency and reduce its inequities, the government has now added to the disaster of the wholesale sales tax system by expanding it to cover a number of items, which I have already mentioned, that are currently exempt from such tax. That does constitute the breaking of a seemingly very firm promise by the government before the election that there would be no new taxes.

This extension and broadening of the wholesale sales tax system will result in new taxes to a range of goods that were not formerly taxed. There is no way that the government can avoid the charge that this is a broken promise and that it did lie to the Australian people before the election about its real intentions so far as taxation was concerned.

Since 1992-93, which was the last election year, sales tax has risen from $9.3 billion, or $9,252 million to be exact, to an estimated figure for this next financial year of $14,160 million. That is an increase of $6,000 million, or 53 per cent, over a three-year period, and it has occurred in the life of just one parliament. We have to go back to the Whitlam years of economic infamy—those times that absolutely wrecked the Australian economy for many years thereafter—to find anything approaching the tax rip-off that has occurred in the life of this present parliament.

I remind the Senate again that in December 1992 the Prime Minister promised to not put up tax. In real terms, sales tax has been increased in real terms in each of the succeeding three years by 11.4 per cent, 9.5 per cent and 18 per cent respectively. That adds up to an increase in the total tax take from indirect tax over that three-year period of 53 per cent, which is half as high again as it was just three years ago.

This package of tax bills should be called the sales tax (broken promises, electoral deceit and government lies) amendment bill 1995, because that is what these bills represent. They are major contributors this year to the government increasing its revenue in percentage terms by the second highest amount since the Whitlam budget of 1973-74. Only once in the ensuing 22 years have we had an increase in total revenue of a higher percentage than we are having this year. That one exception in those last 22 years was the Hawke government budget in 1983, when the total revenue intake, due to a budget of massive tax hikes, went up by a whisker more than it has this year.

Taking the total tax revenue for this year and last year into account, the total increase in revenue for the two-year period will be higher than at any time since those years of economic infamy and wreckage of the Whitlam government. It is a very serious matter because it increases the cost structure and makes business less competitive. It makes it very much more difficult for businesses to earn a profit, to be able to save, to invest and to create the jobs we need if we are to get out of the economic mire that we are in.

I use the word `mire' advisedly. Look at the underlying problems of this economy. We have virtually the lowest savings of any country in the industrialised world. We are at an almost record low with savings by our own historical standards. We have a huge debt to the rest of the world of $165,000 million that is mounting daily. When this crowd opposite came into office 12 years ago that debt was of the order of $20,000 million to $23,000 million, so there has been an eightfold increase in our debt to foreigners over that period. There is no single action that any government can take to lessen a nation's independence and real sovereignty more than to put it into hock to the rest of the world, as this government has done.

This government stands condemned on its performance record over the last dozen years. The great tragedy for the economy and for every Australian is that this budget, and these tax bills which are an important part of the overall budget package, will compound that problem. That is why the coalition, on behalf of the Australian people, will very strongly oppose the major items in this package of tax bills.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will proceed to debate matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I rise on the very serious issue of long-term unemployment in this country. When voters are polled to find out what they see as the most important issue, unemployment comes out at the top time and time again. This was understandable during this government's long recession which extended from 1990 to 1993, but it is interesting that the public still quite correctly perceives that the greatest issue facing this country is unemployment. The most disadvantaged group within the list of unemployed is the long-term unemployed.

PARA.TAB: According to the government, we have 263,000 people classified as long-term unemployed in this country. When we have come out of previous recessions the long-term unemployed have pretty much stayed long-term unemployed. However, on this occasion the official figures show that the numbers have been reduced quite dramatically.

Today I want to expose this sham. The reality is that the numbers of long-term unemployed are not declining dramatically; they are declining to some extent. By a whole range of measures, including defining people off the list, the government has created a situation where we have the illusion of a reduction in long-term unemployment. This is extremely dangerous because it lulls people into a false sense of security. People think, `Oh, this major problem is at last being solved. We can stop worrying about that.' They direct their attention away from it. That is very dangerous because long-term unemployment is creating an underclass of very underprivileged people in this country. If that persists, and if it grows over a long period of time, it can threaten the whole fabric of our society. That is what is so deceitful about the government's action.

From his very close analysis of the figures, Dr David Kemp has been able to reveal that the government's white paper and the various programs on unemployment based on the white paper are currently in tatters. This came out very strongly in the budget. The government tried to put it forward as a victory by saying, `We have solved the problem. We don't have to spend as much on these sorts of programs.'

The reality was that the private sector was starting to reduce unemployment. In its attempt to come up with programs like case management, the government was not able to get the programs in place in time to spend the money that was actually there. What the government did was very deceitful. The government was not cutting real items in the budget; it was cutting off the forward estimates of what it thought it was going to spend and parading this as being responsible economic management. The government claims it will cut $1.2 billion from Working Nation over the coming four years.

I remind the Senate that this program had been in place for only one year. The government is back-pedalling on a program largely because of its failure; a failure which it is trying to hide from this nation. Working Nation is not working. The only thing that is working is the ALP propaganda machine and its objective is to conceal the truth from Australians. It is an attempt to churn the unemployment queues, transferring people from one scheme to another and changing their official status. But that does not get rid of the reality. The situation facing the long-term unemployed—whether they be on official lists or hidden—still remains a disaster.

Another feature of this government's strategy on this matter is to mislead the nation. That was driven home to me recently when I sat rather open-mouthed in a public auditorium in Brisbane, listening to a speech by a local member Wayne Swan, at a conference on unemployment. He was crowing about how successful the government's strategies were. He said, in opening the conference, `We are leading the world with our approach to labour market intervention.' I thought it was absolutely amazing that at a conference on unemployment—that was the whole focus—this member, who, I think, is chair of the caucus economics committee, was actually misleading these voters, who are also the major players in the field, about the situation for the long-term unemployed. I could hardly restrain myself at the conference, but I did manage to do so.

As the proceedings are being broadcast today, I thought the Senate would be a better forum in which to raise this matter, so that the whole nation can learn about this deception and we can put this permanently on the record. Allow me to clinically dissect how Mr Swan misled people on this issue. Labor claims that the number of long-term unemployed has actually fallen by 25 per cent in the last year. That is not only untrue but also is a dishonest misrepresentation. Labor keeps trotting out that the number of long-term unemployed has fallen from 351,000 to 263,200. It trumpets this as a huge fall of 44 per cent in the long-term unemployed, particularly that group aged from 15 to 19.

Dr David Kemp, in particular, has nailed down this fraud. His persistent questioning of Minister Crean has revealed the stark truth. The Senate estimates questioning of DEET has played a part in exposing these facts. This ALP government has had to admit that about half of the so-called dramatic fall in long-term unemployment is shonky. It is the result of reclassifying people after they have been through a job program. They are reclassified, even though at the end of those programs those people are still out of work. This political scam is laid bare for all to see.

About 70,000 of the long-term unemployed in this country are in short-term labour market intervention programs for about 13 weeks. That is the same labour market program as Wayne Swan was lauding in Brisbane the other day. When they participate in job training with skillshare, newstart or jobtrain, they are stripped of their long-term unemployed status. They lose the benefit of the extra assistance offered to the most disadvantaged if, at the end of that process, they still have no job.

They go through a six months training and job program and if, at the end of that, they do not get a job they go back into the queue, but at the end of the queue. They are no longer part of the long-term jobless. Often these are people who might have been out of work for two or three years. They get six months of training and work experience but—guess what?—at the end of it, they are no longer classified as long-term unemployed. This is the way the government has managed to bring down this figure. It is artificial, and it is a sham.

These people who have gone from the front of the job queue to the back of the job queue are given false hopes under these programs, and they end up being kicked in the teeth and are back in the dole queue. The only transparent winner in all of this is this ALP government, which has undertaken this exercise. It is able to then claim falsely that long-term unemployment numbers are falling.

All of these Australians who are in this situation become demoralised pawns in this Labor government's pre-election plans to give the wrong impression that its job programs are working. So far I have discussed only the official unemployed. When you add in, as you must, the people who are the hidden unemployed—and those people have simply given up—the problem for this country and for those individuals becomes immense.

The reclassification of people without finding them work is a cruel hoax. It destroys the will of these people to succeed. The long-term unemployed, who are stripped of that status after training for 13 weeks, are big losers. They lose out in the following ways: they lose the one-to-one case management because they are back on the job queue; they lose the first choice of jobs and further training placement; and under the jobs compact, they lose attractive job subsidies of up to $12,000 to employers who might take on the most disadvantaged. Having had their go at it, they go back to the back of the queue and they have to wait before they become eligible under the long-term unemployment programs again. Honourable senators can imagine the effect on the morale of these people. It is all because the government is out to create an illusion which will score them political points at the expense of some of the most disadvantaged people within the community.

There was a story in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 June reporting evidence given to the Senate estimates hearing when we questioned DEET earlier this month. That revealed another government deception in the long-term unemployed area. Up to 17,000 spouses will now be added to the unemployment numbers. The unemployment spouses will be transferred from their existing DSS payments and registered with the CES from 1 July. Finally, the spouses of the unemployed will now be properly identified as being unemployed as well. These are 17,000 unemployed people formerly hidden by the ALP government. This measure seems like some honesty from Labor, but when we look further, the hand of deception appears once again. Always on the lookout to distort the long-term unemployment figures, the government is unashamedly at it again with this matter.

According to DEET's first assistant secretary from the employment program, a big percentage of the spouses will not be classified as long-term unemployed; they will only be said to be at risk of long-term unemployment if their spouses have been without work for 12 months or more. Even if their spouses have been out of work for many years or never worked, they will be denied the classification of long-term unemployed and therefore denied those programs and benefits that are associated with it. Why? Because this Labor government is determined to keep the long-term unemployment figure artificially down, totally for political reasons.

Again, some of the most seriously disadvantaged people in the community go back to the rear end of the unemployment queue and are denied special help. This is a glaring example of Mr Swan's world class labour market intervention program. The reality is that Labor offers a merry-go-round of deception. This government has proved masterful at concealing the truth and its cruel policies are a hoax on the long-term unemployed.

PARA.TAB: I rise to speak about the government's media hit squad, the National Media Liaison Service. Honourable senators would be aware that this has been a continuing matter of controversy in this chamber and elsewhere, with reference to the expenditure of $1.5 million per annum on the National Media Liaison Service, often referred to as `aNiMaLS'. Its purported purpose is to provide accurate and timely information on government programs but, in actual fact, it seems to have spent much of its time, money and resources in following and attempting to embarrass the opposition. There has been a purpose in a number of Senate estimates hearings to inquire further into just what this service has been doing.

During the Senate adjournment debate on 19 June I made a speech in which I outlined my very great concerns that Senator McMullan had misled this chamber and, indeed, misled the Senate estimates committee regarding the nature of Mr Epstein's employment and his title. By way of background, at an earlier Senate estimates hearing we had asked Mr Epstein to table his contract, which Mr Epstein claimed showed that he was the director of the Ministerial Media Group. As it turned out, when the document was tabled it showed no such thing.

It is no coincidence, I suggest, that on the following day, 20 June, Mr Epstein received a letter from Mr Frank Walker telling him that Mr Walker had decided to establish a position of director, National Media Liaison Service, so the duties that Mr Epstein was performing in relation to the National Media Liaison Service would not continue. On 22 June, when we again pursued the matter of the National Media Liaison Service, Senator McMullan said among other things that the document which was tabled in the Senate, on Mr Epstein's contract, was not complete and that Senator McMullan regretted that.

I think there have been some media reports on this issue, but the fact that Mr Epstein has been removed from his formal duties, at least, with the National Media Liaison Service, can be overstated. The reality is, as we discovered, that Mr Epstein still has complete access to the work of the National Media Liaison Service. When we look to see the real reasons why Mr Epstein was removed—or sacked—from his formal association with the National Media Liaison Service, we find that he was causing serious embarrassment to the government.

Mr Epstein has built a bit of a career out of attempting to embarrass shadow ministers. What has happened in recent months is that Mr Epstein has embarrassed ministers. It is not surprising that, as a result of the embarrassment that clearly he caused Senator McMullan, within 24 hours Mr Epstein was sacked from his position in the National Media Liaison Service.

It is the practice of this government when serious errors occur—and there was a serious error, as Senator McMullan recognised, of misleading the parliament and misleading a Senate committee—to hide behind public servants and staff members. Mr Epstein was just the latest in a long line of staffers that have had to take the fall for ministerial behaviour and ministerial incompetence.

The real issue is not Mr Epstein and his particular activities. The real issue is: what has the National Media Liaison Service been doing? How has it been spending $1.5 million per annum of taxpayers' money? Has that money been spent properly? All the evidence to date suggests that there has been an improper use of taxpayer funding. Mr Epstein was given a sleazy job to do by ministers. When the temperature got a bit hot, Mr Epstein was removed.

It remains to be seen, of course, whether the National Media Liaison Service continues to act in the same fashion. I put it to honourable senators that the sacking of Mr Epstein is not the fundamental issue involved here. The fundamental issue involved here is that ministers have set up a unit, which cost the taxpayers at least $1.5 million, pretending that that unit does a particular task which is to provide timely and accurate information on government activities but, in actual fact, it is directed to do another task. So I wish to give notice to this chamber that this matter simply does not rest because of the sacking of Mr Epstein. In a sense, that is neither here nor there, but just acts as a warning to the staff of all ministers that, when the going gets too tough, they will be required to take the responsibility rather than the ministers themselves.

As I said, the coalition will still be pursuing this matter. The question is: how has the $1.5 million which has been spent on the National Media Liaison Service actually been used? There are two particular courses of action which we are considering. We are planning to seek an amendment to the Audit Act, and there is a bill currently before this parliament to allow the National Media Liaison Service to be subject to an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General. I expect that motion to enjoy majority support in this parliament. Of course, that efficiency audit will have to look at the activities of the National Media Liaison Service in the last 12 months. So I put it to honourable senators that this may well help finally to determine just how this money has been spent. Alternatively, we have the option to establish a Senate inquiry into the use of taxpayer funds by the National Media Liaison Service.

I signal that the sacking of Mr Epstein will not stop the inquiries by this Senate into just how the government has misused taxpayer funds. We now have a new director of the National Media Liaison Service, a Mr Michael Fishpool, I understand. I have given notice that we will be regularly seeking information from Mr Fishpool on the activities of the National Media Liaison Service. He, of course, has the option to ensure that this service performs in an appropriate manner to provide timely and accurate information on government programs. We will be checking very closely to see that that is done, and we would expect Mr Fishpool to maintain comprehensive records of the work activities of the National Media Liaison Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of them.

—As my colleague Senator Abetz said, all of the activities. We will also be seeking assurances from Mr Fishpool that he has not been misusing taxpayer resources to monitor and track the shadow ministers and coalition spokesmen and spokeswomen on various issues, but that he will be concentrating on the prime task of that unit. We will be checking to make sure that the obligations that have been stated are fulfilled so that, for example, come elections, the National Media Liaison Service does not have any role in the election campaign and its activities do not become party political. We will be making sure that Mr Fishpool or whoever ultimately ends up as director—
—I would think that would go without saying.

—As my colleague Senator Boswell said, one would have thought it would go without saying, but we have seen how this government has behaved and we can regrettably not assume that, Senator Boswell. I put on notice that, despite the sacking of Mr Epstein, the fundamental problem still remains. The government has not been willing to tackle that problem. We are determined to find out just how that $1.5 million has been spent. The new director may well have a chance to establish the National Media Liaison Service on a new and proper basis. If he does, good luck to him. If he does not, he will have to explain very carefully to Senate committees just what he has been doing.

PARA.TAB: This afternoon I wish to undertake a brief analysis of His Excellency the Governor-General's comments on the occasion of the Arthur E. Mills oration of 21 June 1995. There are two aspects of His Excellency's comments on which I wish to comment: firstly, whether the comments should have been made at all; and, secondly, whether the comments stand up to scrutiny.

It is inappropriate for Australia's head of state to speak on controversial and divisive matters whilst he is the holder of that office. If one expects and accepts all the benefits and, indeed, the privileges that are attached to the position of Governor-General, then it is encumbent on the incumbent not to immerse himself or herself in politically divisive issues. The role of Governor-General is designed to provide a unifying force; a symbol of what the country and its people stand for. That unifying force—that symbol—becomes tarnished and diminished once it is immersed in the divisive political issues of the day.

His Excellency has done both himself and his office an unfortunate disservice, but every cloud has a silver lining. In this case, the silver lining provides to the people of Australia a foretaste of the type of intervention that will undoubtedly occur on a regular basis by the head of state if we go down the Keating path of constitutional change.

The main purpose of dealing with His Excellency's contribution is not so much to discuss the inappropriate nature of his remarks but to join issue with him on the matters raised. Implicit in His Excellency's comments is a world view which is atheistic, selfish and harsh, and built on the shifting sands of trendyism rather than on the true and tested standards of the ages.

His Excellency summarised his speech by talking about a whole lot of `rights' which are allegedly key principles in a liberal democracy. I happen to be one of those old-fashioned people who was told that rights never come alone; they always come coupled with a countervailing duty. Indeed, the Liberal Party, in item 6 of its We Believe document, says:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that rights connote duties, and that sectional and selfish policies are destructive of good citizenship.

PARA.TAB: His Excellency tells us that we should not have the state impose a narrow predetermined form of morality to which all are supposed to conform. The message sent out to the community is that there is no need to abide by the laws of the country. Why conform? Do your own thing. The message is that, if it feels good, it is okay. In case you think that I am doing His Excellency an injustice, listen to his comments and I will place particular emphasis on the aspect of self in the comments. His Excellency says:

SPEECH.PARA: In short, I must rule myself by my own judgement and my own conscience. The authentic life is led from the inside by what one genuinely and decently believes, rather than having those things imposed from the outside . . .

If that is the guide to one's life, there is no outside objective benchmark to enable the establishment or determination of the morality or appropriateness of your own or, indeed, somebody else's behaviour. As long as it comes from the inside and you feel it genuinely, it must be okay.

PARA.TAB: Social conventions can be badly flawed, as stated by His Excellency, but, with respect, I would have thought that there is also the very real possibility that one's own views and approach to life can be badly flawed. I often test my views against the considered views of other people who have gone before me in order to see whether I can learn from them. Usually I come out on the side of accepting the social convention and mores built over years, decades and, indeed, centuries.

Implicit in His Excellency's remarks is the concept that, if you are a genuine racist and if you feel from the inside that racism is right, then do not be dissuaded by the social convention that all people are equal. I am sure that Adolf Hitler and Stalin felt, and Saddam Hussein feels, passionately and genuinely that their cause was and is morally correct.

The social guideposts which His Excellency has told us have been removed or replaced in this modern age are the objective standards by which we judge and determine the appropriateness of our own code of conduct and the code of conduct of others. When human beings have no target outside themselves, they turn inwards and focus on themselves as being the centre of the world and the focus of their constant attention.

As one of the socially unifying forces within our country, the Governor-General's message of self falls far short of the message of community focus that many Australians would have expected. A message of hope would have been more appropriate. A message to the unemployed, the aged, the infirm and the disabled that they are just as much a part of Australian society and just as much Australians as the Governor-General and other privileged people would have been most welcome. Instead, we hear in His Excellency's speech people described as `unproductive burdens' of whom society ought to be `disencumbered'. I find that phrase horrifying. I find it particularly horrifying that the government has seen fit not to dissociate itself from that highly insensitive, if not offensive, remark.

How on earth can one describe any human life as being an unproductive burden? The callousness of that remark fills me with genuine concern for those who may have felt that the remark was directed at them. It also fills me with genuine sorrow for the person whose considered thought processes allowed him to make that remark. What is an `unproductive burden'? Economically unproductive? Socially unproductive? Should the unemployed feel that they are a burden on society? Should the aged feel that they are a burden on society? Should the disabled feel that they are a burden on society?

Rather than talking of `unproductive burdens', let us talk of hope and the future. To the unemployed, give the avenues to feel part of mainstream society. To the aged, give the feeling that rather than being a burden they are entitled to the benefit of the fruit of their labours. To the disabled, give the feeling that their disability is one we, from our more fortunate position, will share with them. Above all that, let us say to every Australian: `No matter what your lot in life, your life will never be a burden on society because you are an integral part of society. Your lot in life is also my lot in life. Your lot in life is also our lot in life.'

His Excellency talks of his own full life and his `apprehension' facing old age. He then refers to a couple who apparently suicided together because there was nothing awaiting them but `the emptiness of death'. That comment is a sad reflection of a life that has no hope. I genuinely feel for His Excellency, who appears to embrace this view of the emptiness of death. Let me quote a Ronald Reagan analogy. The then President of the United States said:

SPEECH.PARA: Sometimes when I'm faced with an unbeliever, an atheist, I am tempted to invite him to the greatest gourmet dinner that one could ever serve, and when we finished eating that magnificent dinner, to ask him if he believes there's a cook.
I happen to believe that there is a cook—a chef.

PARA.TAB: As soon as credibility is given to the concept that there is such a thing as a life not worth living, we start using terms such as `unproductive burdens'. We set the scene for liquidating those lives that are somehow considered burdensome, unproductive or unwanted. As His Excellency said about abortion, it `is about unwanted children'. If we can have unwanted children aborted, unproductive burdens euthanased, what stops the next and very easy step of ridding our community of antisocial elements by the death penalty? If we feel comfortable with getting rid of unwanted children, why not unwanted adults?

His Excellency canvassed many other issues which I cannot respond to today, and, therefore, I have dealt with what I consider is the most important issue, the inherent God-given and created value of human life. If we no longer regard human life as special by reference to the old social guideposts, we are left with a void and a sense of meaningless for our lives and for those of our fellow human beings. If we want the fruits of the old social guideposts, we also need the roots, trunks and branches to sustain the fruit. Without the roots, trunks and branches, the fruits will wither.

Personal freedom cannot exist in anarchy. Freedom can only exist in a shared basis of community, law and beliefs. I trust that His Excellency's foray into this public debate will allow many Australians and, in particular, legislators, to realise that, in the words of Dame Enid Lyons:

SPEECH.PARA: The problems of government are not the problems of statistics but the problems of human values, human hearts and human feelings.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start my address on the pork industry, I associate myself with the remarks made by Senator Abetz. The comments that His Excellency made concerned me very much, and Senator Abetz has put the matter of the Governor-General's address very clearly.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge the presence in the gallery today of many pork producers who have come to Canberra. I rise today to inform the Senate of the parlous state and the most serious plight that the Australian pork producers find themselves in. At this very minute, apart from the people who are in the gallery there are probably another 800 or 900 strapped pork producers who have sacrificed important time and money to travel to Canberra to inform the federal government and the parliament that they need some attention and that they need it now. They cannot wait.

Problems are attacking pork producers from all directions. These problems are intolerable because they are from areas which are totally beyond the control of pork producers and totally beyond their ability to manage. One of the problems is the high cost of grain feed as a consequence of the drought. Grain prices have risen to unheard of levels. Feed costs form 70 per cent of a pork producer's costs, and, because pig farmers are deemed not to be directly affected by the drought, they are not eligible for drought relief despite the increased costs the drought causes them.

Pork producers are presently the largest user group of grains and so the increase in prices is very burdensome to them. It is no wonder that 20 per cent of pig farmers have been forced to leave the industry in the last six months. Such steep rises in costs would, under normal circumstances, place a severe financial impost on producers. However, today's producers also have to contend with the historically high level of subsidised imports flooding into Australia which are selling at 30 per cent below the production cost for Australian producers.

Canadian pork receives a massive boost from the subsidies given to Canadian grain producers, and, with grain forming the major import cost, this gives the Canadian farmer an unusually unfair advantage. These subsidies mean Canadian farmers can produce a kilogram of leg meat for $1 to $1.15 less than the Australian farmer. This is a huge advantage and it is one that the Australian farmers are finding very difficult to compete against. Canadian industries are coming in and securing long-term forward contracts with Australian buyers at 30 per cent below what Australians can meet.

The danger for the industry arises because imports usually start hitting the industry in the peak Christmas period, and the high incidence of imports so early in the year can only result in further losses of producers to the Australian industry. Already we have seen 20 per cent of the industry reduced. In a last desperate stand, a last desperate plea for help, members of the industry have come down to plead their case to the government today. Senator Crane and I will be asking the government, at question time, to produce a policy that will be responsive to the needs of Australian pork producers.

Imports are at their second highest level ever and are assaulting a weakened industry. The industry has already invested heavily in an anti-dumping action against Canadian imports. I know that because we in my office were instrumental in helping the industry prepare its case in many ways, even successfully moving an amendment that would have helped the pork producers to win their case. That amendment was made with the support of the Liberal and the National parties.

The decision went against Australian industry on the basis that the massive grain subsidies were not direct enough to the pig industry, despite the reality of the enormous boost that subsidised grain prices would give to Canadian farmers. Having invested both years and hundreds of thousands of dollars in mounting an unsuccessful anti-dumping case, the industry has to ask itself what else it can do to fight against the unfair trading position in which it finds itself a victim.

On top of this there lie two issues that the federal government can help with. The first is the delay that the government is creating in the introduction of a truthful origin labelling system. This would enable the Australian consumer to buy the true Australian pork product. Then there is the threat in the near future from the government introduction of more imports based on an expanded minimum risk disease policy. I do not have to tell the Senate of what happened yesterday, when the government allowed imports of pilchards into Australia. Such imports could have infected and been responsible for the huge kills of domestic pilchards right around Australia, not to mention the risk that it has put the salmon industry in, in the state represented by my colleague Senator Abetz, Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the bee industry.

—And the bee industry, yes. What I am saying to the government is this: overseas people want to buy our clean, green Australian product. We can demand a premium on our primary industries because our product is virtually disease-free. But when the government turns over all the time and lets imported products in as a minimum risk, it is exposing and putting at risk Australia's primary industry.

PARA.TAB: The second issue is that the inadequate labelling laws that are being maintained by the government mean that the Australian consumers are being prevented from being able to identify clearly from the label that the pork they are buying is truly ridgy-didge Australian pork product. When the issue of food labelling became politically too difficult, the government slung food labelling off for further investigation until October. I do not have to tell my colleagues on this side of the Senate, the Liberal and National parties and also the Democrats, that we have come up with a labelling protocol that would fully support the pork producers in identifying their product as an Australian product. When we came to that conclusion and we were prepared to amend the government's legislation, that legislation had fallen off the parliamentary lists. It is now languishing near the bottom among 33 bills and it will never see the light of day while this government is in power.

As I said when I was speaking to the pork producers in Parliament House today, I made a commitment on behalf of the National and Liberal parties that one of the first bills that we would get into parliament when we came back as the government would be to introduce labelling legislation that would support not only their cause but the cause of all primary industry that is suffering similar needs for decent labelling.

We have been discussing this labelling legislation for 18 months to two years since the government first introduced it. Before that, there were years of discussion, reports and recommendations. While the government grapples with its own political embarrassment, with a minister at odds with her own union, the ACTU, and all the consumer bodies that traditionally support the Labor side of politics, all Australian primary producers are forced to continue to suffer the disadvantage of imported products being sold and labelled `Made in Australia'.

The price of the government's delay can be seen today: pork producers cannot even rely on consumer goodwill and support to compete with subsidised Canadian pork labelled `Made in Australia'. The government likes to claim that it cannot help because avenues such as anti-dumping actions have failed. The government washes its hands of drought relief. A case could certainly be established on behalf of the pork producers. The government could help; it could do it today. It could put forward the legislation; the legislation is already drawn up. It is listed in government business order of the day No. 34. The government could produce that legislation today. It is already there. It could put the legislation forward and we could debate it today. We could have the labelling, that is needed and required, up and running by the end of the week. The legislation would have to go to Yarralumla for the Governor-General's signature. It is all there ready to go.

The government could introduce a labelling system that reflects the true origin of product: imported products and Australian products would be labelled in a truthful way. It could also consider bringing an action under article 19 of GATT. When we receive a protest under GATT, we act like obedient signatories and quickly initiate actions—in other words, we bend over and allow people to give us a kick in the backside. But, when it comes to standing up for our producers, the government just goes to water.

There are present examples of a 1994 Canadian government protest under GATT about our quarantine requirements for live salmon imports. Already, one year later, AQIS has responded with a draft paper recommending Canadian imports on a minimum risk basis. This same policy is to apply to other primary products such as chicken meat, egg products and pork. At the same time, our domestic labelling legislation can be delayed for many years and a GATT approach on behalf of an Australian industry, the pork industry, is falling on deaf ears.

The facts are that the Australian pork producers are in a truly desperate plight. The Australian economy has lost the benefits of the economic activity of 800 of the industry's 4,800 producers because they have been forced out of the industry this year. The industry just cannot compete against the open flow of highly subsidised imports from Canada that are able to benefit from subsidies and undercut our price by 30 per cent. The industry predicts, under the circumstances, that similar numbers will leave the industry forever in the next six months.

Over the last decade, all Australian farmers made enormous sacrifices in the belief that it would lead to fairer world trade in agricultural products. Some of the larger Australian industries may benefit from the Uruguay Round, although the cracks have appeared for wheat and dairy. The smaller Australian primary industries have really missed out.

On the eve of the commencement of the World Trade Organisation agreement on 1 July, our industries such as pork should not be facing a death sentence because of highly subsidised exports from a fellow Cairns group country. I call on the government to take serious note of the 1,000 protesters in Canberra today on behalf of the entire pork industry and to come up with some solutions immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I to rise to acknowledge the presence outside the parliament of a large number of pork producers. Many of them are small farmers struggling to survive in a very hostile environment, one in which feed prices, of course, have risen substantially because of the drought. Also, there is no doubt that the government's economic policies and other policies have not really done them much good in recent times. What interests me about this industry, apart from anything else, is that it is an industry that even the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) professes to regard as a very sound one, one with a great future. In fact, I remember him saying that he thought the future for the industry was so good that he put his super on the future—I cannot remember the exact phraseology. Anyway, he was putting his super on the future in order to get into the industry.
—And getting out of French clocks.

—As my colleague interjects, getting out of French clocks and into pigs. The thing that strikes me is that, if this is an industry that the Prime Minister thinks is a great one which has his support, and it is in crisis, I wonder what that says for the industries he does not support and is not helping. I fear that if we can have such a disastrous crisis in an industry that, in Mr Keating's judgment, is a great and expanding one, either it does not say much for his judgment, or God help all those other industries that he is not supporting and does not think are great. I fear that is what is happening to so much of Australia now, particularly small business—

PARA.TAB: An honourable senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of them, as my colleague interjects, used to be big business. The way to get a small business in Australia under this government is to start off with a big one. The significance of this is that Mr Keating did have a controversial half-ownership in a piggery group. During that half-ownership, I think that most Australians, particularly those in the pig industry, know that that company was continually in breach of the Corporations Law, as is evidenced here. I have presented non-stop Australian Securities Commission documents demonstrating that. It also lost millions of dollars, and I demonstrated that from the same source.

PARA.TAB: What is interesting though—and maybe the demonstrators outside should be aware of this—is that there is a real chance that the Prime Minister may still in fact have the prospect of having an interest in the pig industry. Perhaps the demonstrators, if they actually get to see him today, should put it to him that not only is it in Australia's interests that this industry survives and prospers, but it may well still be in his interests too.

The Prime Minister said that he had disposed of his holding in the industry. It was his half-ownership of a large piggery group, the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, which has since changed its name and its style and, I understand, its debt and its banker. But it may well be that, since he disposed of his interest, he could end up as the beneficiary of a remarkably generous option to repurchase one-third of the ownership of this piggery. It was part of the extraordinary transaction when Mr Keating's half-ownership was eventually sold through an intermediary to Indonesian interests.

I do not know whether many people have focused on this, but Mr Paul Keating's half-interest in that piggery group is now owned by an Indonesian family operating through a company registered in Singapore; the directors live in Hong Kong. Apart from that, it does not have any international associations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sweet and sour!

—As my colleague interjects, it is a sort of sweet and sour piggery. The fact is that part of this arrangement to dispose of this interest overseas, which requires Foreign Investment Review Board approval—and I do not know whether that was the reason it was done through an intermediary rather than direct, I just do not know—is that there is an incredibly generous option for an unnamed person to buy back one-third of this piggery. Who is this unnamed person, I wonder? Who can it possibly be who will be given such an incredibly generous option? This person does not have to put any money in now and, any time over the next 10 years, to get back a one-third interest in this company, all he has to do is pay for the costs involved to the people who have made this company a success—if it is going to be a success—over the next 10 years.

PARA.TAB: He does not have to risk any money himself. He just sees whether they succeed, and if they succeed he gets one-third of it. That is an incredibly generous option. Why would anyone—Indonesian interests, anyone—give such an incredibly generous option to anyone in a situation like this? That is a question to which Australians, particularly Australian pig farmers, have a right to know the answer.

Is their Prime Minister likely to join them once again—perhaps after this crisis is over and after enough competitors have gone broke—and come back into the industry? That is a serious problem. How many people are going to go broke in this industry? It is a serious problem, and it is not simply one that is concerning the minds of the people outside, who are demonstrating for their livelihoods. It a problem that could affect the supply end of the pork industry, and ultimately the consumers if this industry ends up in the hands of a very few major players.

Let us get back to this question of this option to repurchase one-third of what was the Prime Minister's piggery. It is incredible that under the terms of the sale arrangement to the Indonesians there is an option which can be exercised by someone to be nominated by Mr Keating's former partner in his piggery or, failing him, Mr Keating's solicitor—the man who is the company secretary of Mr Keating's family company. Would it not be curious if they decided that Mr Keating was the person who should exercise the option? It would be even more curious if they did not decide that Mr Keating was the man who would exercise the option! This option may ultimately be worth a lot of money.

It seems to me that with the pig industry in crisis it is up to the Prime Minister to `fess up: to tell the parliament, to tell the people, to tell the piggery operators and pork producers of Australia who are in crisis whether he is with `em or agin `em. Is he likely to be one of them? Does he have the capacity? Is there a secret agreement for him to be the person who will exercise that option—that unnamed person? Will he be the person who will exercise that option to end up with one-third of what will be a major pork producing operation in Australia, or will he not? We have raised these matters in the Senate before, but we do not get an answer. Mr Keating does not even say oink! We just do not know whether Mr Keating is someone who may well have an interest in this industry which is struggling to survive.

There are those of us who would say he does have an interest and does not care whether the industry survives or not, and others who would say that it shows he is not much of a judge of what industry to invest in. That is clearly not true. He is a good judge of what to invest in, because he invested in this industry at a cost of $430,000 for a half-share in the company. It lost squillions of dollars, was heavily indebted to the Commonwealth Bank, and breached most of the rules of the Australian Securities Commission; yet he sold out, at least doubling his money. There are many pig farmers who wish they could be in that situation. It cost him $430,000 to get in, and the Indonesians paid $850,000—$US600,000—to purchase their half-interest.

The pig farmers, who are clearly in a serious position, might like to put a few questions to the Prime Minister about whether he is for `em or agin `em. If he is for `em, would not it be terrible to be an industry he was against? And if he is agin `em, maybe now we know what has gone wrong with this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of my colleagues and the pork producers here today. To those producers who do not know me, I am a Liberal senator from Western Australia. I am in constant touch with the pork industry in Western Australia and hopefully there are a few Western Australians in here today but, if there are not—it is a long way to come—I want them to know that I take a keen interest in the industry in Western Australia. I have represented their views in this parliament on many occasions. I wish to deal with a number of aspects in support of the comments made by my colleagues, the previous speakers, Senator Baume and Senator Boswell.

PARA.TAB: We have known for many years that the countervailing and dumping legislation we have is not satisfactory. It has not carried out what it should have carried out in terms of protecting Australian industry against dumping; that is, selling below the domestic price in the country of production. It has not done that for a number of reasons. One of the most important reasons is that the dumping laws in this country are too slow and the damage is done long before the action comes into effect.

Countervailing impacts on the subsidisation of the inputs into the production of whatever it might be and we have seen the results of that. We made a commitment at the last election that we would tighten up the whole arrangement with the countervailing and dumping legislation. I intend to pursue that when we get into government. It has affected almost every spectrum of production in this country. I am primarily a wool producer and we have found that this particular legislation, and the lack of its capacity to handle particular situations, has even impacted on the wool industry.

I want to talk about the attitude of the government to producers and, of course, pork producers are an integral part of that. We are dealing with legislation today in this chamber that deals with the increases in sales tax, and with the attempted decimation of the rebate on diesel fuel. They are two areas where this government could have eased the pressure on producers, rather than increase the pressure by putting our costs up.

I put it to the people listening here today that the way that we can beat the pants off the Canadians, or anybody else for that matter, is to make sure that the cost structures in this nation of ours are at least equivalent to what they are in other countries. When we look at what we in Australia have to pay for fuel, whether it be on-road or off-road, and what those in other countries have to pay, we see that they are significantly advantaged. We could go through a whole range of cost structures. For example, the cost of the transport structure here is double what it is in Canada, or America or for most of our competitors.

An enormous percentage arises purely and simply because the government has decided, in its taxation system, to make a milking cow out of producers and industry. Until that part of the equation is addressed, we are going to find it very difficult—particularly in times of drought, as now, but also at other times—to compete against imports coming into this nation. We should not have those imposts on our industries.

Yesterday, I spoke on the cattle legislation. I made the point that, if we had had a decent cost structure in our processing and abattoir arrangements so that we were competitive with the Americans, or the Brazilians, or the Argentinians, or whoever, we would not have had developed the export of cattle to Indonesia. Why are our cattle going to feedlots in Indonesia? It is purely and simply because the processing and killing costs in this country force us to take that option. We are very shortly going to see the stupid situation where we will be importing our beef from Indonesia—that is, cattle that we have bred, fed and grown—purely and simply because this government has not got the guts to address that part of the equation.

We have also been dealing with competition policy in this place in recent times with the Hilmer report. The government has picked up a lot of the Hilmer report but there is one area that it has not touched and that is the reform of the industrial relations system and the waterfront in this nation. It does not have the courage or the guts to tackle that particular aspect of it. Until such time as it is tackled, we are going to have these imposts upon us.

One could talk about these particular aspects for hours; I do not have hours. As Senator Boswell said, we will be asking a number of questions today with regard to the pig industry. I also want to re-emphasise the points that have been made as far as labelling in this country. I would have thought that for anybody who is bringing forward legislation as a proposition, `Made in Australia' would mean made in Australia. I would have thought that is a reasonable proposition.

If we asked any of the students who are here with us today what `Made in Australia' meant, they would tell us that it was produced in Australia, it was packed in Australia, it was Australian based. It does not mean that. It makes one ask questions as to why we want to give this in-built protection to imports in this country by not stating quite clearly on the label, for example, `This is Canadian pork. It has been boiled and fried'—or whatever has been done—`in Australia.' That is what it is. We do not do that. We have got to ask ourselves questions. I certainly support the comments made by Senator Boswell about the need for us to address that particular point, which we will do when we are in government.

I wish to emphasise another point or two on taxation and imposts. Do people here today know that this year this government will collect another $14 billion of tax from taxpayers?
