Its tax take will go from $103 billion to $117 billion—the greatest single increase in any one year in this nation's history. Why are we not looking at the wastes that occur in this nation as far as our public sector expenditure is concerned? That is what we should be addressing.

On top of that, the government claims that it is balancing the budget; but it is selling the family silver to do it. One has to ask the question: what is going to happen when it runs out of assets to sell? Crunch time will come. On Friday, I think it is, we will see our current account deficit once again at somewhere round $2 1/2 billion. In fact, it is rumoured it is going to be the record current account deficit in the history of this nation. Of course, the impact of that will be absolutely devastating in terms of the flow-on impact on our costs. In due course, that current account deficit will catch up with interest rates and put enormous pressure on those.

I wind up my comments in these terms: there are a lot of actions that this government can take. In terms of cutting the cost structures in this nation, those actions would benefit everybody—in particular, primary producers in the pork industry, the beef industry, the sheep industry and the grain industry. I put it to the government that it is about time it reorganised its priorities, had a look at what it is doing to the productive sector of this country, and gave that sector equity in its treatment through the taxation system or whatever else in this country of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In a similar vein to media leaks last weekend which were obviously placed in an effort to salvage, Minister, your reputation on the French nuclear testing issue, we note further leaks this morning suggesting that Foreign Affairs officials had sought to explain to Indonesia the insensitivity of appointing as ambassador someone who refers to the Dili massacre as `quite proper'. I ask: why didn't you use your much vaunted special relationship with Foreign Minister Alatas to convey the potential damage to the relationship between our two countries by the appointment of someone whose views are apparently so out of step with Australian values? If you did so attempt, is this just another demonstration of how ineffective you have become?

—I am indebted to Senator Hill for the concession that I have been effective, at least at some stage in the past. Since the new mood of vulgar opportunism and `wet finger in the air' politics has overtaken the opposition, that perception now seems to have changed. I can understand that. This is a political environment. The opposition is engaged in the political business. It is clearly not engaged, however, in the business of acting in Australia's national interests, which is the business that I am in and which is the business that the government is in.

PARA.TAB: We were faced, as I have said on a couple of occasions recently, with a quite delicate situation so far as the appointment of the new ambassador is concerned. There is no doubt about General Mantiri's ability. There is no doubt about his capacity to do the job. There is no doubt about his knowledge of Australia. There is no doubt about his relationship with a number of key people in the Australian government, particularly in Defence industry. There is no doubt about his reputation as a reformer within the Indonesian military system. There is no doubt about his non-involvement so far as the Dili massacre is concerned.

What there is a doubt about is the particular exercise of judgment that he showed on one significant occasion in the middle of 1992, when he said a number of things that are obviously manifestly extremely regrettable. We did take the opportunity, through official channels, to express some concern about the implications of that and the degree of difficulty that would obviously confront an ambassador, having said that sort of thing. I knew perfectly well that that issue was in the minds of the Indonesian government. It was not something that needed to be further pursued in order to make that particular point.

When the Indonesian government, clearly as a matter of President Suharto's personal decision, chose to proceed with the appointment of someone who is fitted in all the ways that I have described for the office, I do not believe in practice, taking into account Australia's best interests, that there was any rational basis or sensible basis on which we could have refused agrement. Under the circumstances I have made publicly clear, as I have made privately clear to the Indonesians, that it would be extremely helpful if a very early opportunity were taken by the new ambassador to find some way of expressing regret for what were obviously very unfortunate remarks.

If the issue can be approached in this way, with a little bit of good sense and a little bit of spirit of concern for the national interest and Australia's regional relationships, rather than vulgar, opportunistic point scoring, we might actually be able to make some progress on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister is demonstrating again how out of touch he has become with Australian attitudes and values. There seems to be considerable parallel with the French exercise in that the time at which influence might be brought to bear was before the formal request was made. My question related to that. In the period of dialogue leading up to that formal request, did you in fact confer with Foreign Minister Alatas? Did you express the view that the Australian-Indonesian relationship is particularly important and the appointment of somebody whose values are obviously so out of touch with Australian values would cause problems? If you did express that view, are you saying to us that you had so little influence that there was no other outcome that was possible than the one that has occurred?

—I am not going to create a precedent on this, or any other, occasion by referring to the detailed conversations I may or may not have had on sensitive and difficult issues of this kind. All I am saying is that the views of the Australian government as to the potential degree of difficulty that might be involved in this appointment, for the very specific reason—and only that reason—that I have described, were made clear to the Indonesian government through appropriate channels. Beyond that, I have no further comment.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from Finland led by the Speaker of the Parliament of Finland, Mrs Riitta Uosukainen. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you all to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both enjoyable and of benefit to you. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Mrs Uosukainen to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TAB.EMPHASIS: Mrs Uosukainen was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the proposed restructure and modernisation of the Australian Commonwealth Games Association, whereby its principal administrative role would be managed by a professional, full-time chief executive, rather than by an honorary secretary-treasurer, and its likely demise at the hands of sports which wish to maintain the status quo. Would the government consider withdrawing Commonwealth Games preparation funds to those sports which do not support these reforms?
—I thank Senator Denman for her question and—
—Which you wrote.

—I did not, as a matter of fact. I acknowledge the interest that Senator Denman has shown in this matter. Senator, the short answer to the question you ask is, no. In my view it would be inappropriate and undesirable as a matter of principle for the Commonwealth government to be making sport funding dependent on whether an organisation voted in a certain way in a forum like the Council of the Commonwealth Games Association.

PARA.TAB: The government cannot withdraw Commonwealth Games preparation funds from sports, because sports are not funded in that way. The government does not provide funds specifically for preparing athletes to the Commonwealth Games, nor does it financially support the Australian Commonwealth Games Association itself. Through the Australian Sports Commission, the government provides funds to sports on an annual basis for international competition. With the implementation of the olympic athlete program, the level of support for olympic sports was increased in 1994-95 but the focus is on preparation for the 1996 Atlanta and 2000 Sydney Olympic Games, not so much on the 1998 Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lumpur.

With the exception of a handful of sports—bowls, cricket, hockey, netball, rugby and squash, some of which may not be on the program at Kuala Lumpur—all Commonwealth Games sports are olympic sports. Any benefit that aspiring Commonwealth Games team members receive from federal government support, therefore, is incidental to the main thrust of the olympic athlete program, which is the two Olympic Games that I mentioned. The Australian Commonwealth Games Association has its own rules; and matters such as the proposed organisational restructuring are subject to those rules.

I believe it is time for the Commonwealth Games Association to bring itself up to date in its organisational administration, as other sporting organisations in this country have done. However, it will be up to the Council of the ACGA to determine its own destiny. This is the point that I made directly to officials of the Commonwealth Games Association, including Arthur Tunstall, and the President of the Association, Ray Godkin, when I met with them recently. I reiterated strongly the views that I have expressed in recent months about the need for their organisation to become up to date and to more accurately reflect the nature of Australian society. This very strong message applies equally to such issues as racism in sport and the professional administration of the organisation.

Whatever the outcome, the government will continue to support Australian athletes at unprecedented levels through the programs of the Australian Sports Commission. Any organisational change that improves the professionalism and the public image of the ACGA would be welcomed by the government and by me as the sports minister. As always, I can say to Senator Denman that the government is committed to assisting sporting organisations in these endeavours.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It relates to your receipt of the Grawemeyer award of over $200,000 for contributions to improving world order. You received this award not only for your book Cooperating for Peace, more commonly known as the blue book, but also for an article written by you entitled `Cooperative security and intrastate conflict', which appeared in the journal Foreign Policy, No. 96, in 1994. The blue book acknowledges the assistance and contributions of many other people, but the foreign policy article goes under your name alone without acknowledgment to others. Why is that so? Was Andrew Mack in fact the author of the article? If not, what contribution did he make? Since you make so much of your own intellectual ability and integrity, why was Andrew Mack's contribution not recognised?

—I do not know whether Senator Vanstone has ever written anything in her life and knows what is involved in the question of authorship and what kind of responsibility is assumed by anyone who puts their name to an article—responsibility as to content, responsibility as to style and responsibility as to substance. I wrote the article which appears in my name in Foreign Policy.
—Ah, it was you.
—I did ask Andrew Mack to do some preliminary research for me and to give me some ideas about one particular part of the project.
—Like the first draft.

—I am very happy to table the original draft given to me by Andrew Mack, if I can find it, together with the final article as produced by me and with all the manuscript in between. I do not think Andrew Mack would be in any doubt whatsoever as to who wrote the article and who deserves the attribution for it. It was Andrew Mack who suggested that I submit the article in the form in which it was published to the Grawemeyer award publication. It was Andrew Mack to whom I have given enormous acknowledgment in many other contexts as a very helpful contributor to the process.
—But not in this one?
—I discussed with him, if you want to know, the question of whether he wanted an attribution as a research assistant and a source of contribution to the ideas.
—He said no because all he wanted was a proper acknowledgment.
—This is getting to ridiculous lengths, Mr President.
—Order! Senator Vanstone and Senator Alston!

—I know it is a time honoured habit in many parts of the world for ministers to produce articles not one word of which they have written or even produce books not one word of which they have written or books of speeches not one word of which they have written. Anyone who knows me would know that I take complete responsibility for whatever I produce. I acknowledge frankly and fulsomely the contributions that are made, as I do at extreme length in the foreign policy book and in the blue book. The ideas in those books are ones that I accept responsibility for as I accept responsibility for the articulation of them. If you are too miserable and mean spirited to acknowledge that, then I have no further answer for you.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, there was no misunderstanding about the attribution of contributions made by other people, in particular those employed by the taxpayer in your own department in this book. The question was why you did not follow the same example in this article. You have just acknowledged that someone did a draft for you. Why did your own intellectual integrity not demand that you give them some acknowledgment? That sort of plagiarism would fail someone in first year law. Will you tell us how many copies of this book, so well contributed to by your department, were bought by your department? How many copies of it have been distributed around to uplift your international reputation, to enhance your chance of getting the UN job that you so desperately want?

—I will take on notice the question about the number of books and all the rest of it. That information has been given to estimates committees in the past. Until now, it has been regarded as a matter of pride for Australia that there would be in international circulation a book that has manifestly been extremely influential in determining the shape of the whole debate about the peace and security agenda of the United Nations in the post Cold War world. Until now, that has been something about which Australians could feel a small amount of pride—as, indeed, I did, for being able to make such a contribution and being able to make it with the assistance of the people who are frankly acknowledged.

PARA.TAB: So far as the Grawemeyer award is concerned and that particular article, I take responsibility for having written about 85 per cent of the final content of that. I readily acknowledge there was about a 15 per cent contribution from Andrew Mack. The footnotes are not normally published in that particular journal. In the context of a journal whose house style is not to publish footnotes, attributions and so on, in the conversation that I had with Andrew Mack, as I recall it, it was agreed that appropriate acknowledgment would be given at another appropriate opportunity, which I am happy now to do. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer him to the arrest of General Obasanjo, the former Nigerian President and member of the Commonwealth Eminent Persons Group on South Africa. I ask: what, if anything, is the government doing on his behalf, particularly given some disturbing but unconfirmed reports that the general might face the death penalty shortly?

—The Australian government is very disturbed by some quite recent unconfirmed reports that General Obasanjo has been arraigned before a closed special military tribunal to answer charges of complicity in an alleged plot to overthrow the Nigerian government. We have been closely monitoring that situation in Nigeria—one, incidentally, in which Mr Malcolm Fraser has taken a close interest, and I have had conversations with him about it. We are seeking confirmation and clarification of these reports.

PARA.TAB: In March this year, following initial reports of his arrest, we called in the Nigerian High Commissioner twice to express concern about that arrest, to seek further information on the circumstances of his detention and subsequent house arrest. The initial press reports of that arrest in March referred to it as being linked by the Nigerian authorities to a planned coup against the government. Many serving army officers were arrested at the same time; 23 are currently before a closed special military tribunal investigating the alleged coup.

On 13 June, General Obasanjo was transferred by security agents from house arrest to an unknown detention centre. In the last week the non-government press in Nigeria reported that General Obasanjo and his former deputy, General Yar'Adua, have appeared before the special military tribunal to answer charges of complicity in that alleged plot. The Australian government has joined other Western governments to make a demarche to the Nigerian government on the situation of all the political detainees, including General Obasanjo. Thus far, it has proved to be difficult for the diplomatic community to make effective representations on this issue.

I put out a press statement this morning. Yesterday, I instructed DFAT, my department, to again call in the High Commissioner for Nigeria to seek an explanation of the basis for his continuing detention and to seek information on what charges, if any, have been laid against him. The High Commissioner has given a commitment to us to respond as soon as possible following communications with his government.

I say again that we are deeply concerned about General Obasanjo's position. I urge the Nigerian government to explain the basis of his continuing detention and to ensure that if any charges have been laid against him they will be considered in accordance with due process of law in public and with the right to legal representation of his choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the minister accept the unequivocal evidence presented by the Australian Democrats as long ago as 1988 which showed that label swapping occurred on canisters of uranium and uranium compounds, making it impossible to be sure that Australian uranium did not finish up in French bombs? Has the minister seen the article in this week's New Scientist which says that the French nuclear tests are not related to ensuring the workability of existing weapons or for `bench tests', a euphemism clearly loved by the minister, but are related instead to the development of a `range of more robust warheads for submarine launched ballistic missiles'? Do either, or both, of these facts change his mind in relation to a ban on the export of Australian uranium to France?

—The story about the uranium sales to France has been told often enough in the past for me not to need to repeat it here. Australian uranium constitutes only about three per cent, as I understand it, of the energy industry's fuel source supplies. The uranium is subject to very intense and close safeguards pursuant to the agreement that we have with France. There is every reason to be confident that no Australian uranium has anything whatsoever to do with the military establishment.

PARA.TAB: There are technical arguments about flag swaps and which molecule finishes up where in the scheme of things, which we have had on innumerable occasions before. I will see whether there is any further information I can give you. I cannot recall your great `canister' disclosure, I am afraid, of 1988—my memory has gone blank on that. But I will endeavour to refresh myself and see what more can be said on that particular subject.

The second part of your question was about the article which appears in the press today from one source in France suggesting that these tests will, in fact, be directed towards the development of new generation missile technology rather than for the purposes of computer simulation development and associated stockpile reliability and safety ensuring measures. All I can say on that particular subject is that there was some ambiguity on this question left by the original statement by President Chirac in which it was said that the tests were for certain purposes (a) and (b), computer development and stockpile stewardship, but it was not expressly denied that they might be for some other purpose. I drew attention to that ambiguity in my discussions across the table with the French foreign minister in Paris last week and asked him for an unequivocal assurance that these tests would not be for the purpose of new generation technology development. He gave me that unequivocal assurance.

All I can say is that it has not been my experience in the conduct of international relations for the past seven years now that ministers tell lies when they respond in that very direct way. There are innumerable ways of avoiding questions if you do not want to be pinned down by a direct and unequivocal question of that particular kind. This was not an occasion in which any such approach was offered in the answer I was given. It was a clear and straightforward answer, `No, that's not the purpose.' That is as much as I can say by way of the assurance that I had been given. Other objective evidence—the fact that there are eight tests rather than many more than that—would suggest that the tests are for the purpose which is being now unequivocally stated by the French government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I just comment that whether it is one per cent, three per cent or 30 per cent, the principle is still there and we are talking about many thousands of kilograms of uranium. But several sources are quoted in the New Scientist article and one talks about the different types of tests. Another source, which is the verification technology information centre in London, said the tests are quite unnecessary, that if indeed the tests are related to computer modelling then information is available from elsewhere. Does this new information now change the minister's mind in relation to exports of Australian uranium to France?

—I am sorry to disappoint Senator Coulter but that is not new information. It is well known that the United States has very advanced computer simulation technology. It is also well known that the US has offered that technology to France to the extent that it has not got it itself. I put that particular proposition to the French minister, as you would expect me no doubt to do, and the response was dismissive—that France did not believe that it would get appropriate or useful technology from the United States and preferred to develop its own. So, again, all I can say is that that proposition is not a new one; it is one that has been around in discussion. It is one that, again, as were all these matters, was put very directly, explicitly, unequivocally and unambiguously, as was our general protest, to the French government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the 1,000 pork producers in Canberra today—many of them in the gallery—protesting about the desperate plight of their industry which lost 20 per cent of its farmers in the last six months, and I ask: when an industry is being assaulted on all fronts from high grain prices which form 70 per cent of their costs but is ineligible for drought relief; when a four-fold increase in Canadian imports is securing forward Australian contracts at 30 per cent below Australian prices and because of advantages from massive Canadian government subsidies; and the government's inadequate labelling laws do not allow Australian buyers to identify Australian pork products, will the government give the industry an assurance it will look at its clearly enunciated problems—including action under article 19 of GATT? When will the government introduce its origin labelling laws so Australians can recognise and buy the truly Australian product rather than pass it off for further delays and comment?

—I thank Senator Boswell for his question. Indeed I am well aware that a large number of pig producers are here in Canberra at the moment. Over the last 12 months I have had a number of meetings with the peak organisations which represent them, and I do recognise the problems that the industry is currently facing. I might add that some of the problems the industry is facing, in common with other intensive livestock industries at the moment, are in terms of the input prices of the feed grain which constitute, and Senator Boswell is correct, such a high percentage of the input costs of pig producers, around 70 per cent of their total costs.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the matters that Senator Boswell has raised about action that could potentially be taken under GATT and claims that are being made about the differential in prices between Canadian pork in Australia and Australian pork and so on, there is a course of action which I intend to propose to a delegation from the pig producers that I am going to meet shortly after question time this afternoon. I am happy to now canvass that for the Senate. I am sure that the delegation will not mind the discourtesy of canvassing that matter now, in advance of the meeting this afternoon, since you have asked the question, Senator Boswell.

The industry is experiencing a severe cost price squeeze which is primarily due to high feed prices resulting from the drought. Both large and small producers are suffering large losses as feed accounts, as Senator Boswell said, for around 70 per cent of the total input costs of pig producers. The price of feed barley, to give an indication of the problem, has roughly doubled over the last year while saleyard prices for the end product have remained fairly constant.

The situation with grain prices at the moment is that the prices are now beginning to show signs of improvement as the new season crop becomes available. In fact, I had a discussion this morning with the representatives of the grain industry about this. Imported grains and livestock feed are also entering the market. I might add that the government's simple announcement some time ago that it was going to allow imports of grain within a fortnight knocked the top off what was then a rapidly increasing price for feed grain.

While the current costs for feeds are high, the outlook is now improving. My latest advice from ABARE is that feed prices for 1995-96 on the current crop projections will be back to or in fact below the 1993-94 pre-drought prices. These difficult circumstances for the producers have intensified the adjustment pressures on the industry, and the existing assistance through the rural industry adjustment scheme is currently providing help for the industry. My last advice was that about 110 specialist pig producers are currently receiving such support. Latest forecasts by ABARE are that pig industry profitability will improve in 1995-96 due to an improvement of five per cent in saleyard prices.

In respect of the Canadian imports, my advice is that imports from Canada for 1994-95 will be about 4,000 tonnes of product. That is compared to the total domestic production of the industry of around 335,000 tonnes. That is, Canadian imports will comprise around 2.41 per cent of the total market. This is about the same level of imports as we experienced in 1991-92 when we also, I might add, had high grain prices.

Canadian imports are in the form of boned-out, frozen product which, under protocol, has to be cooked on arrival and is then processed into products such as pressed ham. The industry has maintained in representations to me that although the imports represent less than five per cent of total production, which is the figure the industry has used, they do have a price overhang effect—

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister's time has expired.
—And I anticipate confidently a supplementary question, Mr President.
—I thank the minister for his comprehensive answer. He announced a few minutes ago that he would give the farmers some indication of what the government would do. He skated around that issue.
—No, I have just not got to it yet.
—I give him another two minutes to do so, by asking a supplementary question.

—There is conflicting information about the total amount of Canadian imports, on the advice that the industry, ABARE and so on are providing me with. I approached the relevant minister, Mr Gear, today to discuss the possibility of the Industry Commission undertaking an industry development reference—in the first instance, this is a major reference—to examine constraints on the efficiency and competitiveness of the industry. However, I have been advised by the Industry Commission that it could quite quickly—within about four to five weeks—examine the incidence and effects of subsidies on pig meat sold in Australia and the likelihood that such subsidies are causing material injury.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the last part of your question, Senator Boswell, another course of action available to the industry is that, if the industry believes there is evidence of dumping by the Canadian industry, it could take action to the Anti-Dumping Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have; they got done.

—That was in 1991-92, Senator Boswell. Fair crack of the whip! I will put those two courses of action to the industry this afternoon and will get an indication from the industry as to what course it would like us to adopt.(Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the South African parliament led by Mr Samuel Louw. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and hope that your visit will be both productive and rewarding.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. What progress has been made in negotiations with the petroleum industry regarding the Industry Commission's report on that industry and the Gardini report on franchising?

—A report of the Australian Industry Commission recommended at the end of last year that the present legislative arrangements for the petroleum industry that had been existence since about 1980—that is, the sites act, the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act—should be repealed and that a voluntary operation take place on monitoring the development and management of the industry. The government indicated at that time that we would not favour repealing that legislation unless there was agreement—
—You are driving the people out of the public gallery.
—Wind it up. They are on their way out, Schachty.

—All of you who get petrol from petrol stations around Australia will find that, if you talk about this with your petrol retailers, they are very interested in this issue. We indicated that we would not repeal the legislation unless both sides agreed to a new voluntary code. Initially, at the end of last year, both sides—the petroleum companies and the retailers—even refused to talk to each other about the concerns raised in that report.

PARA.TAB: After several meetings I had with them, we finally got them to agree, without prejudice to each other, to have a number of meetings. As a result, last week they indicated to me that they had reached an agreement in principle. They will come back to me by 27 July with a detailed agreement—both sides signing a voluntary arrangement for the operation of the petroleum industry and its retail network. Once that is reached and agreed to, the government will consider it and, I would imagine, recommend the repeal of those two acts.

One reason the petrol retailers are willing to go to a voluntary code is that they expect the government to strengthen the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act. They believe that, if there were an attempt by the petroleum companies to use their market power to their disadvantage, they would have redress under strengthened unconscionable conduct provisions. Therefore, I am able to tell the Senate that that is part of the discussions I am having with the small business sector about strengthening that provision of the Trade Practices Act.

This also relates to the recommendations by Mr Gardini on franchising generally. Again, the recommendations he has made and the discussions I have had with him indicate that we could have a voluntary code for franchising operations if there is strengthening of the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act so that small business franchisees feel that they have a better chance of defending their economic position vis-a-vis big business and franchisors.

Overall, this has been a very successful outcome. This is an industry in which there has been a lot of turmoil, argument and distrust from both sides. They have now come to the table to reach this agreement. It is a success for the arrangements on both sides to get so far down the track. I hope in mid-July to be able to announce the written details of the agreement and then proceed with a cabinet submission. I certainly want to place on the record my congratulations and thanks to the representatives of the Motor Traders Association of Australia, the Australian Institute of Petroleum and the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association, which are the three industry groups that took part in these successful negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I note his comments in answer to the question from Senator Boswell with regard to Canadian pig meat having to be frozen. I wonder whether he is aware that AQIS has released plans to remove the need to freeze pig meat before leaving Canada. This particularly relates to a worm called Trichinella spirallis, which kills people. It is carried in pig meat and it kills about eight people a year in Canada. The Canadians have been arguing that Trichinella spirallis is killed in the cooking process and does not need to be frozen. However, the Australian pig industry is concerned about the meat not being frozen. In view of the enormous risk to public health in Australia, what is he doing to ensure that AQIS protocols are maintained to ensure that Australian public health is not compromised?
—Mr President—
—What about the worm called Macdonald?
—It is the worm called Ian Macdonald. Let's get it right.
—Order!

—As I am aware, the current AQIS protocols require that the product be not only frozen but also cooked once it reaches Australia before it is then sold for human consumption. So the product is not simply frozen. Senator Crane is right; the cooking process does destroy this parasite, as freezing does. But the product does not have to be just frozen. The product is frozen and, once it arrives in Australia, it then has to be cooked before it is sold for human consumption.

PARA.TAB: My advice is that, after cooking, the majority of Canadian meat is used for things such as sandwich ham and processed foods like that. If any other development changes those protocols—I understand that that is the existing situation—I will advise the Senate of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Families, especially women in this country, have different lifestyles, sometimes by choice and sometimes not. What are government policies doing for families in this country to support women and families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to say that women in Australia have more choice than ever before, particularly under the policies of this government. We recognise that women in their adult lives will spend some time at home, particularly when children are little, and some time in the paid work force. Our policies, particularly our child-care policies but also our family payment policies, recognise this and support those choices.

PARA.TAB: Women who stay at home with their children are able to receive the home child-care allowance of $30 per week. That will be incorporated into the parenting allowance from 1 July. The home child-care allowance will remain tax free, and it will remain means tested on the primary carer's income only, which is usually the mother's. That is as it ever was when it was previously the dependent spouse rebate.
Despite the opposition's lack of policies, we do know that its leader, Mr Howard, supports this policy. He said on 7 March 1994 about the home child-care allowance:

ANSWER.PARA: There is a lot to be said for the new structure. It puts money directly into the hands of the parents at home. This assistance is completely targeted and it follows the pattern of family allowance.

So we know that Mr Howard supports the home child-care allowance. But his spokesman on the family, Dr Kemp, does not agree with him. He calls the $850 million spent on the home child-care allowance a mere drop in the bucket. It is very interesting for a party that wants to slash spending to describe $850 million as a mere drop in the bucket. I ask those opposite whether they believe this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West's question related to government policy. Senator Crowley says we have no policies but she has just spent the last 2 1/2 minutes discussing the family policy of the opposition. The opposition has made it quite clear that it wants to improve affairs for families, especially women. Could you direct the minister to answer the questions about the government's failure in relation to family policy and women's policy and not keep canvassing our policies since that is none of her business.
—Order! I certainly do not think she was doing that for as long as you said she was. I do ask you to get to the point of the answer, Minister.

—I have been doing that, Mr President. I take your advice, but I find it fascinating that the minute you mention in this place that the opposition is lacking a policy in something, up they spring over there, sensitive and touchy as anything.
—You are standing up referring to our policies. You cannot have it both ways.

—It is one of those things that you might say the government has considered and rejected. For example, Mr Howard is also interested in proposing income splitting. The government is not prepared to accept that as a way of assisting families, but some people—called `Mr Howard'—do believe that this is a very good idea. In fact, `they' said so but the other day in the Australian, 27 June:

ANSWER.PARA: The goal is providing greater choice for families and income splitting is one of many means of achieving this end.

That was in an article that describes income splitting as regressive, sexist, inefficient, anti-saving, and not even helping families with children. That is what income splitting is about and that is one of the policies the government does not accept, will not accept and is not promoting. But the opposition certainly does, and it does not exclude it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the question had absolutely nothing to do with opposition policies that the government might wish to canvass. The government, at the last election, said, `We are not going to have a broad based consumption tax and put a new tax on building materials.' Now it has gone and done that. The question is about government policy and the minister is flouting your ruling. I ask you to bring her into line.
—Senator, I asked you before to get to the point of the answer.

—Certainly, Mr President; I will go back and remind people that I have already raised one very important part of our policy that the opposition does not want to know about, and that is the home child-care allowance which, as I have quoted, has the support the Leader of the Opposition. The next very important part is our child-care policy which assists—
—Once it's his own policy, he'll support it.

—That is exactly right. This is a very important point: the opposition's me-too-ism in catching up on our policies. In the child-care area we have a policy to assist women to participate in the work force, to study and to train. We recognise that is what women want to do, we recognise that is what women are doing, and we know how well they value the government's child-care policies to assist them to do that. We have also recognised the importance of occasional care, which we also provide for women if they choose to do other than work, study or train.

PARA.TAB: Our policies are quite clear. We recognise the needs of women and the opportunities they are exercising to study, to train, to work, to be at home, or to be in voluntary work. Our child-care policies assist them to do that. The opposition has absolutely none. We have them. People know it. Me-too-ism by John Howard is not going to persuade people that those child-care policies are a good thing for women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Minister, is it a fact that your government has failed miserably to deliver on its promises of the introduction of an `invisible' visa system in key tourist source countries and has now resorted to selling equipment to major tour wholesalers and travel agents in those countries? Do firms which participate in this arrangement charge their clients a fee for service? Is it a fact that in Japan authorised travel agents charge Japanese visitors to Australia 5,000 yen or just over $80 for a visa? How can the government justify this additional impost on overseas travellers which acts as a disincentive in our premier growth sector, the tourism industry?

—Mr President, Senator Parer raises a question which is of concern not just to the government but to all sides of the parliament—the question of Australia's universal visa system, how it is applied and how we can make the system better or change it to accommodate our national interests. Those national interests include not only encouraging tourism but also other aspects of this particular issue such as security interests and health interests when people apply to come into this country.

PARA.TAB: We have some very rigorous settings for security, character, and health checks. These are all linked to the way that we have a universal visa system. In consideration of the importance of all these issues, I asked the Joint Committee on Migration, chaired by Senator McKiernan, to address this matter. The committee is undergoing that inquiry at the present time. Senator Short has been making a contribution on the committee to this particular issue.

We have a universal system in place and that system is being addressed in terms of its range and operation. We are talking about an ever increasing number of visitors to Australia. We have had a massive increase in the last few years. Somewhere between 2.5 million and three million tourists visit Australia each year, whereas a few years ago the figure was about one million. By the year 2000 we can expect some eight million—if not 10 million—tourists entering Australia. The figures are still being worked out by tourism advisory boards.

We have to address the issue. One way in which we are addressing it is by looking at whether we can use other mechanisms and new technology to make it easier for people to obtain visas. We want to generally make the process easier. To that extent we are looking at a number of alternatives. One alternative is to look at the paper-free visa. In recent months we have launched pilot projects in places like Korea to see whether we can make an agency arrangement with travel agents whereby when people buy tickets the selected agents will have access to immigration operatives in a particular country and a visa can be issued without paper. As I said, it is a pilot project and it is being pursued in a number of selected countries from which our high volume tourism is coming. These are also countries that have a low volume of tourism overstay rates. Perhaps that is the pilot project that Senator Parer is talking about.

If Senator Parer has any queries as to how much agents are charging for these visas, I will take the question on board and pursue the matter to ensure that people are not being ripped off. We recognise the importance of tourism. We have mechanisms in place to review this area. Those mechanisms take into account not just the need to ensure that people can get into Australia quickly, but also the need to ensure that our national interests through health and security checking are maintained through our visa system.

If you want to do away with universal visa systems, say so and put it on the record. That is not the position coming from Senator Parer's side of parliament. In the meantime we have to look at methods such as paper-free visas and post-embarkation clearances of plane loads of people to see whether we can do it faster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That was an interesting travelogue from the minister. I will ask him the question that I asked the first time. Is the government now selling equipment to major tour wholesalers and travel agents in places like Korea and Japan? Is it a fact that those agents are charging Japanese visitors to this country 5,000 yen—which is just over $80—for those visas to Australia to be issued?

—I thought I answered that question when I said that I would take that particular part of the question on notice. One reason why we have a migration agent registration scheme in this country is that, in an area like this, there is great potential for rip-offs. We can control what happens within government, but quite often we cannot control what happens outside of government—particularly when it is in another country. Senator Parer should realise that. If Senator Parer has particular instances of this occurring he should let us know. When the agency arrangements are finally concluded they will take into account any evidence coming from Senator Parer. The agency arrangements are important. If agents and companies are able to access government equipment and facilities I hope we would be charging them. That would not necessitate a flow-on fee of $80. If Senator Parer has some hard evidence he should give it to us because it will impact on the final outcome of the discussions and arrangements with agents.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the pro-euthanasia statements of the Governor-General, in which he advocated the legalisation of such intentional killing of one innocent citizen by another person. Is it not a fact that section 9 of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act confers on the Governor-General power to disallow a Northern Territory law within six months? In those circumstances, especially since the Northern Territory euthanasia legislation was passed only a month ago, why do you consider that the Governor-General's pro-euthanasia intervention in the public debate was proper?

—Senator Harradine's understanding of constitutional law is sophisticated enough for him to know perfectly well that no Governor-General would ever exercise any power of disallowance, other than on the advice of his ministers. There may be a contest about the scope of some of the reserve powers exercised by the Governor-General in relation to appointments, dismissals and all the rest of it that we are familiar with, but Senator Harradine knows perfectly well there is no doubt whatsoever about the force of that convention governing approval of legislation and equivalent capacity to disallow. They are powers that can be exercised only on the advice of the ministers of the government of the day.

PARA.TAB: Whatever the controversial character of the Governor-General's views on euthanasia may be, as expressed in that recent speech, Senator Harradine is drawing an extremely long bow—one that he himself knows is perfectly untenable—in suggesting that there is anything about the nature of the Governor-General's office that should have inhibited him from expressing such a view.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question flowing from that answer. Minister, are you suggesting that maybe the government has prejudged a petition that may emanate from the Northern Territory—for example, from Aboriginal groups in the Northern Territory—that such a law be disallowed? Under those circumstances, are you suggesting that it is proper for a governor-general or, indeed, a president to involve him office in that particular debate or to involve himself in a matter which is likely to come before him pursuant to a law of this parliament?

—No matter how many petitions a governor-general might receive asking him to exercise some formal power that he might be perceived to have under the constitution or any other equivalent enabling legislation, the Governor-General knows perfectly well—as everyone else in the country, including Senator Harradine, knows perfectly well—that there is no independent right of discretion in these particular matters, that both powers have to be exercised on the—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister is not responding to the question that I asked. I asked quite directly: has the government prejudged that particular petition, should it so come forth? I did not say the Governor-General; I said the government. I ask that the minister address the question.

—I have said many times—and I am sure you are quite aware, Senator Harradine—that I have no power to direct the minister as to how he will answer the question, except in terms of general relevance. He is generally relevant.

—I was not seeking in any way to avoid the question. No, of course, it is not the case that the government, as the government, has prejudged the petition. To the extent that anyone is going to be in a position of advising the Governor-General as to how he exercise that power, that is perfectly apt. But we are talking about the Northern Territory here, so it is not the Commonwealth government which has relevant responsibilities in this matter. It is, of course, the government of the Northern Territory, and that is the way it shall remain, as far as we are concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the response the minister and the Inspector-General of Defence's representative gave to my questions at a Senate estimates hearing about a defence contract relating to Indonesia, which I first raised with the minister last August. While welcoming the minister's intervention in this serious matter, I ask whether there has been any attempt within his department to cover up this issue and whether any of what the Inspector-General describes as `three potentially criminal matters' he has referred to the Australian Federal Police involve any senior employees of the Department of Defence. Does the reference relate to any consultant to the department? What internal disciplinary action has been taken so far in respect of these matters, or is it being deferred while awaiting the outcome of the Inspector-General's and the AFP's inquiries? In the meantime, how many senior officers have been transferred out of the section of the department involved in this matter?

—Senator Baume asks whether there has been a cover-up in the department. That is a very broad question. That can go from a conspiracy not to divulge information through to incompetence. I will not be able to make a conclusive view on any of that part of the question until the Inspector-General reports. The Inspector-General took up this matter after Senator Baume raised it in questions on notice and later at an estimates committee. The inquiry, as Senator Baume would know, was a little slow to start because we were awaiting information from himself and others, but it did get a fair head of steam up.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry did find, in regard to the principal person who was hired as a consultant, that there were some anomalies. It required the Federal Police to look at those. They are properly described as criminal matters. These are not hanging offences, by the way, but nevertheless they required its intervention and that investigation is under way. I really do not want to comment on the details of that until the AFP's report is in.

In terms of any internal discipline, such discipline may occur if the Inspector-General finds that there have been breaches of the code of conduct of the Public Service, irrespective of anything to do with the Federal Police.

Finally, on the question of movement of officials, this is a very hard question to answer because people move all the time. People get promoted and people get transferred, all for good reason. I can say that it has been agreed that one officer of this section has been removed to try his expertise in another field.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Minister, in your speech on land cover disturbance and vegetation clearance, you indicated that the largest area being cleared is in Queensland and that leasehold approvals were given to clear over one million hectares in one year. Recently we have seen clearing of rainforest in the Daintree, extensive clearing of mahogany glider habitat and clearing, leading to koala road kills, in the Burdekin. I ask the minister: what measures has the federal government taken in response to the loss of such significant habitats in the last month? Has he received a request for funding from the Queensland government and will he match the Queensland government money to purchase these habitat areas?

—The mahogany glider, as Senator Woodley would know, is listed as an endangered species under the Commonwealth's Endangered Species Protection Act. Its range is narrowly restricted to predominantly coastal eucalypt forest in North Queensland from near Ingham to Tully. Through the endangered species program of ANCA within my portfolio, significant research and habitat identification have been and are continuing to be funded for this species.

PARA.TAB: The clearing of mahogany glider habitat is a serious issue and it is one that needs to be addressed. But the clearing of native vegetation in North Queensland, including mahogany glider habitat, is not occurring solely as a result of the sugar industry infrastructure package, as has been mentioned by some. There are a range of factors involved, including the fact that there is currently a high price for sugar—that has created favourable economic conditions—and the fact that land is rated on agricultural suitability, irrespective of whether it retains native vegetation or not. Of course, that means that land holders can be financially disadvantaged if they retain native vegetation. There are also significant other developments, such as residential subdivision, which are having an impact on native vegetation. There are a number of other issues, as I am sure Senator Woodley understands, where the Commonwealth has little jurisdiction—in fact, very little control at all.

I am closely liaising with the Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage, Molly Robson, to explore a range of mechanisms to protect native vegetation in North Queensland. The minister has raised the issue of Commonwealth financial support with me and has asked for the establishment of a working group of Commonwealth and state officials. I have responded to the Queensland minister agreeing to the establishment of the working group. That will, of course, identify priorities and develop an appropriate response, particularly to the protection of mahogany glider habitat. The working group is also planned to assess the likely budgetary implications, the timing and mechanisms of any proposed action. I have also written to my colleague Senator Bob Collins on these matters seeking a nominee from his department to participate in this working group.

I am particularly interested to explore those mechanisms in addition to land purchase which have been identified in the environmental impact assessment process which has been conducted as part of the sugar industry infrastructure package. These include cooperative measures, in conjunction with local government and land-holders, to encourage and formally agree on the retention of native vegetation. I certainly welcome the fact that the Queensland government has acted to protect important habitat in the short term. I understand that it has placed some 16 interim conservation orders over critical habitat in the Ingham and Herbert River area. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. However, Minister, since you have raised the issue of the sugar industry infrastructure package, can I ask you whether or not you believe it is ecologically sustainable to contribute to the extinction of another Australian mammal and whether or not you believe mass clearing of lowland rainforest and melaleuca habitat right up to the waterways is really being sustainable in that sense? Could you also confirm for me, because I was not quite sure what you were saying, whether or not you are going to contribute funds to the purchasing of habitat?

—Very quickly, the sugar industry infrastructure package consists of 12 infrastructure projects, seven of which have been designated under the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Approval for those projects is conditional on satisfactory Commonwealth-Queensland environmental impact assessments being implemented for each of these projects. A number of initiatives have already been identified in environmental impact assessments commenced for these projects to assist in the protection of important mahogany glider habitat.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the second part of your supplementary question, Senator, the suggestion that has been made that the Commonwealth has not provided any money to protect critical habitat is wrong. The Commonwealth has funded and will continue to fund the acquisition of habitat through our national reserves cooperative program. Just last week, for example, I announced $1.125 million towards the acquisition of property at Silver Plains in North Queensland. It is, in fact, home to over 100 rare and endangered plants and animals. It is an announcement that has been well received right across the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—During question time, Senator Vanstone mounted a personal attack on me on the basis that I had plagiarised, in effect, a draft written for me by Professor Mack of the ANU for an article entitled `Intrastate Conflict and Cooperative Security', for which I was awarded this $200,000 United States prize. Might I say by way of parenthesis that the actual book that was submitted for the prize was the blue book, Cooperating for Peace, itself. The article simply was a supplementary piece of material. The jury actually decided that the article, because it was in an American journal, I suspect, was the one that it wanted to particularly base the prize on. But that is neither here nor there.

PARA.TAB: The story of the production of the article was this. Andrew Mack was one of those people from the ANU who was collaborating with me on the preparation of the original book Cooperating for Peace. He developed a strong view that the themes running through—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your department directly funded it.

—Let me finish, Senator Hill. He took the view that the themes in that particular book deserved wider currency and publication and that I ought to write something for publication in an absolutely mainstream American journal, because there was a much better chance of getting the ideas out and about than would otherwise be the case.

PARA.TAB: I responded favourably to that suggestion but asked him, because of the pressure of time I was under, to have a go at reducing the Cooperating for Peace book to its bare essentials in the form of a publishable article. That is the draft that was done for me. As discussion proceeded on the kind of article the publishers were looking for, the shape of the article—I had to remind myself of that from the files that I asked to be brought into the chamber after Senator Vanstone asked her question—really changed quite a lot. From being a general summary of all of the themes in the blue book, it narrowed down to a quite specific account, development or extension of the theme of the blue book, intrastate conflict, which was touched upon only relatively lightly in the book itself.

So the article took a new form. Although I did draw on aspects of Professor Mack's draft—which I found very helpful because he is an outstanding academic and scholar, and a very helpful collaborator—the article, as finally published, represents very much my own contribution to this debate. As proof, I table the manuscript as produced by me as the first draft of the article. The manuscripts went through a number of subsequent refinements, as things do. These are just corrected typescripts and do not have the impact of this manuscript copy.

You will see, Senator Vanstone and anyone else who cares to examine it—and I hope a few do—that, overwhelmingly, the article in its construction and language is my own. There are something like 26 pages of manuscript, with just a handful of pages involving re-cuttings and re-pastings of that material. I am not sure whether I was quite accurate in saying that the proportion was 85:15—I might have been doing Professor Mack a bit of injustice in that respect. No doubt, Senator Vanstone will pore over the manuscript with a ruler. The truth of the matter is that the concept of the article, as it finally appeared, was mine and, overwhelmingly, the content was mine. Senator Vanstone can look at that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not acknowledge his contribution.
—I explained the circumstances of the attribution.
—He gave you the idea for the article; he did the basic work; and you did not acknowledge his contribution.

—Thank you, Senator Vanstone. When you have had a chance to look at this manuscript, if you have any grace in that body and mind of yours, you should give me an apology for the imputations that you cast upon me.
—Get real!

—So that is the response. There was a real willingness on my part to acknowledge the contribution and input of Professor Mack, even though it turned out to be only a relatively small contribution to the final product. The circumstance, as I recall it, was that it was not the editorial policy of the journal Foreign Policy to have footnotes of that or of any other kind except in exceptional circumstances which you approach the editor and ask for. In those circumstances, Professor Mack said that he was delighted for the article to go forward without the normal attributions of input—however minor—that I have always been willing to make.

PARA.TAB: While I am on my feet, I also table a copy of the accounts for Cooperating for Peace, which we would have submitted in estimates committee had anyone been interested in asking for them. Those accounts spell out the purchases made by my department and the relevant financial inputs and outputs involved. While I am about it, I will also say—because this canard has a life of its own—that as soon as I can extract the manuscripts from archives, where they are presently lodged, I will be very happy to table or make available for scrutiny, in my Canberra or Melbourne office, the complete manuscript of Australia's Foreign Relations, so you can see for yourself how much is in my handwriting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not interested in that.

—No, you are not interested in that because you are afraid of the answer that you will get when you look at the facts. It will spoil the prejudice, it will spoil the allegation, it will spoil the innuendo, it will spoil the imputations. You are just impossible in that respect. I will make these things available publicly, because I have kept them. They are fully there and they will be on the record. I also do it to the extent that I can find the manuscript—

—Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I have been reasonably tolerant in this particular matter. I am claiming that the imputation against me that I have either attacked or cast negative aspersions and imputations against the minister be withdrawn. The facts of the matter speak for themselves. I asked a very simple and reasonable question about whether appropriate credit had been given to an article. The truth of the matter is that appropriate credit was not given. The minister then said that I should be interested in every other article or book that he has written and suggested when I said, `No, I am not because it is not the question I asked,' that somehow I am not interested in the truth of the matter. I have the answer that I was looking for. You did not damn well give credit where you should have. He should withdraw that imputation against me. I asked a simple question. We have the answer, and he does not need to go on about it any more.
—On the point of order: Miles Kupa got credit for the Marshall Islands. Why should Mr Mack not get credit for this?
—Can I get on with my answer?

—I was going to make a ruling on the point of order, commenting on the fact that it has been obviously a very vigorous debate with both sides taking part, leaving the chair somewhat as a spectator. You may continue your answer, but you should recognise the chair in doing so.

—What is in issue is my integrity in terms of my capacity and willingness to put on the public record publications with my name on them which are not my work. This is a demonstration to the contrary; this is my work. I will also give you a demonstration as to just how much of the book Australia's Foreign Relations is my work. You can look at the amount of handwritten manuscript work that is on that. I will also do my best to give you a demonstration—if the material is around, which I think it is, but I will need to check—
—That was Bruce Grant, wasn't it?

—With Bruce Grant. You can see for yourself and work out the relative contributions of whoever you like. I have put hundreds of hours of my time late at night, early in the morning and over weekends into trying to put into publishable form material that I think is important in Australia's national interest, to get on the record views and approaches which are now very much part of an international debate. I make no apology about that. I repeat: I will make available that manuscript so that Senator Vanstone, even if she is not interested, Senator Kemp and anyone else who is minded to go on making these kinds of allegations can have the opportunity to see for themselves. Let the record speak for itself and let there be the apologies that are due as a result.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise on a point of order. Earlier during the discussion, Senator Vanstone interjected and made the statement, `Go and bake some cookies.' I understand that there may be some humorous elements to that, but there is also a very serious element in it. It is very derogatory of the role of women within the Senate. It is a statement that would certainly not be acceptable in the way that it portrays women if it came from a male member of this Senate. I certainly do not think it is acceptable when it comes from a female member of this chamber. I ask that Senator Vanstone withdraw the statement. If she is unwilling to withdraw the statement, she should be directed to withdraw by you, Madam Deputy President.
—Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: there are different ways that we all speak to each other. I quite agree that would not be an acceptable remark if a male made it to you.
—It is not acceptable from a female.

—Madam Deputy President, it is appropriate that I should address you. Equally, a man might say to another man, `Why don't you calm down and go and have a beer.' If Senator Neal is offended by my suggesting that she go and do something else more useful than her contribution here, then I am happy to withdraw. I would not be offended if she said that to me. I just ask her to remember Eleanor Roosevelt's very famous and sensible line, `Nobody can make you feel inferior but you yourself.' You can only do that if you let people do it to you.
—I think Australian women in general will be offended by your diminution of their role in this process. But I also find offensive the constant—
—I have withdrawn.
—Order! Senator Vanstone has withdrawn. Do you wish to raise another point of order?

—It is in relation to pointing across the chamber, which is a continuous mode of addressing people across the chamber generally. I have never raised it before but while I am on my feet I suggest that the senator also be directed that physical indications like that are considered rude and not appropriate in this chamber.
—We will move on to motions to take note of answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to the importation of pork from Canada.

SPEECH.PARA: I need to wipe the smile off my face regarding that last episode. Next time Senator Forshaw tours the shearing sheds he might take Senator Neal with him.

PARA.TAB: I wish to refer to the answer given by Senator Collins today to my question with regard to the worm known as Trichinella spirallis, which is in pork meat and which is particularly prevalent in Canada. My question related to the alteration of the protocols with regard to the entry of pork into Australia and what was required. Unfortunately, Senator Collins is not here. It is an incredibly important matter. I wish to inform Senator Collins and the chamber that a Pig Research and Development Corporation memo states:

SPEECH.PARA: On 1 June 1995 advice was received from AQIS that following a request from Agriculture & Agri Food Canada the import requirements for pigmeat from Canada have been amended.
So the first thing that tells us is that our protocols are being run from Canada and are not controlled by AQIS and the minister. It then states:
Basically the changes remove the requirement that meat be frozen at minus 18 degrees C for at least 30 days providing that the meat is heated according to current specifications at 55 degrees C . . .
It then states:
. . . it appears—
and I emphasise the word `appears'—
that the cooking process itself inactivates the Trichinella organisms . . .

This is a very serious matter. It is human health that is at risk. I said in my question today that approximately eight people a year die in Canada from this, as well as other people elsewhere in the world. We now find under this minimum approach to the entry of imported goods into this country that the protocols are breaking down.

PARA.TAB: An enormous debate has occurred in the grain industry about the import of grain into this country, and the minister was hauled back from his previous position. We have seen the problems in the salmon industry in Tasmania. We do not know what the hell is going on with the pilchards in this country. There was the case of the lupins that came into Western Australia which had to be totally destroyed because of a disease imported from Europe. They even went past the protocol system; they were not inspected. Once again we see that this minister is completely out of touch with his department and AQIS. We find AQIS making the decisions.

In a previous answer to a question by Senator Boswell the minister made mention of the fact that before pig meat could come into Australia it had to be frozen. The facts are quite different from that. I noted in the answer to my question that Senator Collins said he would look into the matter and come back to the Senate if necessary.

Senator Collins should have known that this was going to happen and he should have acquainted himself with the facts and the risks. He should have known, through advice from his own department, that this reference to cooking was referred to only in the context of `appears' and not that it did.

I put it on the public record that under the minimal approach to protocols that we are adopting in this country, enormous damage will be done to public health, industry and a whole range of people—and that those risks need not be taken. One of the reasons these things are getting passed is that we have a minister who is becoming very tired and is inadequate for the performances required to protect Australian industry and Australian people.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the memo from the corporation. I have had this action cleared with the duty minister.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: PIG RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION
