MEMORANDUM
Date:6 June 1995
To:Mr Trevor HopeChairman
Dr Rob WilsonDirector
Mr Bruce MuirheadDirector
Dr Roger CampbellDirector
Mr Ian FarranDirector
Dr Richard SheldrakeDirector
Dr John HolderDirector
Mr John GirdlestoneDirector
From:Dr Mike Taverner Executive Director
Ref:MRT:hra:069
Re:Proposed Changes to Import Requirements for Canadian Meat
On 1 June 1995 advice was received from AQIS that following a request from Agriculture & Agri Food Canada the import requirements for pigmeat from Canada have been amended.

Basically, the change has removed the requirement that the meat be frozen at minus 18(o) degrees C for at least 30 days providing that the meat is heated according to current specifications at 55(o) degrees C for not less than 60 minutes or reaches a pH of 5.2. The requirement for freezing was to inactivate Trichinella spiralis however, it appears that the cooking process itself inactivates the Trichinella organisms and therefore it is not necessary that the meat be frozen prior to export. There are some supporting technical references to this document, however, there appears to be little that can be done other than noting this change.
If there are further actions or information required by Directors, please contact me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Crane said. As Senator Crane pointed out, the word `appears' is an incredible one in the circumstances because, as he said, the requirement for freezing was to inactivate trichinella spiralis. However, it `appears' that the cooking process itself inactivates the organism and, therefore, it is not necessary that the meat be frozen prior to export.

PARA.TAB: When you are making a serious change like that, you do not do it on the basis of an appearance. One would have thought you would do it on the basis of scientific proof. If there is scientific proof, then the word `appears' should not appear there—it is shown to be. But for it to `appear' to be, we are going to change the rules no matter what risks Senator Crane has pointed out exist.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) not only has to come back, as Senator Crane said, but also to provide this Senate with the scientific proof supporting the proposition that the cooking process itself inactivates the trichinella organisms. Without that proof, I think it is improper for this change to be made and to be done in a way about which not even the minister knows.

This is even more extraordinary—on a day when the minister is meeting the industry, when Senator Crane asked this question, he did not know the facts about this change in the protocol which significantly affects the standing of this industry. I find it absolutely incredible that the minister was either kept in ignorance or failed to find out.

The other point I want to make briefly about the minister is that he said in this answer and, I think, in the response to Senator Boswell's question, that imports represented something like only two per cent of total pork products. That is a ludicrous and inappropriate measure—and the minister knows it.

The cuts coming in from Canada are the prime cuts—the essential bits that have the big market. The whole of the pig does not make bacon. The minister has failed to note the proportion of imports in relation to the cuts of pork with which those imports compete.

So it would be very nice and a pleasant change if this minister at last produced some figures which were honest and to the point: what is the relative significance of imports relating to those prime cuts that are competing with Australian pork?

I can remember when I was in the beef industry people assuming that the price of rump steak should bear some relationship to the cost of buying a bullock on the hoof. If only the whole of the beast had been rump steak there might have been some relevance to it. But there are a whole lot of bits like brisket, for example, which earn you very little.

So all I want is, firstly, for the minister to be well informed and a lot better informed about what is going on in this industry than he is; and, secondly, to produce figures when he is trying to argue a case in this chamber that bear some relevance to reality.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks that were made by Senator Crane and Senator Michael Baume when taking note of those two answers. I do not think Senator Bob Collins, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, really got to the nub of the question. Senator Boswell was talking about the fact that 20 per cent of pig farmers have been lost to the industry in the last six months. He said that he recognised the problems grain prices caused for pig producers. Grain prices have risen because of a shortage of supply.

PARA.TAB: I am also disturbed about the answer that Senator Collins gave about the grain industry when he spoke about imported grain. Of course that is of concern; it is a problem for people in the grain—I declare my pecuniary interests in that regard. He said that in 1995-96 grain prices will fall below or be at pre-1993 levels. That will mean that he will have a grain industry that will go down the chute because, if grain is produced at the levels of the cost of production in the 1995-96 year and if producers only get pre-1993 prices for it, they will be in a great deal of trouble.

One of the problems that I do not think the minister has addressed is the fact that the government has imposed costs and charges on the farming community, whether they be pig producers, grain producers or whatever. We have wholesale sales taxes and fuel price increases and transport cost increases because of the wholesale sales tax increases. We have waterfront problems which have not been cleaned up. We have no labour market reform to make the cost in our abattoirs cheaper, or at least competitive with other countries, when killing our animals, whether it be pigs or whatever. I do not think that the minister has quite grasped that.

The minister said that this afternoon he would be talking with people from the industry and that there may be an Industry Commission reference regarding the competitiveness of the pig industry. That is okay, but all those costs and charges, unless they are taken off, will still not solve the problems of the industry. He also said that they will look at what damage is being caused by the subsidies that have been given to the industry in Canada. He indicated too that he would look at the dumping problem but, as Senator Boswell made the point, it was proved some time ago that injury had been caused but nothing at all had happened about it.

Basically, I believe that the minister missed the point with his answer to the question. I think it is high time that this government took note of the costs and charges associated with primary industry, whether it be in the pig, pork or bacon industries or whatever.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Crane properly indicated, it is broadcast day. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) is now not here but, as I understand it and as he indicated, he had to leave the chamber to talk to the people who produce pig meat in this country.
—I didn't criticise him for that.

—I know. Of course you were not criticising him. Those who suggested that the pig farmers should be here during question time so that they could hear what the opposition was saying on their behalf should not be criticised either. I am glad that Senator Crane raised that point. This minister, who has been criticised in other respects, I presume is at this very minute doing what he should be doing. He has gone off to speak to the farmers. The matter has to be talked through. I think that that is the thing that both sides of the chamber should be intent upon doing rather than criticising the minister for what he is supposed not to have done.

PARA.TAB: We should be working through this problem because it is a more difficult problem than might have been thought. I am not sure whether Senator Crane is saying that any imports from Canada should be banned, that we should shut Canada out of the market, or whether he is saying that there should be fair competition. He has not made that clear.

We should trade with Canada more and more if we can. There is benefit in trade with Canada, and that trade will be prejudiced if we use wrong tests to exclude its product. If the salmon and pig meat that Canada wants to bring to Australia are diseased, then they should be shut out, but they should be shut out on that basis and not on another basis. I think that much has been done by the high commissioner from Canada, Mr Berry, in this respect. I think he has taken a very appropriate approach to this, and it would be very good for our international relations with Canada—a great friend of this country—if we approached this problem properly. The government, through its minister, is out there at this very moment talking this through with the farmers so that our farmers, our trade with Canada and our relations with Canada may be properly looked after.

The farming sector of this country is, as this government has said again and again, an integral part of the economy and an integral part of society. Senator Crane, I am glad that you have acknowledged that the minister is presently doing what he should be doing, that he can talk this problem through with the industry and that a proper and enlightened solution will be found.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to the announced resumption of French nuclear testing in the South Pacific Region.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, we debated a private member's bill which would have had the effect of banning Australian uranium exports to France, and that debate was gagged on a motion by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) with the support of the opposition. We have seen further evidence since yesterday that the French have not even been honest about why they are conducting these tests. I referred in my question to an article in this week's New Scientist, a very reputable science magazine, which said:

France will use the eight nuclear tests it announced last week to design a new improved warhead, according to researchers who keep a watch on weapons development. The official line that France needs to carry out the tests to perfect its computer models of nuclear explosions—which will eventually replace the tests—is grossly exaggerated, they say.

CHIRAC claims that the tests are needed to ensure the `safety, security and reliability' of France's nuclear deterrent and to help it to develop a system for simulating nuclear tests in the laboratory. He says that after the tests, France will sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty `without reserve'. . .

Prime Minister Alain Juppe says the tests are not aimed at making a new type of weapon. But Christopher Paine, senior researcher at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington DC is not convinced. `Why the French need to do the tests and why they say they need to do them are two different things,' he says.

Last year, Paine visited Paris as a member of a team investigating France's attitude to nuclear testing. The team uncovered official concerns over the long-term reliability of the warhead installed in its submarine-launched ballistic missiles. Paine and other scientists monitoring nuclear arms say France will use the explosions to test a more robust design of warhead. Marc Launois, deputy director of the military applications division of France's Atomic Energy Commission, says only that the tests will be used to `perfect' French weapons.
Here is the denouement:
Chirac's mention of laboratory simulations refers to a planned 10 billion-franc—
that is $3.5 billion—

programme, called PALEN. This will include a giant laser, called Megajoule, which will be built near Bordeaux and should be ready by 2003. Weapons scientists can use lasers to recreate the conditions at the heart of a thermonuclear explosion. They train the beams of light on frozen pellets of hydrogen, forcing the pellets to implode and the hydrogen nuclei to fuse. The results will help to build computer models of nuclear blasts.
There we have the explanation for the term `improving the computer models'. It has nothing whatsoever to do with the tests in the Pacific. It goes on:

But Paine says French officials have `vastly overstated' the need for more tests to design simulation methods. Patricia LEWIS, director of the Verification Technology Information Centre in London, goes further. She says the French need no more tests because they could simply use models developed by the US and apply them to data collected during past tests. But Launois argues that insufficient data were collected at earlier tests.
It goes on to say:
`France has always jealously guarded its nuclear independence.'
My God, it jealously guards its nuclear independence at the expense of the whole world.

PARA.TAB: Again, I make the plea that this is further evidence that Mr Chirac, the French president, is quite deliberately misleading the rest of the world in relation to the nature of those computer modelling tests. He is referring to something quite different from the nuclear explosions. He is misleading the rest of the world.

We have seen seven heads of government in Europe go to the French president and complain. We have seen the French president ignore those complaints. We have seen the French president ignore the complaints of the Australian government, the New Zealand government and a number of governments in the South Pacific area. The arrogance of this man really needs to be brought to book.

I believe, as I said yesterday, that the only action the Australian public will accept as reasonable for the Australian government to do in relation to these French tests is to ban the export of Australian uranium to France. We indicated in 1988 that well over 2,000 kilograms of Australian uranium was mislabelled and could have found its way into nuclear tests. That is quite contrary to what the minister said in his reply when he indicated that only three per cent of Australian uranium is used by France. A danger lies there. We think that strong action needs to be taken. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day, relating to comments made by the Governor-General on 21 June 1995 concerning euthanasia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans was not intentionally misleading the chamber when he responded to me, but he said things to the chamber which were in direct contradiction to what he said to the chamber on 20 October 1983 in respect of the very matter about which I asked him. I referred to section 9 of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act and the inappropriateness of the Governor General's pro-euthanasia statement in light of the fact that that section enables the Governor-General to disallow that legislation within six months of its being affirmed by the administrator.

PARA.TAB: The minister, Senator Gareth Evans, told the Senate this afternoon that that would need to be on advice. Nobody doubted that that would need to be on advice, but on advice from whom? The minister said that it would be on the advice of the Northern Territory government. That is quite different to what he told the Senate on 20 October 1983. I will read what he said to the Senate then:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that section 9 of that Act—
that is, the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act—

allows the Governor-General acting, of course, on the advice of the Executive Government of the Commonwealth to disallow a Territory law or any part of a law within six months of the Territory Administrator's assent to it.

As I said, the minister has probably only unintentionally misled the chamber, but it is a very important point because this government should grasp the nettle on this issue. Not only did the minister not accept my invitation to consider as proper the Governor-General's statement; he actually described it as `controversial'. In government parlance, that probably means `improper' but why not come out and say so directly? This matter relates not only to the current situation with the Governor-General; it is also a question that the government, the parliament as a whole, and the people of Australia have to face in considering whether to have a president and how that president will be appointed or elected. Consideration of these matters is essential now before we get into further trouble.

PARA.TAB: This is a situation where the Governor-General used his office to promote the legalisation of the intentional killing of one innocent human being by another human being. Not only is that improper; it also demeans the office of the Governor-General. That office is a symbol of the power of the state, and the state has the duty to uphold the right to life and liberty of all. For the occupant of that position to advocate the legalisation of the intentional killing of one innocent human being by another human being is to demean that office.
The government should not leave it at `controversial'. It should be straightforward in saying that the statement demeaned the office of the Governor-General and was entirely improper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to congratulate Senator Harradine on his question. It is a pity that we cannot congratulate the minister on his answer. The matters raised in Senator Harradine's question go to the very heart of why His Excellency should not have addressed such a controversial issue.

PARA.TAB: There is legislation on the statute book, passed by this parliament, which officially requires His Excellency to exercise a judgment in relation to Northern Territory legislation within a period of six months. How on earth can he undertake that duty and that obligation when he has pre-judged and, in effect, broadcast his own personal views before he can be appropriately petitioned by the people or approached by the government, as it should approach him to cancel that legislation. That is the nub of this matter, which the government refused to address until recently.

We had the giveaway line from Senator Gareth Evans that His Excellency's comments were controversial. I fully agree with Senator Harradine: if you listen to the poli-speak of Senator Evans and others, a word like `controversial' in relation to one of their mates clearly means that the statement was highly inappropriate and improper. I am glad we got that admission out of the government since I spoke about this in the debate on matters of public interest earlier today.

The Labor Party's silence on this matter to date has been absolutely appalling. In effect, it has given de facto support to the lack of value placed on human life by His Excellency in his speech. Indeed, when I asked a question about this matter earlier this week, the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, said that it was inappropriate for the government to become involved. But the government found it quite proper to get involved when Arthur Tunstall made a comment completely unrelated to the government. The government said that it disapproved of his comments—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you disagree with that?

—No, not at all. In fact, I was one of the signatories to the letter that was sent around by Senator Margaret Reynolds because I held that view. But the government cannot hide behind the fact that His Excellency was expressing a personal view. The government comes out on other occasions and attacks people who were also expressing a personal view, albeit that that person held high office—Arthur Tunstall. I suggest to Senator Faulkner that the Governor-General holds a lot higher office than Arthur Tunstall and therefore he should be even more restrained in the comments that he makes.

PARA.TAB: The other part of this hypocrisy is that when the Western Australia governor made some controversial comments recently the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia was into him like a rat up a drain pipe. But that was okay because it was the Western Australia governor. The Australian Labor Party is happy to criticise him for his comments, but not the Governor-General—undoubtedly because he was a former mate of the Australian Labor Party. There is one thing about the Western Australia governor: he had the decency to apologise for having offended people. His Excellency the Governor-General ought to do the same. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Reynolds, I present the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies entitled R-rated material on pay-TV, regulation of bulletin board systems, code of practice in the television industry, together with the transcript of evidence and supplementary material.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies gives to the chamber an update of the activities which the Senate committee is engaged in. It deals with our references relating to R-rated material on pay TV; the regulation of bulletin board systems; and the question that has been occupying our attention as well, program standards for free to air television. All of these matters, and others, are of vital interest to the public. I can say that the committee has addressed these matters with those concerns in mind.

PARA.TAB: I also would like to say that the committee goes about its work in a very open way and has taken the opportunity to invite persons interested in particular subject areas referred to the committee to speak to the committee. For example, in regard to the operation of codes of practice in the television industry generally, the committee held a public seminar in Sydney on 18 May 1995, to which all players were invited. It was a very well attended meeting. It would be of interest, I am sure, to other senators and to the public at large to receive a transcript of the evidence and the discussion that took place at that public seminar.

As a result of the work of the committee, when the broadcasting services legislation was dealt with by this parliament, a statement was made by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Bob Collins, that it was the intention of the government not to allow on free to air television material that went beyond the former AO classification. The committee has referred to that in its report. I am glad to see that the chair of the committee, Senator Reynolds, has entered the chamber. She, like me, was probably under the impression that this would be coming on at about 20 minutes past 4.

We have adverted to that matter in this report. It is a matter that the committee wishes the government to ensure occurs. There is also reference to the fact that the various program standards of content, et cetera, are not readily identifiable as uniform between the various free-to-air television stations such SBS, ABC and the commercial broadcasting stations.

As the committee indicated, it awaits the response by the government in respect of its recommendations relating to R-rated material on pay television. As honourable senators will remember, we recommended against that. We indicated that we may reconsider our recommendation if the Attorney-General tabled a revised R classification to ensure the appropriateness for broadcasting of such material into the home environment. We had indicated in our report that our recommendation that R-rated material should not be permitted on pay television was based on the evidence of the community concern about the levels of violence in the media, especially depictions of sexual violence and realistic, degrading, demeaning or exploitative sexual material.

The regulation of bulletin boards is a very topical issue at present. Many parents and, indeed, many people in the community generally are concerned about the material which is excessively violent or sexually explicit to be downloaded off Internet. Those who are involved in the Internet system may well have concerns about the integrity of that system if this is allowed to continue. We held a seminar on this matter, to which a number of people were invited. I am sure it would be of interest to honourable senators and members of parliament generally and the public generally to read the discussions that took place at that seminar. The volume is available from the committee on request.

We noted in our report to you, Madam Deputy President, that the next meeting of the Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers is scheduled to be held in July 1995 at which a national approach will be discussed. The committee is most interested to hear what the decisions will be. We expect to hold public hearings with government representatives and technical experts on the adequacy and technical feasibilities of the ministers' decisions. We also hope that the ministers will take particular account of the need to protect minors from material which could cause them harm—material that is readily available to any computer literate child. Many of them are very computer literate, especially the children that I know, in how they are able to handle that technology. That material needs to be addressed and action taken to ensure that the rights of children and parents are protected from that material and, indeed, the integrity of the system is upheld.
I notice that Senator Reynolds is in the chamber. I will defer to her and thank the Senate for allowing me to fill in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine. I am sorry I was not here for the tabling of the report because I think it is a report about issues that are of major concern out there in the Australian community. The issue of how to balance the new technology and management of the new technology against the standard of expectation in the Australian community is one that concerns all of us. I think the key is education. I am not convinced that it is a question of censorship, as such, but it is certainly a question of a sensible approach to education and appropriate regulation, be it self-regulation or regulation that is more prescriptive from government.

PARA.TAB: The report covers three major issues. First of all, it covers our report on the issue of R-rated material on pay TV. This has created considerable interest in the community. During our year-long inquiry, we took evidence from experts in the fields of psychology, media studies and communications, as well as from a wide range of concerned community groups. The committee also closely examined the attitudinal research of the Australian Broadcasting Authority and found that, despite high levels of support for R-rated material on pay TV in principle, it is clear that media predictions of violence, and particularly sexual violence, are of major concern to the majority of Australians.

In the ABA research we found that when we asked people, `Do you think R should be available on pay TV?' everyone said, `Yes, that is okay,' but later, in answering questions, they contradicted that view by expressing grave concerns about levels of violence already in the media and the possible impact that extreme depictions of violence, especially sexual violence, may have on certain personalities. Everyone felt that, while it would not affect them, it may affect other people; it may affect their behaviour and impact on society negatively.

We found the ABA's research quite contradictory. That is why we finally came down with a recommendation to the government that there should be a review of the R category. There is R and there is R. It seems to have become a dumping ground for all material, a catch-all. When material cannot be classified in any other category, into R it goes. It means that there is certain material within the R category which we believe would be totally inappropriate to be, as Senator Harradine has put it, freely available and going into the home environment.

I was in New Zealand on Monday and they are dealing with precisely the same issues. We know it is of concern in many countries. How you get the right balance between freedom of the individual, freedom of speech and the right of adults to see and read material of their choice, and the protection of children is no longer the old censorship debate of the 1960s, which is when I first became involved in the debate.

We have taken on a new way of working on our committee. I think it is probably because we are committed to the promotion of an educated approach to these very complex issues. We ran two seminars, one on self-regulation in relation to codes of practice, and one on bulletin boards. We feel that a great deal of benefit came out of each of those seminars. The material will, we believe, assist not only us in making future recommendations but also censorship ministers as they consider the vexed question of how to regulate bulletin boards.

We do think that the decision of censorship ministers next week is of critical concern to many parents, teachers and others who are concerned about the potential impact of young people having access to totally inappropriate material—they have even been put in touch with paedophiles through this new medium. But that is not to say that we should criticise the medium continually because the Internet has enormous opportunities for entertainment and knowledge. It is not appropriate for us to continually blame the medium but we do have to learn how to get the right balance between controlling the way in which the medium is used and appropriate community standards. That is where we come back to education.

The seminar on programming in the television industry held in Sydney in May was the first parliamentary review of the effectiveness of the self-regulatory initiatives of the Broadcasting Services Act of 1992. All sectors of the industry were represented and the large public gallery indicated the interest in the topic in the general community.

While the pay TV sector is still more concerned with technical and marketing issues than programming, free to air television has had nearly three years experience with self-regulation. In the Spring sittings the committee will present its report card on the state of the industry. It is fair to say now that there are aspects of the current system about which the committee does hold a number of concerns. I just want to flag those because the committee is still considering these issues.

Over the next six months the committee will be continuing its inquiries into the regulation of bulletin boards and into television programming. We await the government's response in regard to two major issues: R-rated material on pay TV and overseas sources of audio tech services. The committee also foreshadows the conduct of further public seminars into major topical issues as its workload permits.

One issue that I know a number of members of the committee are interested in pursuing is the question of the extent and availability of child pornography in Australia, notwithstanding the fact that it is illegal. Nevertheless, we know the material is available. There have been reports of just how many items have been seized by Customs. Of course, with every respect to Customs—and I note the minister is in the chamber—you have to wonder how much material may not necessarily be recognised at the border and how much material is circulating in the general community. That is of major concern. The Senate can be assured that the committee is still active and is, in my opinion—and I hope in that of other members—fulfilling a very important role. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports:

SPEECH.PARA: Report No. 16 of 1995: Golf Course Estate development, Palmerston, Northern Territory and Report No. 17 of 1995: joint venture with Delfin Property Group of the Willows, Townsville, Queensland, for defence housing.
I seek leave to move a motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee's 16th and 17th reports for 1995 relate to joint venture housing developments to be undertaken by the Defence Housing Authority—DHA—in partnership with the Delfin property group in Darwin and Townsville. The committee, while recommending that both projects should proceed, has made a number of comments on each.

PARA.TAB: The Darwin project, which is the subject of the committee's 16th report for 1995, relates to the development of the Golf Course Estate at Palmerston, Northern Territory. The government decision to increase the army presence in the north involved a need to expand infrastructure works at Robertson Barracks and to provide additional housing in the Darwin area to accommodate army personnel and their families. The site to the north of University Avenue will be known as Fairway Waters in the suburb of Durack.

The Defence Housing Authority proposes to develop a 132.9 hectare site in a joint venture project which will integrate service and private sector housing and yield some 1,400 units, of which approximately one-third will be retained for service families. The site is well located for army personnel working at Robertson Barracks and is in close proximity to the educational, community, recreational and commercial facilities of Palmerston.

As part of the negotiations for this site, DHA has undertaken to extend the existing golf course at Palmerston to an 18-hole course at a cost of $4.7 million. Half of this cost will be borne by the joint venture partner. For a time the committee has been concerned that some DHA housing is being built too close together, with resultant lack of privacy for the occupants. The chairman made the comment that one TV would do the whole street. The committee, therefore, recommends that the Defence Housing Authority considers increasing the size of its housing blocks, so that more privacy is afforded to occupants of its houses.

At the time of the public hearing, the Defence Housing Authority was not able to provide the committee with definite plans of the types of houses it intends to construct. The committee recommends that once housing plans are finalised, and before construction commences, the Defence Housing Authority formally briefs the committee on the types and cost of houses it intends to construct and the size of the blocks intended for the Golf Course Estate.

The committee also recommends that the Defence Housing Authority includes in its contract documents a clause stating that subcontractors must be paid before progress payments are made to contractors. The committee was advised at the public hearing, that a site on Marjorie Street, approximately one kilometre to the north of the proposed estate, was used for many years as a Commonwealth, and later private, analytical laboratory. That site has elevated levels of lead, zinc, arsenic and cadmium.

The committee was advised that preliminary investigations of this now vacant land indicate that there is a potential for the elevated levels to have extended along the drainage line onto the proposed site. However, the precise extent is unknown at this stage. It is therefore necessary to ensure that the site does not pose an environmental or health risk. In order to prevent such occurrences in the future the committee recommends that the Defence Housing Authority ensures that its sites have been examined and cleared of any possibility of contamination prior to referral of projects to the committee.

The committee recommends the development of the Golf Course Estate at Palmerston Northern Territory, at an estimated cost of $144.02 million to the Defence Housing Authority, subject to confirmation that the Defence Housing Authority would build on the site only if any contamination has been remediated to the satisfaction of its expert advisers. The recommendation is also subject to the briefing of the committee by the Defence Housing Authority on the types and costs of houses it intends to construct, and the size of the blocks intended for the Golf Course Estate.

The second report which I have just tabled, the committee's 17th report for the year, deals with the development of land at the Willows in Townsville. The DHA identified a need to provide adequate housing for service families in Townsville. Originally, DHA formed a joint venture with Delfin Property Group to tender for a parcel of land at Douglas in Townsville. The tender was unsuccessful. Soon after, on behalf of the joint venture, DHA successfully negotiated the acquisition of 107 hectares of land at Kirwan, known as the Willows.

Development of a portion of the land on the eastern side of the main stormwater drain has already taken place. The proposal examined by the committee involves the development of the balance of the land. It is planned that DHA acquire approximately 25 per cent of the lots from the joint venture at a reasonable discount and construct new houses for service families, specifically designed for the local climate.

The DHA owns 833 houses in Townsville which are classified as being substandard and, of these, 309 will be disposed of and the balance will be upgraded over the next three years. I know that my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald, who is in the chamber this afternoon, has been very concerned about the standard of service families' housing in Townsville for quite some time. The committee concluded that there is a need to provide additional houses in Townsville as a consequence of existing substandard housing, the DHA disposal program and planned relocations of Defence personnel to Townsville from southern states.

The site which the joint venture will develop is 107 hectares, which will yield 1,000 blocks, of which no more than 20 per cent will be courtyard lots. DHA and Delfin will share the development costs and any profits equally.

The DHA will acquire a minimum of 200 blocks during the life of the development, with the balance being offered for private sale. Traditional suburban blocks will be 650 square metres and courtyard lots 450 square metres. As was the case with the Palmerston report, the committee has recommended that the DHA should consider increasing the size of its housing blocks so that more privacy is afforded to occupants and advise the committee of the size of the blocks intended for the Willows development.

The committee has recommended that before any site works commence a comprehensive resource inventory should be undertaken, including vegetation, soils and the presence and location of any cultural sites of significance. Measures designed to protect endangered or rare species and cultural sites found on the site should be implemented.

The committee has made a number of recommendations concerning the design of the houses. The first is that the DHA, having gone to the expense of commissioning a portfolio of tropical housing designs, should retain ownership of any plans commissioned from local architects and engage tropical design experts from James Cook University to review any designs before they are accepted. When these plans are finalised and before construction commences at the Willows, the committee has recommended that the DHA should formally brief the committee on the types and cost of houses it intends to construct and the sizes of the blocks to be provided.

Another matter relating to the design of houses involves the provision of solar hot water heaters. DHA advised the committee that it is not proposed to provide the houses with solar hot water heaters on the grounds that it not the community standard in Townsville. The committee believes that the stance taken by the DHA is at variance with the government's policy to nationally reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and the reasons for not installing them in Townsville are out of touch with national interest considerations.

Current estimates suggest there are 250,000 solar hot water heaters already installed in Australia. The committee believes it is difficult to determine what community standards are with so many installed and strong growth expected as a consequence of Commonwealth initiatives such as the energy card.

Community standards are dynamic and the committee believes the stance taken by the DHA should not be reactive. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that DHA houses in the Willows estate should be provided with solar hot water heaters. When referred to the committee the estimated cost of the proposed joint venture development was $37 million while land acquisition cost was $5.6 million, a total of $42.6 million. Being a joint venture DHA is responsible for 50 per cent of the broad acre development costs—a total of $21.3 million. The cost of the acquisition of allotments and the construction of 200 houses amounts to $38.517 million giving a total cost to DHA of $59.817 million. I commend the reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (EXCISE) BILL 1995SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (CUSTOMS) BILL 1995SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (GENERAL) BILL 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should declare an interest in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Modification (Excise) Bill 1995 and cognate bills before the parliament at the moment. Unlike a lot of Labor senators, I own my own home. It is an old Queenslander. It is one that regrettably constantly requires roofing and guttering. It is a big old wooden place which constantly requires painting. On the rare times that I have some spare time I do some painting, some sealing, some puttying and little odd jobs around the house, like every other Australian who owns a home and like those who would like to buy a home. I enjoy doing that sort of thing.

PARA.TAB: In the future, if this bill is passed, it will cost me more every time I want to do some of those repairs. We have wanted our guttering repaired for months now. It is a bit hard to get a tradesman in my town at the moment. They left us alone for three months but fortunately—and I exerted no influence—they came along a couple of weeks ago and did my guttering. Unfortunately, the painter that we organised three or four months ago will not be there before 1 July. If this particular bill is passed, I will have to pay that much more. But will I? Senator Schacht might answer that question. As the minister for small business, he has been in Townsville telling the contractors how they will get on. My contractor has given me a fixed quote. He has not come yet. He will have to pay more for the paint that he uses on my place because of the wholesale sales tax that you want to charge him. What will he charge me? Will I have to pay it? My quote is a pretty fixed one. Someone is going to miss out. It may well have to be the small businessman that Senator Schacht is supposed to be looking after. I just hope that Senator Schacht, as the small business minister, will come over our side of the chamber and vote with us when this iniquitous tax on home owners and small businessmen is put before this parliament.

I am looking at new carpet for my house, which will require adhesives. I am looking at new aluminium windows and joinery, which will need facings and sealants. I am looking at some additional joinery if I happen to get new kitchen cupboards. The Labor Party will ensure additional taxes if I want to put in some more tiles, and regrettably I do. If I have to put in a few electrical points, it will cost the small businessman money who will then pass the cost on to me. I declare an interest in this bill, but I emphasise that every other Australian house owner has an interest in this bill. That is why there has been such absolute outrage by Australians everywhere at this tax on housing. As my colleague Senator Gibson said, the slogan for the Labor Party will be, `If you want your house taxed, vote Labor.' What better slogan could there be? That is obviously the way it will be.

My colleagues have been through this bill, and I do not want to repeat too much of what they have said. But I point out that in the year 1989-90, just before the recession, sales tax raised $10.132 billion or 11 per cent of taxation revenue. That fell for a little while, but this year, should these bills be passed, the government will obtain $14.16 billion from sales tax or almost 12 per cent of the total taxation revenue. So much for the Labor Party's promise last election that taxes would not go up! In 1992-93, the government raised $47.5 billion in revenue from income tax on individuals. In 1995-96, the government has forecast that it will raise $62.25 billion from the taxation of individuals.

I again ask: what happened to the Labor Party's promise not to increase taxation? In this budget the Labor Party is trying to put up the price of building materials by 12 per cent on those hardware and building material items which are subjected to this tax. They also want to put up the cost of a motor vehicle, the family car for ordinary Australians, by 30 per cent. So when you hear the Labor Party at the next election saying, `This is in legislation, this is law, we promise, we guarantee, we give an assurance, we'll cross our hearts and hope to die, we promise you all these things,' you can understand what the Labor Party means by that. You have only to look at the last election to realise that their promises are not worth the ink on a scrap of paper.

I do not really need to waste any of my time elaborating on that. The people of Australia have shown quite clearly in opinion polls recently that they have given up believing Mr Keating or any member of the Labor Party. PARA.TAB: That shows, Madam Acting Deputy President, that in yours and my town, for those wanting to buy a $100,000 house the price will go up by $1,950; and if they are building a house worth $136,000 the price will go up by $3,445. When I raised this very serious matter in the parliament yesterday, what sort of response did I get from the senior ministers of the crown? PARA.TAB: What did Senator Cook say when he waffled on about it? First of all, he said, `No-one has ever given us the figures.' We have given them to him now. Then he babbled on with this idiocy, saying that if we knock off these tax increases then the interest rates will go up.

What about the government knocking off a couple of hundred million dollars from the Qantas float? Would that raise interest rates as well? Even if interest rates fell by one per cent, the prime cost rise caused by the new tax would offset any interest saved. All of the other experts in the market have said the same thing and the institute is saying the same thing, that this pretty trite argument of Senator Cook's has no basis—and this has been exposed everywhere.
Finally, Madam Acting Deputy President, because I have nearly run out of time—and that is of some regret as I had a lot more to say—I do mention that—

—That is not necessary, Senator Panizza; I know we have to get on. The Townsville Chamber of Commerce, the same as every chamber of commerce right throughout regional Australia, has written to me pleading for us to stop these increases, because they quite rightly point out that the tax will impact harder on those of us living in regional Australia. They point out that small business already has problems and that new housing construction is down 40 per cent and they ask us to stop it. (Time expired)

—The sales tax exemptions and classifications related bills have a number of issues of concern. I will outline some of the key issues and in the committee stage I will give more details on the specifics. For example, passenger motor vehicles: not necessarily the rate of tax but the mechanism by which the tax was charged from budget night—which I know was charged on a lot of small items generally so as not to give undue benefits to some people and cause a rush on certain items—the problem is that obviously a number of people in our community, before there were any rumours of an increase in sales tax, were committed to the purchase of a motor vehicle. The problem is that those people are locked in.

PARA.TAB: The government is saying that those people have access to the Trade Practices Commission. This may well be true, but the average person's ability to utilise the law may be limited. It may also mean a feast for lawyers in this case. But there is no indication from the government that it may make this mechanism a little easier. There may be occasional rorts in the system. There may also be a number of people who have been caught. For most people, the second most valuable purchase that they make is a car. Of course, the family home is the biggest financial stake. It means that, if they have signed a contract to purchase a car, then an increase of this nature is substantial, especially if they are scraping to make the repayments.

There needs to be some mechanism other than a wipe of the hand saying, `Let them eat cake,' or in this case, `Let them go to the Trade Practices Commission,' to enable those people to more easily seek redress, or to allow some justice for people who are linked into a contract. A contract is a binding document.

I know the government will say, `People don't complain if we give them a tax reduction.' They are not usually the same people. We are talking about substantial amounts of money. We are not talking about very small amounts of money. It is really not good enough to say, `They will not complain if they get a tax decrease.' It is not a sufficient answer.

There are problems in the impost of a sales tax on building materials. The problems here seem to stem from the government suddenly realising that, in making a two footed jump to appear purer than pure in the Uruguay Round of GATT, we have gone from a 35 per cent import duty on such things as tiles to eight per cent—and that will go down to seven per cent.

Under the Uruguay Round of GATT the import duty was not required to go down from 35 per cent. But the government did it just to prove how wonderful we are and to try to assume that the rest of the world would be just as wonderful. Well, they were not. The point is that now, to make up the revenue, we are doing things like increasing taxes on the things that everybody needs—the basic parts of houses.

Everybody needs tiles. Now the Australian tile industry, which at this stage is producing about 20 per cent of tiles, will find it a lot more difficult to survive because tiles, for instance, as an item will become more expensive. It means that, once again, this measure will have an adverse impact on local industry and local joiners—and tiles are a basic part of a house. The reality is that the measure will have a greater effect on those people building a basic house than on those people building a very large house. Although you might have two bathrooms, it does not mean that you have a bigger percentage of those particular items.

Perhaps the least defensible of all—although the building materials section was obviously fairly poorly put together—in my opinion, in terms of logic, is the change in the tax treatment of recycled paper. The reason is that even American economists who have used the real economic rationalism—not this pretend fundamentalism—will say that if you are going to have a `market economy' what you do is even up the uneven playing field by looking at what the real costs of economic decisions are and using such things as the tax system to enable that playing field to at least be level.If you do not do that you are not creating a market, what you are doing is creating market imperfections. This is classic economic theory. We are assuming that that does not exist, and we are assuming that there is a level playing field; well, there is not.

The government makes certain commitments to the industry in order to enable recycling industries to get off the ground. It is quite true that the big players in the game—who mostly use organochlorines and who mostly continue the majority of their operations in ways that we think are very detrimental to the environment—don't mind about this increase. And why don't they mind? They don't mind because it means the little players—the people who are actually setting up their industries to produce recycled products as an entire industry—are going to go under.

I wonder about a government which sometimes pretends in international fora to be world's best practice, environmentally sensitive and so on, yet is standing by and allowing the big players in this industry in reality to stomp on the small players who are trying to do the right thing.

There are a lot of areas within sales tax which cannot be defended. There is not even a GATT excuse in relation to recycled paper. I asked very carefully during the committee hearing on the World Trade Organisation bills whether the government's move to remove this tax differential was to do with GATT. The answer from the government was that it was not to do with GATT; that we were not required under GATT to remove this, but we were doing it anyway.

So if there is a GATT excuse, it was not admitted before. If there is no requirement under GATT for us to remove this differential on recycled paper, there is no excuse whatsoever to remove the commitment the government gave to this industry, and no excuse at all, I believe, to be putting back the disadvantage companies will have by doing the right thing by the environment and avoiding the cost that otherwise the community ends up paying. The community ends up cleaning up the river system; the community loses the amenities of the forests; the community ends up paying those otherwise external costs.

Until governments, on whichever side of politics, recognise, firstly, that those external costs exist; and, secondly, that as a government they have a role to play in seeing that those external costs are built into the equation, you can talk all you like about the market but it is certainly not an even playing field, it is an uneven playing field, in that the government is loading the dice towards those who would continue to pollute the environment and inefficiently use resources.
There are a lot of issues here; there is obviously going to be an interesting committee stage, and you will be hearing more specifics as we go on.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the second reading of three sales tax bills—the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Modification (Excise) Bill 1995, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Modification (Customs) Bill 1995 and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Modification (General) Bill 1995. We are now concluding the second reading debate in which honourable senators have dealt with the broad purposes of the legislation. They have debated how well the legislation addresses that purpose. On behalf of the government, therefore, I conclude the debate by replying to the views expressed by, I think, 16 members of this chamber who participated in the debate.

PARA.TAB: It is perhaps in its own way right that there should have been a number of participants in the second reading stage of this debate because these are significant items of legislation. The bills themselves are probably unexceptional in the detail that they contain but what they signify is indeed very important. They spring from the budget this year—the 1995-96 budget—which was brought down on 9 May. The budget is a budget for its time.

This year the budget, which is a major event in Australia's annual economic calendar, addressed a number of important elements which are necessary to maintain the economy of Australia on a sustainable growth path. The budget addresses ever improving living standards. It addresses the need to cut unemployment, to improve the growth prospects of the economy, to keep inflation low and to ensure that Australia is able to hold its head up in the world economy as a model to others. It does so by, for the first time, putting in place a medium-term program to enhance national savings.

The linchpin of that program is, of course, the superannuation provisions that the government has made in this budget. On the one hand, these provisions guarantee Australians a dignified and decent retirement at levels above the age pension. On the other hand, they ensure that Australia builds up a pool of national savings capable of being tapped to reinvest in the growth of the Australian economy; that we do not have to borrow from foreigners in order to finance our own growth.

One of the most striking features of this budget is that it engages in what all of the commentators and the opposition were encouraging us to do but which we, in our own way, believed was right—to tighten the fiscal parameters of the budget. We have done so in a responsible way, in a balanced way and in an appropriate way. That is, we have sought to tighten them in a manner in which the social obligations of a government to provide proper education, health and social security are protected and maintained at world's best level. Nonetheless, we have sought to find savings. We have cut back government outlays in a variety of ways.

One of the features of this budget is that it is a fiscally tight budget. As I say, the responsible commentators have been calling on us to do that. This tightening also involved the further additional step of putting some Commonwealth assets up for sale.

The net effect of what we have done is to bring the budget into surplus in this coming year—a surplus of $718 million. Although this is not the first surplus for this government, it is indeed an important surplus; a surplus that in economics terms is an important provision in the counter-cyclical nature of economic management. It is an appropriate time to bring the budget into surplus. The surplus next year will be one of $3.4 billion. In 1996-97 it will be $7 billion plus, and that will be a structural surplus. We will have started to lift off with our pool of national savings, which are so important to the future health of our economy and so important to addressing the nagging questions of the current account deficit.

So far so good. Everyone agrees in theory that these things should be done; they applaud that these things should be done. The government has had the courage, the determination and the foresight to do them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pity you didn't do some last year. Then you wouldn't be in such a mess this year.

—We debated last year's budget last year. We are in a responsible position this year. I accept the interjection and say that, if Senator Kernot disagreed with our budget last year and thought we should have been tighter, last year was the time to say so. I would be grateful if Senator Kernot could tell me which areas of the budget she believes we should have cut last year. The important thing here is that, irrespective of what she thought of last year's budget, the proposition before the chamber now is this year's budget. This year's budget delivers on fiscal tightening and achieves a surplus. To unmake that is to swim against the tide of your own interjection—the inference that we are not fiscally tight enough. The question that is coming forward is the position of the other parties.

PARA.TAB: Let me conclude my narrative. The actions taken by this government are broadly endorsed by the OECD, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. In the private sector, the international ratings agency Moody's has recently expressed itself about the Australian economy, maintaining our credit rating but observing the major fiscal tightening that we have undertaken, and, indeed, coming to a lower forecast than our budget papers suggest on what the future track of the current account deficit might be and urging further fiscal tightening—something which we have heeded and which will take place next year and the following year. I am saying that there is a great deal of endorsement for what the government has done.

What does it mean to ordinary Australians? Governments answer to their people, so that question is an important consideration for this Labor government. For ordinary Australians, the significance of this budget means downward pressure on interest rates across the board but, for most Australians who are borrowers, on mortgages to finance their homes, the significance is downward pressure on those home loan interest rates. If interest rates were to fall one per cent, it would boost the ability of average Australians to purchase a new home, and it would increase that affordability by eight per cent, which would mean a reduction across the board in the price of an average home to the average Australian of $9,500.

This budget brings downward pressure on aiming and achieving those and better gains on interest rates, and they have those massive across the board benefits. I do not think anyone queries that. Given the speeches in the second reading debate by several honourable senators opposite and on the crossbenches, we have in this chamber the proposal to unmake the budget, to relieve that downward pressure, to take the pressure off interest rates and to do a number of other things which work against what everyone in loud chorus has said is the most important issue—attacking the current account deficit.

But when it comes to the point of having a macro-economic strategy which does those things positively, which is acclaimed around the world and approved of in this budget, and when it comes to the point of taking the responsible steps to deliver, what do we have from the opposition? We have obstruction. It wants to punch a $1.5 billion hole in this year's budget and take the downward pressure on interest rates off. One can only assume that those opposite are therefore quite happy to see interest rates in Australia remain stable or increase. That is the only logical consequence of what they are saying. No matter how you cut the cake and no matter how you throw the dice, that is the absolute outcome of the position from the opposition.

We have a slightly more sophisticated intervention from the Australian Democrats and from the Greens: not to oppose all of our revenue measures but to oppose those parts of them that they think have a popular mandate for—that is to say, applaud broad, responsible macro-economic management but play to the gallery and tamper with the budget, undermine its bottom line by trying to get a few claps of applause, or maybe a few votes in the ballot box for staggering minor parties by attacking some parts of it for which they think there is some public concern.

I know that there have been discussions between the various parties and the Treasurer (Mr Willis). I have seen the letter of the Treasurer to the minor parties indicating the government's response to their recommendations and to their suggestions about how the budget of the Australian government should be remade. The government is determined to push through and deliver this budget, given the massive advantage it gives to the Australian economy, the massive prospects it gives to the war against interest rates, the massive shot in the arm it gives to the attack upon the current account deficit and the real values that it implies for Australians in finding more and better work more easily and more often; less people will be unemployed; a high standard of living will be maintained; and disposable income for the ordinary Australians will be growing. It is also delivering across the fronts of health, education, social security and social value services.

The government is now in a position of saying—and I say it here—that we will fight for the provisions in this budget, irrespective of the views that have been put in this chamber. As a last—and I hope not forlorn—request, I again ask honourable senators not to be in a position of toeing their party line. When I first came into this chamber as a senator, this chamber was regarded as a chamber in which a degree of independence existed between the Senate and the House. When the leader of a political party in the House spoke on behalf of a party, independent senators here, even in the same party, would hold up as a right of freedom within their party—this is the coalition—that they were not necessarily bound by it. We now find that Mr Howard speaks for the senators in this chamber. I ask you on your side, the coalition side, to reconsider what he says and to act on behalf of the wider interests of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called party discipline.

—And to Senator Kernot, since you are the voice of the interjection and also the Leader of the Australian Democrats, I put it to you one more time to give some consideration to what are the overarching important principles here; that is, to deliver important macro-economic reforms to the Australian economy, not tamper with the budget bottom budget line, support stability, support the concept of continuing sustained economic growth and to vote with the government. I say the same to the Greens and the same to Senator Harradine. I acknowledge you all, and I thank you for your contribution to the debate. I do not necessarily agree with all the things that have been said. It has been a healthy debate. I look forward to the committee stage, and I commend these three bills to the Senate.
