TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support this request for amendment moved by the opposition. I want to talk about the general condition of the car industry and revisit an argument that Senator Coulter has run in here over the years concerning an approach to taxing motor cars generally.

PARA.TAB: Go back to 1992 and the reduction in the wholesale sales tax. It was one of a number of counter-cyclical measures, as we see them, in the One Nation economic statement that were designed to assist the Australian motor vehicle industry. It helped restore the level of sales. Look at what has happened since 1992. Between 1992 and 1994, sales rose from 406,000 to 461,000. In the first quarter of 1995, sales have continued to rise. The April figures are up 10 per cent on last year. We consider that this is reasonable evidence that the motor vehicle industry has recovered in line with the general economy.

Generally, it is important to review this kind of measure when fiscal tightening is needed to slow down the economy. Having broadly supported the general thrust of the legislation, I want to revisit an argument that Senator Coulter has been pressing for some years. We think it could be done differently. We could achieve the same outcome but in a better and different way.

Take the combination of tariffs and other measures. Since January 1992, tariffs on imported cars have fallen 10 per cent from 37.5 to 27.5 and will fall another two per cent in January to 25.5. As customs duty is added into the wholesale sales tax bill, imported cars have become about 12 per cent cheaper since 1992. In response to that, the market share falling to imported cars has risen. Last year, it rose from 40 per cent to 47.5 per cent, and it is still rising.

If the government sought to raise $330 million from cars, it could have been entirely appropriate for imported cars to take the bulk of the burden. The argument that we should be reducing tariffs to increase consumer welfare would not wear in this case; the government has decided to increase the price of cars. But the question would be whether it would be all cars or imported cars. Cancelling the 10 per cent cut in tariffs since One Nation would have raised $280 million. That is quite close to the full cost recovered in the way that the government has chosen to do it, which is via this tax rise.

We always argue that the government should use the tax system more effectually to encourage better environmental outcomes. We have often floated the idea of a sliding scale of sales tax based on fuel efficiency. The Australian Conservation Foundation has, in the past, suggested five categories ranging from the lowest taxed cars in the 6.5 litres per 100 kilometres category to the highest taxed cars in the 10 litres per 100 kilometres category. This idea has some merit. We keep raising it.

We have heard arguments backwards and forwards. It is important to keep this idea on the agenda. It would need to be phased in to allow Australian manufacturers to move towards producing more fuel efficient cars. The government should also consider the tax anomaly on four-wheel drive passenger vehicles. Four-wheel drive passenger vehicles are not very fuel efficient. Take a Mitsubishi Pajero. It operates on a fuel efficiency of 14.5 litres per 100 kilometres. This compares with a Mitsubishi Magna on 10.5 litres and a Lancer on 7.4 litres. The Lancer is almost twice as efficient as a Pajero, but it is taxed at a much higher rate than the Pajero. From 1 July, it will be taxed at the rate of 35 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't support my argument about three years ago along these lines.

—Okay. They did not accept it then. Senator Panizza should get his party to support it. We will then have the numbers to do something about it. This is because the tariff rate on four-wheel drives is 10 per cent compared with the motor vehicle rate of 27.5 per cent. The government ought to address that anomaly. It could be done by raising the sales tax on four-wheel drive passenger vehicles from 22 to 32 per cent. About $60 million would be raised by doing that. The government ought to at least consider these ideas. They show how the revenue from motor vehicles can be raised in a more environmentally friendly and economically responsible way. We think this is a second-best tax, but we will still support it.

PARA.TAB: One aspect of this that I need to raise—we raised it with the Treasurer (Mr Willis)—which is an unfortunate part of how the sales tax increases operate is that it is legislation by press release. I totally concede that it is hard to overcome it, but the impact of it is that there are hundreds of new car buyers on budget night with an unexpected new sales tax bill of $1,000 or more. Many car owners had made a contract to buy a car, but the car was yet to be delivered after the budget decision.

I asked the Treasurer to investigate this situation and to consider a proposal to exempt from the taxes motor vehicles purchased but not delivered prior to budget night. Advice from the Australian Taxation Office suggests that such an amendment would create serious difficulties. In a legal and practical sense, it would give rise to opportunities for tax evasion. I understand how backdating works, so I accept that advice. I will not be proceeding with such an amendment. But always on budget night there is a slug on a number of quite unlucky Australians who have made a decision in a whole range of areas. I wish that we could find an administrative way to cope with those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —There certainly is a number of issues. As Senator Kernot has said, it is a vexed question. Some people would say that new cars have fewer emissions than old cars. That is true; there is no doubt about it. Once again, we are now seeing the government scrambling for revenue in areas where there used to be revenue available through import duties. The measures will obviously fall hardest on any vestige of locally produced cars, although anyone who really thinks we have an Australian car industry is probably a little misguided.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that it would certainly be preferred. Given more time and staff, it would certainly have been good to fly the flag to the government, be it via a Democrats amendment or a Greens amendment—we both had the same thing in mind—that it is no longer acceptable on a major item like a car to make no distinction in relation to engine size, engine efficiency or emission levels, whichever approach is more effective. On every area that we have talked about in terms of regulation, we have been told that we cannot be prescriptive. We were told that there could not be a carbon tax. It gets down to what on earth one can do.

If the stick approach will not be taken up by government, perhaps the carrot approach will; the consumers will end up making a choice. If we do not include some sliding scale based on these kinds of social benefits and disadvantages, in the end, the community pays anyway. It is not government and generally it is not industry that pays; the community pays. It is well overdue that any decisions like a major new tax impost on cars be scaled in relation to the environmental impact of that item. The car is a major item and a major producer of pollutants, including CO2 emissions.

If Australia is going to be able to hold its head up in the future in international fora, it will have to show that it is at least taking something seriously by doing something about it. It is a notice to whichever side is in power in the future that it is now expected from society that governments play their part in areas where markets will not or cannot play their part. They need to start making changes that will impact on what we do in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another notice that should be given to the government is that the parliament, and particularly this chamber, will keep it to the undertakings that it has given to the electorate. Quite clearly, this matter has been canvassed previously. I believe that that is a function of this Senate, no matter which government is in power. In another debate on another reqest, I will be adverting to the matter again.

PARA.TAB: A number of questions have been raised about environmental factors and I will deal with them briefly. This government is proposing to squeeze another $400 million from motorists by increasing the sales tax on cars. We must remember that not long ago the government depreciated the value of hundreds of thousands of existing cars by selectively increasing the excise on leaded petrol. Now it is becoming harder for people to trade up to newer vehicles because of the increased sales tax on new vehicles. It is quite clear that once you raise the sales tax on a new vehicle you will up the price of its immediate predecessor. That makes it harder again for those who are driving leaded petrol vehicles to upgrade because they have to overcome the discriminatory burden of paying an additional amount for leaded petrol in their older cars.

If the government believed its own rhetoric on the environment it would be making it easier for people to trade-in older leaded petrol vehicles for newer family cars, but it is doing the reverse. It is making it harder for families to trade up from their older cars to newer cars which can take lead-free petrol. Fewer and fewer families can afford new cars anyway, and this is just another revenue raising measure which will flow on to affect the standard of living of ordinary families.

A particular problem with the increase in the sales tax on motor vehicles is the retrospective effect that it has on the car rental industry. I raise it as a matter that concerns me, and probably everyone else in this chamber, but I am not sure how you would overcome it. It will require wiser and more bureaucratically inclined heads than mine to attack this. I raise it here because many of the contracts for longer term hiring of cars are based on prices as they currently exist. The car rental industry will effectively be caught out with an unfair lump sum tax that it cannot pass on to consumers.

Senator Kernot and others have mentioned the situation of those people who have contracted for the purchase of new cars but have not actually paid the money. Suddenly, after budget night, they have found that the price has gone up a thousand bucks. That is another problem that needs to be looked at.

I will be supporting the request moved by Senator Gibson requesting the House of Representatives to delete that section of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Modification (Excise) Bill which has the effect of increasing the sales tax on new motor vehicles. I do so for the reasons I have just outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to support the request that has been moved by Senator Gibson in relation to the sales tax increases on motor vehicles. This is a further classical example of the way the people were deceived when the government, prior to the last election, said that they would not incur sales tax increases and would be better off with its tax regime than under any other form of taxation. That was a great fraud.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister how this government can possibly justify such an increase when our motor vehicle fleet is aging at such a rate and when the purchase of new motor vehicles is being put further out of reach of ordinary Australians. Why are you not encouraging people to buy unleaded vehicles? You are consistently increasing the tax on leaded fuel, making the older cars more expensive to run. Nothing you are doing is friendly to the environment—and this is just the thin edge of the wedge.

Will the minister explain why there have been so many other sales tax increases from a government that, prior to the 1993 election, promised no increases in sales tax. So many things have already gone up or are about to go up on Saturday. One would have thought that prior to the last election we had no sales tax whatsoever on food but, as of Saturday, there will be 12 per cent on biscuits, cordial, ice cream, confectionary, savoury snacks, flavoured milk, fruit and vegetable juices, and so on. This from a government that said there is no tax on food!

Then there are the increases in the fuel excise and the motor vehicle sales taxes. They all add to the cost of these particular products. At a time when any sensible, sane, responsible government would be encouraging people to consume low alcohol wine, you put up the tax on it. On Saturday the tax on low alcohol wine and cider goes up to 14 per cent. You deceived the people prior to the last election about everyday products—cars being but one of them. How about the everyday products that from Saturday will be taxed at the rate of 22 per cent: toilet paper, soap, ballpoint pens, writing paper, cosmetics, toothpaste, shampoo, detergent, batteries, soft drinks and disinfectants? The list goes on. These are things that people use every day of the week.

Prior to the last election the government was saying there would be no increase in sales tax. We now have a 22 per cent flow-on; the fuel excise and everything else flows on through. Ordinary wine and cider you are putting up to 26 per cent. Then there are things such as watches and clocks, binoculars, cameras, video recorders, radios and televisions, costume jewellery, and so forth, which will be at 32 per cent. I might add that this does not include antique clocks, nor do the food items include something like caviar, but they do include orange juice and flavoured milk. Is that not extraordinary from a government that told people they would be so much worse off with a one tax rate that scrubbed out seven others? Here we have six taxes being retained while the other one has been increased time and time again since the 1993 election.

How can you honestly justify that to the Australian people? It is a most monumental deception when we consider that families are going to be taxed 22 per cent for pet food, tents, tarpaulins, car covers, household insecticides, polishes, glues, starches, lawn mowers, travel wear, handbags—all the sorts of things that I would not consider luxuries. I would not consider that a hairbrush is a luxury. You are whacking the tax up to 22 per cent on a hairbrush, a toilet bag, toys, games, amusements, umbrellas, musical instruments, oils, and lubricants. You are putting the tax up on everything you can think of. You are coming from a position of saying that there will be no tax increases.

It is about time that you explained to the people of Australia why you deceived them at the last election and why you are doing it again in this budget. Clearly you are making a mockery of any election promise. You had no intention whatever of keeping that promise. You knew it at the time, we knew it at the time, but sadly the Australian people—many of whom voted for you—believed you. Here you go with taxes on luxury motor vehicles. Who terms something a luxury?

Large vans fall into that price category and they are not luxuries; they are a necessity. Families need to be able to go out and buy a larger vehicle to take their families out in one hit. But you never seem to care about that. Car tax is but one section of a million-section budget where everything has just gone up. At some stage the government needs to be responsible for that deception of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clauses before the Senate this evening relating to increases in sales tax, particularly in relation to vehicles, display very vividly the great deception by the Australian Labor Party towards the Australian people. I remind the Senate that during the GST debate prior to the last election there were a number of sensitive issues. One issue was sales tax on cars. There was a possibility that under a GST regime people would be getting their cars a lot cheaper. The Labor Party, somewhat fearful of this, fairly cynically decided, `In order to beat them we will have to reduce the sales rate from 20 per cent to 5 per cent'. The Labor Party did reduce the rate to 15 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In order to get the business vote the Labor Party decided to reduce the corporate rate of tax from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. There are other measures, but I think these two stand out on their own as a vivid illustration of the length to which the Labor Party will go to deceive the Australian people in order to achieve power. The rates were only brought down for expediency. They were brought down temporarily. The Australian Labor Party did not tell the electorate that the reductions in company tax and sales tax on cars were only short-term measures. In fact, everybody thought that the rates were going to be reduced for the long term.

But having won the election, a budget or so later the Labor Party decided that it needed more revenue. So the corporate rate rose and the motor vehicle rate went up from 16 per cent to 21 per cent, and it will increase to 22 per cent from 1 July. The Australian people deserve better treatment and a greater degree of honesty from this government.

I think it is pretty poor when the government says to us, `If you destroy our budget you will be responsible for increases in interest rates'. I remind the minister that the government has not pegged back sufficiently the gap between the ratio of GDP to savings and investment.

Undoubtedly, there might have been a few minor reforms to narrow the gap. Savings raised 1.5 per cent, but despite these initiatives a gap of five to six per cent still remains, which is rather frightening. The lack of commitment will come home ultimately to haunt Australia—if not in the immediate future, certainly by the end of the century. Unless governments do something a lot stronger to bridge the savings dilemma, the dollar exchange rate will continue to fall. The dollar cannot improve in the environment that the government has created. The government has not done enough.

These indirect taxes are a deceit by the Australian Labor Party to try to retain government. To raise revenue under these circumstances is most reprehensible. The government has not done enough to increase savings. True there are some indicators—e.g., 1.5 per cent for superannuation. The government still have to bridge this big savings gap completely, otherwise it will result in increased pressure on the Australian dollar.

Money is flowing out of this country at a time when it should be remaining here. The pressure is on the government for action. The government has to deliver on fiscal and monetary fronts. Our standards of living are going down—everybody who goes overseas realises this when spending on necessities—in terms of their purchasing power in the countries they visit.
I leave it to you, Minister. Australians are entitled to something a lot better than you are dishing up at the present time.
Question put:
That the request for amendments (Senator Gibson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In relation to each of the bills, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Schedule 2, page 9, 1 to ll, omit the items.

This request relates to the sales tax on building materials. As I said earlier, the coalition has opposed the revenue increasing measures for both motor cars and building materials. We are not opposing the other measures in the bills, which do increase revenue somewhat. We are opposing those two measures because the government, prior to the 1993 election, said that it would not increase taxes. That is our position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This request for amendments by the coalition is identical in intent to those proposed by the Democrats. I want to revisit a couple of the arguments I made in the second reading debate, because I think our rationale for opposing the extension of the sales tax on building materials is an important one, and I gave three major reasons.

PARA.TAB: The first reason is, we believe, that the extension of the sales tax in this way is a breach of an election commitment by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) not to tax housing. I gave specific quotations in the second reading debate. The second reason places a tax on shelter, which we still consider a necessity of life. The third reason is that the timing of the tax is particularly inappropriate, in our view.

I would also point out to the government that people have not accepted the argument that this is a one-off cost of about $400 because, in fact, it is a cost which trebles over the life of a mortgage. The very fact that it is added on to the total cost and continues over the life of the mortgage means that it probably amounts to something like $3,000 on the life of an average mortgage. I think that is a substantial cost to be considered.

I think there are other reasons why we should also oppose this building materials sales tax extension in the context of other things which have happened to make housing less affordable for young families, and I will quickly run through those. We have the highest interest rates in the Western world, up by 2.75 per cent in the last year. With banks, deposit requirements were tightened last year by the Reserve Bank in a belief, which, I think, was later proven to be wrong, that housing lending had not yet peaked.

On the matter of banking competition, we have a home lending market that clearly is not competitive, where the banks have been able to resist passing on a one per cent fall in wholesale interest rates since January. This affects about 90 per cent of their customers who actually have variable rate mortgages.

If you look at the other option, public housing, you will see a cut in real terms of over $100 million over the last two budgets. All of these things together, I think, make it much harder for young families to move into a new home. Rents are rising in Sydney and Melbourne. To a lesser extent in Perth and Brisbane, there is a shrinking rental vacancy.

Over the last two weeks I have been able to table petitions signed by 21,342 people objecting to this tax. That might not seem a lot to you, but I think it is a lot in one week. I can assure you they are still pouring in.

I want to address another aspect of the government's rhetoric on this matter. It says, `One of the main reasons we have to do this is that we are just fixing up some anomalies.' We say, from experience, `Beware the grip of the creeping anomaly.' Go back to 1988, when the government extended the sales tax to bathroom fittings. It said, `We're only fixing an anomaly.' I do not think it is really clear to this date what that anomaly was. The opposition, mind you, voted for that at the time. In 1988 it was okay to vote for that sales tax extension, but in 1995 it is not. I am glad you are saying it is not, but I wonder why it was in 1988.

In this particular budget, it is anomalous that the bathroom is taxed and the kitchen is not. There are a couple of options there. You could stop taxing the bathroom but, no, the tax office view of the world with respect to fixing anomalies is to keep taxing more things. It is clear, I think, that the shrinking list of items that are tax exempt would be very shortly caught up, probably when the election is nicely out of the way.

I also think you can see evidence that this bill actually creates a whole lot of lovely new anomalies for the tax office to address next year or the year after that, when the government says, `Excuse me, we've got to extend it a little bit further because we have to fix up a few more anomalies.'

Let us take kitchen cupboards, for example. If they are prefabricated, they would be taxed. If the builder builds the kitchen on site—and builders argue that that is a less efficient use of resources—they are not taxed. Nails would be taxed, but the wood they are hammered into would not be. Floor and wall tiles would be taxed, but roof tiles would not be. Light fittings would be taxed, but electrical fittings would not be. Taps and nozzles would be taxed, but the pipes they are attached to would not be. Eventually all of that will be brought under the sales tax net—a total haul of $2 billion plus—bit by bit and anomaly by anomaly.

Today the Democrats continue to say that housing should continue to be exempt. For all of the same reasons that the current Treasurer, Ralph Willis, gave in opposing this very tax in 1981 and for all of the reasons that Prime Minister Keating gave in opposing a GST on housing in 1993, we still believe buildings should not be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the request moved by Senator Gibson for the House of Representatives to amend the legislation so as to exclude the tax on building materials. It has been indicated that the tax on an average house would be as low as $600 and as high as $1,000.
—That would have to be a pretty good house.
—Only a $180,000 home.

—Whatever it is, it is too much. I note that in this document on Australia's future, Poles Apart—the Labor Party's official critique of the GST—the opposition was criticised for proposing increased taxation on housing. I agree with the government's view in 1993 that housing should not be taxed because housing is a necessity of life. It has long been a very valid principle that necessities of life should not be taxed. Unfortunately, that principle is being eroded time and again both directly and, might I say, indirectly as well.

PARA.TAB: We could look at the failure of governments to maintain dependent spouse rebates and so on and in refusing to set thresholds for each dependent child, whereby the income earner is not taxed for those thresholds. The fact that there are certain amounts of money required for necessities of life for dependants shows that the government is not living up to the principle that has been the ideal principle and should now be the ideal principle that the necessities of life should not be taxed.

Much has been said about what the government promised in the last election. On this particular occasion the Senate ought to hold the government to its promise that was given to the people of Australia in 1993. I have heard what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been saying. I had a bit of a chuckle because, looking around at the senators who are currently in the chamber, there is only one who was present in 1981—that is, Senator Jones. In the 1981 budget, the then coalition government proposed a 2 1/2 per cent tax on a wide range of consumer items which were previously exempt, together with an increase in the sales tax levy. Lo and behold, one of those related to building materials for the construction of private dwellings. I remind the Senate that the Australian Labor Party and I voted against that. At the time the Labor Party had no problems about voting against that measure.

Somebody said that the Prime Minister was cynical and hypocritical. As we get on, we forget things. My memory was jogged on this, and the Prime Minister probably forgot about that. That is a bit unfortunate because he has since been reminded of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Willis couldn't have forgotten about it. He was the shadow Treasurer and now he is the Treasurer.

—He might have forgotten about it too. To cut a long story short, there was no problem at that time in opposing such a measure. I feel that we should not have a bucket tipped on us for opposing it on the grounds that we are traducing democratic principles and all this sort of nonsense. Let us look at it face to face. I strongly feel that necessities of life should not be taxed. I believe that shelter happens to be one of those necessities of life, and building materials fall into that particular category. To propose an increased tax on building materials presents me with a problem and should present the government with a problem because of its undertaking not to increase taxes. In short, I will be supporting the amendment which has been moved by Senator Gibson.

—Listeners to this debate might recall that the coalition lost the 1993 election after proposing a large shift in tax from the direct to a uniform indirect GST. This was perhaps the greatest reform ever put before the Australian people. In a sense, the Australian people rejected that change. Perhaps one of the focal points of attack by the Labor Party at that time was the impact it was going to have on building and homes. Two budgets away and the government has walked away from its election promise not to widen the sales tax base. The government has not only walked away from its election commitment but also miscalculated in a very significant manner the cost impact on building a home of the sales tax impost on building materials. The estimates in the budget papers were only half of what all the reputable people in the industry were saying and what Mr Willis now concedes is a more correct figure, that is, that it will add at least $1,000 to the cost of building a family home.

PARA.TAB: There are going to be a lot of problems associated with this tax. Allow me a few minutes to enumerate some of these difficulties. The changes will, to a large extent, affect people who are not used to dealing with sales tax and who do not have the systems in place to cope with it. Also, there will be a number of transitional problems in determining what transactions are subject to sales tax and who, as a matter of commercial reality, bears the brunt of the tax on contracts entered into—but not completed—prior to the changes.

In the long term, the problem revolves around what I term the classification issue. That is a major headache for anyone in the sales tax area. For example, the classification of non-timber benchtops is unclear. The Australian Taxation Office seems to be accepting that they might be taxed at 12 per cent but, arguably, they could be exempt as architectural building units or even taxable at 22 per cent, as they are not covered in any other schedule in the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Act.

While the tax office seems to be interpreting the provisions to make them administrably easy for taxpayers to deal with, the result could be l-o-r-e rather than l-a-w. The industry may well end up being segmentalised. There is concern that the big players in the industry may be disadvantaged because of their overheads structure. From a revenue perspective, it is difficult to know what difference the proposed changes will make, because it depends on economic activity and the interpretation of the provisions by both the Australian Taxation Office and the courts.

I am very concerned that in my home state the level of building activity has really slumped. When I read the mainland press I find that activity in the big Jennings home group is down by about 30 per cent. On top of this drop in economic activity, particularly in the building area, the government decides it is timely to impose a new tax and also to tell the Australian people that the tax is only about half what it really is going to be. That is pretty reprehensible. The government has not thought out the consequences, it has broken election promises and it is going to cause a lot of difficulties for people in this area.

The minister and other honourable senators will recall a contribution I made here earlier in which I said that the people who will be particularly disadvantaged will be the joinery workshops. I am concerned about the impact it will have in my home state and the shift it will cause towards what I call a cash economy. The small builder without overheads and without a joinery factory will build the cupboards, and as much of the construction work as he possibly can in the home with the explanation that, `This is an installation cost,' because installation costs, apart from material components, will not be subject to sales tax. However, the work in the joinery has a material component, plus labour and overhead components—to which a margin is added. In effect, the tax is going to make this whole area of activity quite uneconomic and, to avoid the impost of this tax and to keep the cost down, the pattern of how work is done will change from the joinery workshop to the home site.

There are also problems with classifications. For example, the benchtop, the bathroom vanity unit, the kitchen sink and all these other sorts of items are now going to be subject to sales tax and will require a lot of new people—who have not been involved with sales tax—to register for the very first time. Therefore, initially there will be confusion, particularly for those people who have contracted at a contract price to build or to renovate. Builders will not have built in these sorts of costs in the contract price. There is also going to be disputation about such items as slate tiles. For example, a slate tile that is greater than eight millimetres in average thickness and is normally used as a floor tile is taxable at 12 per cent, whereas a slate tile less than 8 millimetres is usually used as a roof tile and is sales tax exempt.

The industry is going to have to put up with all these classification sorts of difficulties. There is also the question of timber floor coverings, including parquetry blocks, which will be taxed at 12 per cent after 1 July 1995. However, polishes, mop oils, paints and other coatings in liquid paste or powder form—if they are not of a kind marketed principally for application to buildings or fixtures—pigments, thinners and dryers will be unchanged and taxed at 21 per cent, rising to 22 per cent on 1 July 1995, whereas glues and grouts for tiles, fibreglass and liquid sealing and bonding agents for application to building or fixtures, silicon based bonding, setting and sealing products, taps, nozzles, tap handles, shower heads, arms, brackets, rails and flexible hoses for showers will become taxable at 12 per cent. It is not surprising that the government did not realise the scope of the tax on building hardware.

What does worry me is that the tax will extend to what I will term child safety features and latches, which for the first time will come under this building hardware sales tax provision. I believe it is a reprehensible imposition and quite inappropriate. When one looks at the sorts of building materials involved, one sees it is not going to be easy to determine whether they will be exempt because, obviously, a lot of items are still exempt—such as metal roofing and skylights—whereas door handles, hardware, light fittings, ovens, hotplates and hot water services will be taxed at 12 per cent.

Then there are other items, such as spa baths, timber, free standing fences, scaffolding and so on, that will be taxed at 22 per cent. It is not going to be easy for those in the trade to determine the classification involved in such a tax grabbing exercise, an exercise which I believe is very cynical. It is a deception and, effectively, the Australian people were cheated at the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —The request we are being asked to support has merits. The Greens WA are inclined to support it. The issues are many, as has been mentioned by previous speakers. It is true that some small businesses have never had to collect sales tax before. If you are in a small business, it is an extreme time impost; and there is a cost involved.

PARA.TAB: A committee was looking into the impact of our taxation system on Australian small business. It makes us wonder when that sort of committee is looking into those impacts and what is going wrong. With more and more individuals and small businesses being required to do the job of the tax office, why is there a change that has exactly the opposite effect? It requires more small businesses—they are not all small businesses, but quite a number, including joiners, fit in that category; and they would not normally have been required to collect sales tax—to collect sales tax.

Why is the government taking a direction that will require more and more people to use unproductive time to do the job of the tax office? It does not make sense. It also leads inextricably to the fact that the kinds of problems mentioned by Senator Watson of delineation between what is and is not taxable over each period—and what stock is included—inevitably will lead to an anomaly being considered. At some stage it will be said, `There are areas that are not currently covered by the tax and, because there is a confusion about what is and is not taxable, we might as well put the rest in, just to make it simpler: there being an anomaly.'

The reality is that it is GST by stealth, and that is a problem. This is not totally in line with the tax situation, but Australia is a very indebted country. Each person in Australia has a very high level of personal debt, and a very large portion of that personal debt is related to housing. Instead of schemes to suddenly artificially boost this by a private superannuation scheme, which is fraught with difficulties as it stands, it is important that government look at ways of assisting people through various schemes, incentives and so on to simplify housing plans.

The market says that a new house even for a first home buyer should have three or four bedrooms, a study, an en suite, a family room, a formal dining room and so on. The reality is that the people on the smallest income try to get those as well and end up with poor quality housing. If this scheme goes through, such people will end up with tiles that you can see through, which will not last very long and which will end up costing them more in the long run, and houses with no floor coverings and so on. The reality is that what we should be doing as a nation is looking at incentives to encourage the industry and consumers to look towards meeting their needs in a way that does not impose this huge cost to the environment and other areas. This probably needs a rethinking of how we use tax incentives.

Perhaps the government's own housing program can look at this issue. I have seen government housing in Broome, where people got together and helped design their own houses. For the same price as normal government houses, they included a very reasonable sized living area which everybody in the house used, the number of bedrooms that were needed plus a work area for those people with hobbies. Studies have been carried out that show the majority of most houses in Australia, especially the new design houses, is hardly ever used. We are creating a culture of excess in terms of housing and housing expectations. Therefore, when people are first married and set up a house they get into huge debt. Maybe part of the problem is the excessive consumer ethic that is around. Maybe governments have a role to play in taxation in leading the way in terms of their own housing programs.

This particular measure by the government in simply slapping a tax on the basic materials for building a house will not help this particular housing debt problem that we see at the moment. Over time, perhaps what is needed is a very concerted program to help people find that the quality of life is not associated with the number of rooms, no matter how often they are used, and that community housing and other methods can solve housing problems and work to solve environmental problems as well. This is what we need to do in terms of the choice of housing in the future. That is only vaguely associated with this particular measure, but it is associated with the quality of life. A lot of people have two jobs in order to support their mortgages. We will not be supporting the government's proposal to increase tax on building materials at this stage. In the future we will certainly be looking at ways that governments in general can look at schemes that enable people to look at their consumption levels regarding housing choices and look for environmental solutions. That is something that we will flag for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know this is a second bite of the cherry, and I apologise to the chamber. I want to raise an issue and hopefully get a response from the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens. There are a number of people in the building supply industry—for example, people who supply paints, wallpaper, thinners and builders hardware—who have orders for materials to be supplied after 1 July. Let us say that the Senate rejects the government's propositions and sends back the bill with a request. In effect, we are really rejecting the sales tax impost. What if the government then brings back the legislation not this week but in September?
—In three months time.

—In three months time, for example. Am I to understand that the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens intend to maintain their opposition to this measure? This is a very difficult question. If you are a wholesaler, will you collect tax just in case there is a change of mind by the Senate on this particular matter? I would like to know, for the sake of certainty, whether or not the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens will continue their opposition to this particular measure as it would apply from 1 July or, retrospectively, if it came back to us at a later stage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly indicate that the Democrats will not be changing their minds. They have not done so in the last 14 years, and we do not intend to on this matter. It is an important question that Senator Harradine raised. I can think of two examples where a matter has come back from the House of Representatives recently and the opposition has changed its mind.
—Have you ever changed your mind?

—I do not think we have. We make sure we get it right the first time around. The opposition changed its mind on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 and on the Aboriginal land fund bill. Those are two contemporary examples. It would be good to hear from the opposition on this matter.
—The opposition has made it plain since the 1993 election that we will oppose any tax increases of a general nature. That has been the consistent policy since then, and we will stand by that policy.
—All the way through the process?
—Yes.

—If the bill gets knocked out, could the government direct wholesalers to collect the tax? If they had not, the ordinary punter who came in between now and whenever the bill came back—and if it did get turned around—will not have paid the tax. Therefore, the government would have to change the start-up date, which would make it a different bill. Is that not the case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also implied in Senator Harradine's questioning was contracts prior to 1 July 1995. I have a bulletin from the Australian Taxation Office.
—You have every single one that was ever printed.

—I do have a collection, yes. I think it shows the lack of concern from the Taxation Office and the government towards people when they are implementing tax changes, particularly tax changes giving such short notice. The Taxation Office bulletin states:

SPEECH.PARA: Contracts entered into prior to 1 July 1995 may have the price altered to include the sales tax increase unless the contract has expressly written provisions to the contrary or it is clear from the contract that the alteration of sales tax has been taken into account in the agreed contract price.

That is not much consolation for the Australian people who are engaged in home building. I remind Senator Harradine that his concern is not only a problem with sales tax. On Friday, the Senate will rise without having considered a number of income tax bills. Some of those income tax bills relate to changes which will occur from 1 July 1994. Will people be expected to prepare their income tax returns on a basis for which there is no legislative mandate, as the bills have not been debated and passed by the Senate? This is quite reprehensible. If a number of the issues in these bills are not passed or are modified, taxpayers will be put to the expense of having to lodge amended income tax returns.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party has really lost control of the taxation debate in Australia. It has organised its timetable to push all the tax bills right at the end of the session. Some of those bills will not be addressed this session. Some bills, as Senator Harradine said, may be returned to the Senate in a modified form. Therefore, the Senate will rise on 30 June and there will be a high degree of uncertainty on the part of the Australian people in terms of their current year tax obligations. I put it to you, Madam Temporary Chairman, that it is just not good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the debate this afternoon, I have not been convinced by the government or by what has been said during the committee stage. Senator Cook has not given any replies while I have been present as to his underestimation of the claim by the coalition of a $1,200 increase in the price of a median house costing $95,000. He has not debunked the calculations by the building surveyor from North Queensland, who calculated that the figure would be much higher than that. I would also like Senator Cook to answer whether, when the government was putting together this sales tax on building materials, it took into calculation the effect of the diesel fuel rebate not being rebatable for the mining of clay for bricks and also for diesel fuel used in firing brick kilns. I said in my speech during the second reading debate that the two aspects, taken together, would mean that an average double brick house in Western Australia would cost at least another $2,500. I have not heard any argument that that is not correct.
—We have had some research that that is not correct. The housing industry has got back to us.

—Much as I do sometimes take note of what you say in here, in this case I have advice from the brick manufacturers of Western Australia, who do their homework pretty well. It may be that mining clay in some areas of Australia is more difficult and costly than in other places. If Senator Kernot believes that that figure is not right, there must be a figure. It is a compounding figure; it must be there. On top of that you have to add your builder's margin.

PARA.TAB: The government has not given any reason whatsoever why our figures are wrong, even though Senator Ian Macdonald quoted figures supplied by a building surveyor. I said this afternoon that a building surveyor who is worth his salt has to be accurate within two per cent. A building surveyor does the quantity surveying so the builder does not have to do it himself, and then quotes on that basis. Sometimes a surveyor will do quantity surveying for more than one builder. If three builders quote for a job and they all had the same quantity surveyor, it should be fair across the board.

But it does not always happen that way, particularly with small buildings. Senator Jones was a builder previously, so he would know what I am talking about. There are different quantity surveyors, so each one has to be pretty spot on. Not only might they not get the next job, but also they could be sued by the builder that they are working for. They have to work in a very tight margin. They have to be very accurate. That is why it costs a lot of money to employ these people. I cannot see why we cannot take note of the one building surveyor who did give us an opinion. The government has not answered that one bit.

Senator Cook asked me the other day at a legislative committee: `If I give you all those answers will I convince you to vote for the bill?' I told him that I listen to all debating points that he and others give me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You told me you would not vote for it.

—I did not say that. I will tell you what I said. I said I always debate matters vigorously in my own party room and when the majority decision comes down I adhere to that decision, just like you do in caucus. When you get rolled in caucus you have to go along with it. I do not know how often you get rolled but you must do so now and again. You go along with it, just like I will go along with it. You have not given me any material or figures as to why I should have gone any further on this matter in the party room.

PARA.TAB: Let us get back to what you call past history. I do not call it past history because it was only 2 1/2 years ago that you were saying that the GST would have added $2,000 to $3,000. I came up with the figure of $3,500 which would be added by your proposal regarding the diesel fuel rebate levy on manufacturing bricks and mining clay. I said $4,500 in the second reading debate but I have amended that figure. Your proposal will be far beyond the GST estimate. We are back in a situation where you slammed us 2 1/2 years ago on what it would do to the cost of building.

Senator Cook told me the other day that housing affordability has never been better than it is at present. If that is the case, why is the vacancy rate so far down? If the affordability is there, the vacancy rate goes up because young people go out and buy their own homes. But that has not happened. They have no confidence in the economy of Australia and they are not confident that interest rates will not blow out. Maybe that is the reason, but the government has not debunked any of our theories; it has never given us any answers on it. I am not going to use the term `lied' to the Australian people on this occasion; I am just saying that the government told the Australian people and the Australian people obviously believed it because about 1,252 more of them voted for your side of politics than ours. That must have had a big bearing on those 1,252-odd voters, which was the difference between whether or not we won government.

They must have taken a lot of notice. Having said that two and a half years ago, how can you even look at yourself in the mirror in the morning? And, Madam Temporary Chairman, that is quite a valid question under the standing orders. Then there were the promises of no new taxes. I do not know how you gave the excuse the other day that housing affordability has never been higher so you would grab the opportunity to tax people further.

Senator Margetts referred to ordinary floor tiles. I do not think anyone would dispute that this is the first time tiles have been subjected to a sales tax. We heard evidence from the tile manufacturers of Australia that this sales tax will increase the cost of a house. However, I would like to be told whether that is counted in the $1,200 increase in the price of an average house because, normally, tiles are something extra that you put down yourself after the house is finished. My experience of house building and property development has told me that.

Senator Margetts pointed out that this will probably lead to unfinished houses. Anyone wanting to build their dream home gets the structure up and lives without a few of the nice finishes like catches on the cupboards and so on. They will quite likely leave the tiles out and make do with other things to get to the position one day when they can afford them.

I heard Senator Cook, somewhere along the line, say today that Australia is aiming for increased employment by cutting unemployment. This afternoon, I submitted two charts for incorporation in Hansard. Those charts definitely show what this sales tax will do to kick the cyclical situation of house building. House building rises and falls. History shows that when you cop a sudden rise in something, whether it be bricks, transport, the imposition of sales tax or anything else, building activity takes a dive. It is already on its way down at the present moment, so this increase will accentuate that fall. This will cause more unemployment. The government has not refuted that whatsoever.

These charts were prepared by the Housing Industry Association and the Master Builders Association and I know the HIA is not flavour of the month with the government. The government has not answered any of those points, yet they expect us to pass this measure which, on their figures, will raise an extra $249 million in a full year when we know full well that it will raise a minimum of around $650 million extra.

Looking at the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, the government brought in all of those taxes telling you that they would not raise very much and that they would be at the very lower end of the scale. Over the years everything has blown out. That has been the history of this government.

It is not only affluent people who build houses. When people talk about houses, they talk about these luxury houses that are being built. In remote areas it costs people twice as much to build a house. Going into the far regions, 500 or 600 kilometres from a capital city means that you have to double the median price of a house in the capital city. I know that from bitter experience. So what will this sales tax do to regional Australia?
If the government had any sense, even at this stage, it would think twice before proceeding with this measure to impose a sales tax on building materials.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, once again, we see an administrative `mistake'—the inevitable governmental administrative mess-up.

PARA.TAB: Here in the advance to the Minister for Finance we see that the government failed, due to an administrative oversight, to make a provision in either Appropriation Act (No. 2) 1994-95 or Appropriation Act (No. 4) 1994-95 for payments to be made during the 1994-95 financial year under the Supported Accommodation Assistance Act 1994.

A matter of no significance? Well, it is only $12.77 million! They forgot about it! They did not realise they had actually to pass a law to pay it. This is just another example of this government's crass incompetence. The ministers have been there too long and have been too fat—one cannot be sizeist—just too lazy to know what on earth they are doing.

It follows, of course, the previous situation where I think Senator McMullan, who is in the chamber, had a little problem with the export market development grants. They forgot about the fact that parliamentary action had to take place.

We have Senator Cook with his research and development grants. Actually, they were paying those illegally because they failed to table the appropriate documents. Fail, fail, fail! They do not know what they are doing.

In the latest lot this mistake, this error, this incompetence, has been rescued. This mistake by the then Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe) has been corrected because there has been an application for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance to cover the mistake.

We can understand why the minister would make a mistake. After all, he was the Deputy Prime Minister and he has been so busy protecting his back for the last year or so that doing things like this administratively are a bit beyond him—making certain that $12.8 million is properly made available for supported accommodation assistance.

To help him in his arduous tasks, he has had the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Ms Crawford) to help him. She has been busy trying to protect herself in the seat that the Labor Party has left her in. I understand it is next to unwinnable. She is still on the list of Labor candidates so that the Labor Party can meet its targeted quota, which it is missing anyway, for the number of women in parliament. After redistribution, her seat has changed its character dramatically and she sought to move, unsuccessfully, to another seat. She has obviously been too busy protecting her political life to get involved in looking after the law.

This failure to provide the money is quite an important matter because the object of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Act is to grant financial assistance to the states to administer the supported accommodation assistance program, which is to be implemented principally through common form agreements between the Commonwealth and the states. It received royal assent on 16 December 1994, and the state of Victoria signed the agreement in May 1995. By the agreement itself, it was deemed to have come into force on 16 December 1994. The agreement committed the Commonwealth to provide financial assistance to the state for the financial year for the purpose of meeting the reimbursement expenditure. It is now urgent because of the error. In signing the agreement, the Commonwealth committed itself to the provision of this money. But there is no provision for payments under Appropriation Act (No.2) or Appropriation Act (No. 4). So the necessary amount is required from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. This is just another example of monumental incompetence. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (EXCISE) BILL 1995SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (CUSTOMS) BILL 1995SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (GENERAL) BILL 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to give a few more examples of the nightmares that these bills will cause within the trade. I refer firstly to administration. A nightmare will be caused for those building operatives working on government projects, which are exempt, and those working on private sector projects which will be subject to sales tax. Builders will have to distinguish between the nails and the screws for exempt and non-exempt buildings. Also, the plaster fittings but not the rosettes or the plasterboard will be subject to tax if sold to the private sector. For the larger builders, a storage classification difficulty will be incurred in determining where builders segment their nails and all these materials for government projects, which are exempt, and those for the private sector, which are not exempt. In times of the private sector trying to be more efficient and trying to keep our costs down, this government tax is not the right way to go.

PARA.TAB: There will also be a problem for small shops. A number of them will bypass selling kitchen and bathroom requirements because they simply will not want to get caught up in the sales tax system. Further, merchants will not want to give a breakdown of their sales tax to builders as it could discount their buying price.

One thing that concerned me during the earlier debate was that at least one or two senators on the Labor Party side believed that this hardware tax was not going to have a flow-on effect into labour costs and factory service costs. I will quote again from the tax office bulletin. In manufacturing cabinets, the tax is applied to total manufacturing costs—plus, a margin. With regard to the manufacturing cost, it is true that sales tax is not applied to installation. This is where the black economy will come in, because there will be all sorts of underhand shuffling by some shifty builders to try to call joinery related costs on the job installation costs rather than the costs of manufacture.

The tax office bulletin further states that manufacturing cost refers to the `cost of manufacturing', which is calculated on the basis of full absorption costing. That has three elements: labour, materials and factory service costs.

The bulletin further gives an example. If a cabinet-maker or a joiner produces a kitchen at a fully absorbed manufactured cost of $10,000 and sells the kitchen to a builder for $13,000, without installation charges or tax, then the taxable value will be $10,000—the total manufactured cost—plus one-third of $13,000, which is the selling price, minus his cost of $10,000, which equals $1,000. Therefore, the notional wholesale selling price for joinery would cost $11,000—that is, $10,000 for the manufacturing cost, plus the notional wholesale margin of $1,000.

Earlier, I mentioned that there is a problem concerning the thickness of the tile, which is important in determining whether the tile is going to be taxed at 12 per cent or exempt. For example, those tiles which are less than eight millimetres—an average thickness which is commercially regarded as roof tiles—are exempt from tax simply because of their particular size.

If we look at slabs of stone, there are further size complications. One must be particularly careful in measuring the slab of stone to determine whether it is going to be subject to tax or whether it is going to be exempt from tax. For example, slabs of stone of 10 millimetres or less—an average thickness and normally for tiling purposes—are taxable at the rate of 12 per cent. But slabs of stone in excess of 10 millimetres, which are not commercially regarded as tiles, are exempt from tax because they are regarded by the tax office as structural or architectural building units. Senators could just go on and on giving examples of difficulties that will be incurred within the trade as a result of this unnecessary and untimely tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson is always extremely useful in bringing out the detail in these debates. I was reminded while he was speaking that in this budget and over several budgets we have seen the government move away from a diesel fuel rebate system because of the conflict that arises between fuel which is held by an operator who has both on-road vehicles and off-road vehicles and the possibility that the person could use the on-road vehicles but use fuel on which a tax had not been paid or for which a rebate was claimed. Because of that anomaly, the government is choosing to move in a different direction.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson has put his finger on precisely the same anomaly that the government is now going into with respect to a simple thing like nails. The reason I have risen is that the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) is not responding to any of these important points which are being made. The question is quite simple. This comes out of what Senator Watson has just said. If a builder is working on two buildings and has nails and screws which are tax exempt on one building and nails and screws on which tax is paid on the other, how will the government be sure that those nails and screws do not get mixed up? I would like an answer from the minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) has not replied to anything said this evening. I was going to address a couple of other points about building surveyor Mike Corrigan, who is from North Queensland, but Senator Ian Macdonald is here, so he might like to further that matter.

PARA.TAB: I want to speak further about something that came out of a legislation committee hearing last Friday. I asked about the effect of this housing downturn on employment in Australia, even if these extra sales taxes were not implemented. This is what I discovered in a letter from the HIA:

SPEECH.PARA: The Indicative Planning Council has forecast dwelling starts will fall from 178,000 in 1993-94 to around 130,000 in 1995-96, a reduction of 48,000.
We estimate that the full year impact of this decline, from an economy wide perspective, to be in the order of
.job losses of about 72,000.
This is what will happen even before the imposition of this sales tax; there will be job losses of 72,000. A minister like Senator Cook should be interested in this. It continues:
split equally—
I have said before that a multiplier of two in the work force, including those involved in the supply of materials, applies—
between housing and the rest of the economy;
. loss in income and company tax of around $400m;
. losses in commodity taxes (sales tax, fuel levies) and indirect taxes (payroll, fringe benefits, land tax and stamp duty) of about $220m;

On top of that, having hosed down the industry and demand for housing, there are other losses. Perhaps those losses are to the state government, so this government and this minister are not interested. But there will be a loss of stamp duty on associated property transfers. The rates charged vary between different states. All up, the HIA estimates that loss to be around $75 million. These sorts of imposts will apply to the building industry in Australia, irrespective of the imposition of the increased sales tax.

PARA.TAB: I will now consider the government's estimation of the $249 million that it will raise. I have a letter from Hettich International which came out of the inquiry we had last Friday. I will read part of it into Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: Following our conversation earlier this morning I confirm in writing that there is every indication and our firm belief that the proposed sales tax impost on housing/hardware will be far greater than stated in the budget papers.

I do not know how far the government inquired into the effects of this when it drew up the budget papers, but going on the non-answers we received from the Treasury representatives that attended with Senator Cook last Friday, I am not surprised at them. The letter continues:
In fact the stated figure of $215 million—
that is, in 1995-96—
will be exceeded by the tax on kitchens alone—aside from all other items now to be included.

It explains that statement by listing items that are included in renovations. Renovations have not been addressed too much in this debate. Those who cannot afford a new house or renters who cannot afford to buy a house are affected by renovations. From my experience, renovations are carried out far more in rental properties than in houses that are owner occupied.

PARA.TAB: One could say that renovation is the landlord's job so it need not be worried about. But the landlord does not stand in the place of social security; he or she will invest in rental property that will be paid for in rent by tenants. From my knowledge, investment in rental properties in Australia is certainly declining. I heard Mr Howe say the other day—this is a side issue—that there should be a federal law to cover all renting in Australia. The federal government would apply certain conditions, et cetera. If federal government gets into that sort of thing, I do not know what will happen. The fact is that renovations paid for by landlords have to be added on to the rent. There are no two ways about it. So it affects low income earners.

I will read the list of items included in renovations in this letter. In 1987, cupboards were involved in 83 per cent of renovations. In 1994, they were involved in 68 per cent of renovations. In 1994, bench tops were included in 65 per cent of renovations; sinks and taps were 47 per cent; electric range ovens were 34 per cent—they are not really subject to this legislation—gas range ovens were 17 per cent; rangehoods were 31 per cent; and dishwashers were included in 81 per cent of renovations. About 358,000 renovation contracts were done in 1994-95 at a total value of $1.698 billion.

The major kitchen suppliers in New South Wales and Victoria estimate a median price of $9,000 to $10,000, excluding appliances, for a kitchen renovation. From my experience, $10,000 spent in a kitchen on cupboards is quite moderate. One would not spend that in a luxury house. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: This also agrees with the average cost of kitchen cabinet hardware/inclusions which we estimate at $400-$450 per kitchen. Hardware is usually estimated at about 5% of total kitchen costs.

The government should listen to this. On this basis, the total taxable base for kitchens would be as follows. Of 358,000 home renovations, the average base value would be an estimated $4,000, making a total of $1,432 million. The average tax would be $480, making a total tax take in one financial year—do not forget that this is only for kitchens—of $171.84 million. New housing starts in 1995-96—again, do not forget that this is for kitchens alone—have been 135,000, which is down from the 160,000 that we have had in the past couple of years. The estimated base value is $7,000, making a total of $945 million. The average tax is $840, giving a total revenue take of $113.4 million.

PARA.TAB: That is a total, at 12 per cent sales tax, of $285 million, yet the government maintains that this measure, when applied to the whole housing sector, will raise only $215. We have provided evidence from this building crowd, who are no slouches, but the minister sits there and has not responded one iota to our concerns. We have shown that this measure will raise $285 million on kitchens alone. Remember, this is the government that gave us the FBT and the capital gains tax.
This is a very serious situation. I urge the government to look at it again. I see that Senator Ian MacDonald is looking to rise, so I will give way to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you would recall that your government initially said that the cost of this tax would be about $300 on a new home. Like most other parliamentarians, I was approached by representatives of the building industry and the cabinet-making industry who said, `That is rubbish. It is closer to $2,000 or $3,000.' I said, `It's no good just telling me that. I need an assessment of what this tax will cost that I can take to the government and get its response to it.' That assessment is the document I tabled in the parliament yesterday and had incorporated in the Hansard today.

PARA.TAB: Mr Corrigan is a very reputable quantity surveyor. I have no reason to doubt that the document is his honest and professional assessment of what the additional cost would be. He said he would go to the housing estates and pick out a house in the $100,000 price bracket, which is very popular, and another in the $135,000 to $140,000 price range, which is also very popular. He costs houses every day of the week. Builders and purchasers rely on him. I said, `You go through this line by line and item by item and come back to me with something that I can table in the parliament. It will be subject to heavy scrutiny. You tell me what figure you come to.' Minister, this document is what he gave me and his assessment is quite a dramatic shift from what your advisers originally told you.

That document was tabled yesterday. I wonder if you have had the opportunity to have it checked? Are you in a position to comment on it? Is it correct? Do you argue with it somehow? It is the work of a professional and independent building consultant who, with a group of others, came to see me. I said, `You go out and do the sums and give them to me.' If he is right, it makes a mockery of your original assessment of $300, which rose to $1,000, went down to $800 and then went up to $1,000 again.
I would appreciate your comments on this document. Do you accept it as accurate? Do you challenge it? What is your position in relation to the document which has been tabled?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to Senator Ian Macdonald's comments about the disappearance of the great Australian dream of home ownership. If this bill is passed it will significantly push up prices, as Senator MacDonald has just indicated, and homes will become less affordable for young couples. The building industry already pays its fair share of tax. In 1992-93, $260 million was collected from the wholesale sales tax on building materials. The industry is fearful that if this measure is passed it will not be quarantined. Its concern is that the tax base will be widened in following years.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 7.00 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I had mentioned that, if passed, this government initiative represents a reduced government commitment to the Australian people towards home ownership. This is most unfortunate because the tax increases the price of a home and therefore reduces the affordability of home ownership to young Australians. The Australian people are entitled to a commitment from the government during this debate that it will not, in the future, attempt to widen the sales tax base in relation to building materials and that it will not increase the tax rate. John Howard gave a commitment not to introduce a GST. I seek a similar commitment from the government during this debate.
