That the request for amendments (Senator Gibson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In relation to each of the bills, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 2, page 9, after item 11, insert the following item:

TAB.TAB: Add:

SPEECH.PARA: '(6)Toilet tissue or facial tissue.'.".

I found it rather interesting listening to the debate we have just had, in which Senator Panizza was saying of the government that not two years ago it had said things about increasing tax. Not two months ago, Mr Howard said in an interview—and this comes from his office—`Look, we're not going to start talking about things that have not happened. We will vote against increases in taxation.' I repeat, `We will vote against increases in taxation.'

PARA.TAB: These requested amendments seek to remove the tax on recycled paper. The government is seeking to put the tax on recycled paper up to 22 per cent across the board. At the same time, it is disingenuously going to spend somewhat over $5 million convincing the public that they should buy recycled paper at an increased charge. It is trying to convince the people to act against their own interests, to act against the very ideology which drives this government and this opposition. That, as well as the nails and screws matters that we have just debated, indicates the gross inconsistency of this government.

In support of the government position, the government recently provided some background material from the large paper industry from which, I guess, the government and the opposition have been taking their advice. There are some remarkable statements in this document. Just take this for a load of logic. We read here, and this comes from the industry, that 34 per cent of total production of paper in Australia is 100 per cent recycled paper. Forty-five per cent of paper production has at least 80 per cent recycled paper content—note that figure. In other words, the total amount of recycled fibre going into paper must be less than 45 per cent. The very next sentence says that waste paper currently comprises 48 per cent of the fibre used in the production of paper in Australia.

So much for the documentation provided by the industry, which wants a 22 per cent tax imposed on it. It wants a 22 per cent tax imposed on it because it wants to squeeze out the small producers who are producing the recycled paper. That is the sort of mathematical nonsense that the industry is presenting, and it is the mathematical nonsense that the government has swallowed.

Further on in the same document we find the statement that recycling has no long-term advantage in terms of saving trees. If 34 per cent of the total production of paper in Australia is 100 per cent recycled paper, taking the industry's own figure, on each round of the use of that paper, 34 per cent fewer trees are being cut down. That is its own logic. So much for the sorts of arguments on which both the industry and the government are relying.

In the history of this whole matter, we find that the government has been quite inconsistent in the way it has dealt with recycled paper. As I indicated in the second reading debate, many years ago we moved an amendment to remove the sales tax from recycled paper. That was defeated by the government and the opposition, voting together—and neither the government nor the opposition likes any taxes related to anything that will encourage anything to do with the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the environment spokesman for the opposition?
—The environment spokesman for the opposition is not even—
—There he is.

—He is here, but he is not sitting in his right place. The environment spokesman for the opposition, like the environment spokesman for the government, will vote for an increase in the tax on recycled paper, as I understand it. I hope I can convince them otherwise.

PARA.TAB: Shortly after my original amendment was defeated, the government saw the wisdom of its error and it then moved to remove the tax from recycled paper and, for a short while, we did not have the tax on recycled paper. We then had the reintroduction of the tax accompanied by, because of the pressure which the Democrats were able to bring to bear on the then Treasurer, a payment of a bounty scheme, which in the first year exactly equalled the tax on the recycled paper—a 20 per cent sales tax accompanied by a 20 per cent bounty payment. So effectively it negatived the tax. In the next year, it was 15 per cent. In the final year, which was the last financial year, it was 10 per cent. Since then, there has been no tax encouragement to recycle paper.

In addition to that chronological inconsistency, we also had the inconsistency between different sorts of paper. When the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Act 1989 introduced a sales tax exemption with effect from 5 October 1989, it did so for the following goods made from recycled paper: writing paper and drawing paper; pads of writing and drawing paper; books of writing and drawing paper; paper for use in accounting ledgers and journals, envelopes, toilet and facial tissue; and paper bags marketed for household purposes or for use in marketing goods sold by retail. We now have in this definition of paper re-run of the nonsense we heard about earlier with nails and screws used for different purposes and treated differently under the tax law.

The amendment was originally announced by the Prime Minister in his environment statement on 20 July 1989. The expected cost to revenue in a full year of this amendment was expected to be less than—wait for it—$500,000. That was in the second reading speech. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Act 1992, as I have indicated, then removed the sales tax exemption with effect from 26 June 1992 for the following: books of writing and drawing paper; toilet and facial tissues; and paper bags marketed for household purposes or for use in marketing goods sold by retail. Thus, the following goods remained exempt: writing and drawing paper, pads of writing and drawing paper, paper for use in accounting ledgers and journals and envelopes. So we had this quite arbitrary distinction between the various uses to which paper could be put.

The reason for the removal of the exemption was that high quality waste paper was used in the manufacture of those recycled goods but, due to their nature, they were unlikely to be recycled again. The removal of the exemption was expected to result in increased revenue of—wait for it—$12 million. That was in the second reading speech. The difference between this revenue effect and the 1989 revenue effect would imply a massive increase in the supply of and demand for such recycled goods. Of course, the more likely explanation would be a very poor original estimate.

In order to ensure passage of the amendment through the Senate, however, it was necessary for the government to agree—I gave an indication of this before—to Democrat demands for transitional assistance to the Australian manufacturers affected by the bill. As I have indicated, the assistance varied over three years between 20 per cent down to 10 per cent. Any continuation of these payments beyond July 1994 would be subject to review of the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. In this regard—I note these figures again—$5.97 million was appropriated for the first payment, $10.26 million for the second and $5 million for the third.

Interestingly, in mentioning the Environment Protection Agency, it has looked at this matter and it has recognised the value of using bounty arrangements, sales tax arrangements or differential price arrangements to encourage people to act in environmentally responsible ways. When it completed its review of the bounty arrangements for recycled tissue products, it concluded that there remained a continuing need for financial assistance to manufacturers of paper products containing recycled paper on the basis of the quantity of post-consumer high grade waste used by the manufacturer. We have the situation where the government's own advice is to continue with some such arrangement.
Finally, we also have a document which comes directly from the paper manufacturers—I referred to it earlier—in which they say:

SPEECH.PARA: Between 1992 and 1994 the Paper Manufacturers Association member companies invested $150 million in facilities to make recycled paper. The amount of new investment in recycled paper facilities announced in the 1994-95 financial year is $285 million.

It then goes on and lists the actual amounts that were expended. However, what do we find in anticipation of this increase in the sales tax from Amcor? We find that the day after the budget—this was in the Australian Financial Review of 9 May 1994—it will make a decision to go ahead with a new $200 million fine papers plant, using non-recycled paper, in October. Coincidentally, the next day the budget virtually eliminated recycled paper as competition by taking the tax exemption off recycled paper in November. While the large part of the paper industry is claiming virtue for itself in some of its investments in recycled paper, its investments are dwarfed by the investments it is making not in recycled paper but in paper based on virgin fibre.

PARA.TAB: It is for those very sound economic and environmental reasons that we are seeking to remove the sales tax on products made from fibre which has been recycled. Honourable senators will note that if this request is defeated and the opposition—against the clear promise which has been made by its leader, Mr Howard, that he would not support any increases in taxation—does not support this amendment by the Democrats, I will be moving a further request which seeks, instead of a zero rate of tax, the 12 per cent rate of tax, which is the new concessional rate after the changes occur.

I will briefly explain why this is a fall-back position. Those parts of the industry which recognise the intransigence and inconsistency of the opposition have looked at the possibility of some halfway situation and have said that they could live with an across the board 12 per cent tax regime, but a 22 per cent tax regime would wipe them out. That is exactly the motivation of the large paper producers. A 12 per cent rate of tax would still maintain a 10 per cent differential, which would essentially make recycled paper of the same order of cost as paper made from virgin fibre. Those people, who were minded for good environmental reasons to buy the recycled paper, would not be disadvantaged.

In conclusion, I thought it was a principle that was established long ago that in politics one does not rely on conscience to get things done. One does not say to people, `You must act against your best interests and use guilt as a strategy to get things done. You should put in place economic measures which encourage people to do the right thing and reward them for doing the right thing rather than penalise them.' The imposition of this tax penalises people who have a conscience—the people who will continue to buy the recycled paper. In a futile attempt to address that, the government is spending of the order of the same amount of money to encourage people to act against their self-interest as it would expend if it adopted the middle course—the 12 per cent sales tax on recycled paper.
I strongly commend this request and ask very strongly that the opposition is consistent with its stated position and with what its leader has said and will support this by the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to rise for a couple of minutes to address what Senator Coulter said. He questioned my consistency and that of Mr Howard. I would like to debate who said what to whom. If we are talking about consistency, let us be consistent. Paper is not the only recycled commodity on this earth. I know it is the favourite of the Democrats. I do not know about the Greens, but recycled paper and the environment have always been a big favourite with the Democrats.
—That is what your leader said.

—Senator Coulter can wave it around as much as he likes, but if we are talking about consistency, let us be consistent. Waste paper is not the only commodity that is recycled. A massive amount of steel and aluminium is recycled. When aluminium is manufactured into new windows or steel is used in new cars, they are not sales tax free. Even tyres are recycled by being re-capped. I can remember once upon a time when there was no sales tax on re-capped tyres. Can Senator Kernot remember back that far? She would not have bought a tyre in her life or got one re-capped, so she would not know. Batteries are recycled for their lead. Is sales tax paid on new batteries? That is a valid question. Has Senator Coulter or Senator Kernot ever stood up in this chamber and said that batteries should be recycled for their lead? No, they have not. They have not said it while I have been around, and I have been in this Senate longer than they have.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats can plug as much as they like when they are zero rating on recycled paper—that is up to them—but, when they question my consistency and the consistency of John Howard, I question theirs. I have never heard them stand up and talk about any of these products.

The environment question is valid for products made from steel or lead because the more these products are recycled, the less mining needs to be carried out and there is less damage to the environment and less generation of electricity. Have they ever heard of what generation of electricity may or may not do? If the Democrats want to be consistent, they should get away from the fairies at the bottom of the garden and get into the real world, and then I will believe that they are consistent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate the support of the Greens (WA) for the request moved by Senator Coulter for the Australian Democrats, in the anticipation that we may not gain support for the alternative motion either. The underlying motivation for this government budget measure has two stories attached.

PARA.TAB: The first is attached to some small, local Australian-based companies, two of which are AusTissue in Western Australia—interestingly, in the Assistant Treasurer's electorate—and Cosco in Queensland. They are two small local companies employing local people and having local collection points for office paper recycling. They are enormously impressive as a community response to concern about the environment and the impact that our wasteful lifestyle has on the environment. I would like to share part of a statement by the Australian Recycled Paper Manufacturers Association, of which these two companies are a part. On 7 December 1994, Mr Head from ARPMA stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In every other country in the world, governments have created incentives for the manufacture of 100% recycled paper products. Australia made that commitment in 1988, but appears to be weakening in its commitment.
He also said:

Our industry cannot afford to carry the 21% WST at this point in our development. We've invested more than $75 million over five years in the technology, R & D and collection networks to produce products that have a positive impact on the environment.

The arguments that have been made against the support of these businesses sometimes blind government and other people with science, saying, `Because they are going mainly into toilet tissue, they are only single recyclers. They go from fine office paper to toilet paper. We really need to promote other recycled products.' However, that argument is pulled from under anybody who uses it with the realisation that at the moment we have 600,000 tonnes of waste paper still going into landfill.

PARA.TAB: We, as Australians, need to ask the federal government why it is not committed to a 50 per cent reduction in all waste to landfill by the year 2000. This was outlined in the national waste minimisation and recycling strategy, and by the Australia and New Zealand Environment Conservation Council agreement. But it appears that the government has reneged on its commitment and is much more interested in gaining revenue through the tax. I think there is another story to this: it is not simply a critique of those small, local Australian based industries and the very good work they are doing. The minister will probably think up other arguments along those lines; but let us remember the industries that this amendment is urging us to maintain our commitment and support for.

The second story that underlines the need for this amendment is about some bigger players amongst which are Amcor, Kimberly-Clark and Bowater-Scott. The real story of the need for this amendment lies with the forest industry. Most fibre used for manufacturing paper in Australia comes from native forests. The approximate proportions are imported pulp at 12 per cent; recycled content, eight per cent; domestic plantation-grown, eight per cent; domestic native forest grown, eight per cent; and other, three per cent.

Companies like Amcor form a mixed industry. They have said they are starting up recycled components. That is only a very small part of their industry. They have a vested interest in not wanting to see the small, lively competitors that are working on 100 per cent recycled paper gaining some kind of foothold in their market. That is the real story underlying the government's switch from small players to big players.

The way these big players appear virtuous is to have made a commitment—for this we commend them—to plantation sourced pulp. That is okay if it does not involve a kind of predatory view towards other industries that are helping us to reduce the 600,000 tonnes of landfill that could be used in 100 per cent recycled paper products. That is the reality of the second story. I will quote again from a statement by the Australian Recycled Paper Manufacturers Association. Its representative stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The forest industry companies have not involved themselves to any great extent in the manufacturer of 100% recycled paper products and will comfortably survive any decision by your Government to agree to a policy of favouritism for these products. Our industry cannot survive a decision which imposes equal Sales Tax on our product and the non-recycled product, especially where the non-recycled product is not required to contribute to landfill costs on a polluter-pays basis, contributing to the real costs of landfill yet there is no recognition for our companies taking waste out of landfill.

It is an extremely valuable contribution that is going unrecognised. Just in case senators would need to hear the position of Australian Paper, Amcor, I would like to quote from a 2 December 1994 letter to me. It states:
Amcor is an Australian company with a share market value today of about $6 billion and traces its origins back to the 1860s to Australia's first paper-making ventures.
What is paper made from? It is made from forests. The letter continues:
The company has operations in every State and employs over 14,000 people.
The company's pulp and paper business, Australian Paper, has grown to become the largest business of its kind in the western Pacific.
Australian Paper is Australia's major forest plantation owner and the country's largest paper recycler, collecting more waste paper than all other recyclers combined.
Australian Paper is firmly opposed to the sales tax exemption for recycled papers and does not support subsidies for recycled paper producers.
A wholesale tax exemption for certain 100 per cent recycled paper products came into effect in October 1989. The aim of the exemption was to encourage the recycling of paper.

The letter goes on to argue against the validity of that. I do not want my citing of the letter to be taken as a criticism of all the activities of that company. I merely want to show the different motivation that is operating. That is the position the government has chosen to move in favour of. It feels those big arguments, the 14,000 people, the $6 billion, and being the biggest company of its kind in the western Pacific, are reasons to listen and do something which Australian Paper has said is of no concern to it: the removal of the exemption. Of course it is of no concern; it is in that company's favour.

PARA.TAB: The decision eliminates its small, growing competition which is doing a very valuable job. There are plenty of people who will not buy toilet tissue containing other than 100 per cent recycled paper products. They are investing in our future and supporting environmentally sound practices. This failure of the government to recognise that is a disincentive for local companies.

I would like to say shame on the opposition for indicating that it will support the government on this measure. I warned the shadow minister for the environment, Senator Kemp, that I would be pointing out to him a document in which a series of correspondence appears from various members of parliament across all the parties. I think Senator Kernot's letter is the first one in here. There is Tom Barton, the member for Waterford, Robert Tickner and any number of people from many parties supporting the need for the continued support of the these 100 per cent recycled products. There is also a letter dated 20 November 1994 from the Western Australian Liberal state government's Minister for the Environment. The then environment minister, Kevin Minson, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australia stands to lose an important green industry and hundreds of jobs in recycling if the Federal Government prematurely removes its assistance from the recycled tissue paper industry . . .

There are very few product differentials on environmental issues between the federal government and the federal opposition, but here is one. I therefore urge the opposition to reconsider its position and to support the Democrat's amendment, as the Greens intend to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said during the second reading debate and also at the start of the committee stage, the coalition's position has been quite clear for some long time. It has been clear since the 1993 election that we would oppose any tax increase measures of a general nature that the government campaigned against prior to the 1993 election. Therefore, we are against any general tax measures. The government wants to make changes in the budget for other reasons, and we will not stand in its way.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier this evening, we will not stand in the way of changes that have been made to these sales tax bills as a result of court decisions—that is, to safes, model aircraft, scaffolding, et cetera. It is consistent with our principles. The things that we did oppose and what we will oppose in the next level of amendments include motor vehicles, which have already been dealt with this evening, and building materials, half of which has been dealt with already. With regard to the third set of items—that is, the Industry Commission recommendations to the government relating to recycled paper—we are not here to argue the ins and outs of that particular industry tonight. Because of the principles with regard to the budget measures, if the government cares to change its mind regarding that industry, so be it. That is on its head, not ours. We are not supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the debate, particularly to the views put forward by Senator Coulter and Senator Chamarette. Senator Coulter made a long speech, but I do not think he did the analysis. The analysis simply is what will best encourage the use of recycled paper in this country. I think Senator Chamarette did weigh up some of the issues. On the one hand, Senator Chamarette recognised that a number of the very large users of recycled paper have strongly urged the removal of this exemption. She recognised this particular view. On the other hand, she attempted to weigh it against a view put by some companies that the removal of the exemption would be damaging to them.

PARA.TAB: I think all of us share a view that it is important that the use of recycled paper be encouraged. I do not think anyone would stand up in this chamber and oppose it. In fact, it is my strong view that everything should be done to encourage the use of recycled paper. However, from the material which has been brought before me and after listening to the debates, it seems to me that the removal of this particular exemption will not effectively, certainly in the medium and long term, discourage in any way the use of recycled paper. In fact, all the information that I have seen is that large investments are currently being made to use recycled paper. I think Senator Chamarette listed some of those investments.

I listened to the analysis given by Senator Coulter. I was intrigued that he quoted people's promises and statements. I think my colleague Senator Gibson effectively responded to that issue on behalf of the coalition. I am delighted that the Democrats are getting up and saying that promises are important. I have been saying that to Senator Kernot for a long time. Australia would be a significantly different place if she had stuck by the view that government promises are important and that governments should be held to their promises. I regret to say that after the last election she effectively invited the government—

TALK.START.PARA: —I never supported the tax cuts; never.
—You did not support the tax cuts, but the Australian people relied on a promise by the federal government.
—I never changed my position.
—I am afraid you have changed your position.
—No, I have not changed my position.

—This is a debate for another time. Senator Gibson has effectively answered the issue raised by Senator Coulter in relation to the position of the opposition. On the issue of governments being kept to their promises, I think Senator Kernot was tested after the election and was found wanting. She encouraged the government to bring in a massage range of tax increases, which it did, and to break its promises on the l-a-w tax cuts.
—You just said they had the right to do it.

—As I said, we will revisit that debate at an appropriate time. As we get closer to an election, I am glad that you have suddenly discovered that promises are important. It is a great pity that, when you were tested on this issue, not only did you not make a stand—
—We made consistent statements.

—No, you were utterly inconsistent. As a consequence, the Australian people are wearing far higher taxes as a result of the actions of you and your party. I understand that the debate is a complex one. Everyone wants to encourage the use of recycled paper. We read the claims from a wide variety of companies that are involved in this sector. Some of the major users of recycled paper have strongly argued that this exemption causes a distortion in the market and they support the government's measures. Other companies, the smaller ones as pointed out by Senator Chamarette, believe the exemption they currently have is of benefit to them. I think we have to weigh up the arguments.

PARA.TAB: The report of the Industry Commission recommended the abolition of sales tax exemptions. Its study found that it had a limited impact on recycling rates. That is an important point. We may well differ on that, but the Industry Commission carried out a study on it. I am intrigued that both Senator Coulter and Senator Chamarette did not draw attention to a point which I regarded as quite significant. In order to finance changes in the environmental budget, as a result of these changes the government is saving of the order of $45 million over the next four years. I was surprised that you did not contrast this with the additional $5 million that the government is proposing to put into various programs to encourage the use of recycled paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks for pointing it out.

—I think that was important. That is why I said that the analysis has to be done. All of us are convinced that there should be as much encouragement as possible to the use of recycled papers. It seems to me on the weight of arguments that this concession is not achieving that goal. Therefore, the question arises: what other programs should have been put in place?

PARA.TAB: If you read Senator Faulkner's budget statement, you will see that it is very skimpy as to what the additional programs, which cost in the order of $5 million, are going to produce to encourage greater use and demand by consumers of recycled paper.

In conclusion, and to support my colleague, I do not think the requested amendments that have been proposed by Senator Coulter are the way to go. I do not want to pretend that I do not understand the arguments, but I have to say, on balance, from the evidence that has been presented to me, that this concession is not producing the results. As my colleague said, it is one of those changes which removes some distortions in the tax system which we are not opposed to. We will be supporting the government's proposal on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the increase in the tax rate on recycled paper. Again, I have before me this statement by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard: `We will vote against increases in taxation.' To me, those words are simple and they mean that the opposition could not support what the government is proposing.

PARA.TAB: The issue of consistency has been raised by several opposition spokespeople. Senator Panizza confused two quite separate issues, as he often does. The first is consistency in relation to policy and the second is consistency in relation to the philosophy which lies behind that policy. In relation to consistency, we are saying that, to be consistent with what the Leader of the Opposition has said, the opposition should not support this increase in taxation.

In relation to the fundamental philosophy, it is simply untrue, as Senator Panizza asserted, that we have not spoken about the relative importance of taxation on virgin materials and a lesser tax rate, or a bounty scheme, on recycled materials across the board. We have spoken at great length and in great detail on this matter. On many occasions we have pointed out how this would work. Virgin materials, particularly non-renewable materials such as the specific metals that Senator Panizza mentioned, in our view should attract a tax. That tax should not be applied to those metals when they are recycled. There should be encouragement to recycle those things to the maximum extent possible. We have been absolutely consistent in that respect.

Senator Kemp said that does not do that. I will give Senator Kemp some figures. In May 1994, just over a year ago, the figure for recycled writing paper from Australian paper was $5 per ream; the non-recycled Copyright, $5.67; Reflex, $5.74; and the imported, $4.99—almost exactly the same price as the recycled.

Senator Kemp, under those circumstances and given that you want to buy Australian, which would you buy? Recycled costs you $5; Copyright is going to cost you $5.67 a ream. As an economic rationalist what would you do? You would buy the recycled paper, would you not, because it was cheaper. Let us look at the figures after the government has placed its impost. That recycled paper from the same manufacturer will cost $6.91 per ream. Copyright will cost you $6.28 per ream. Senator Kemp, which would you buy—the recycled for $6.91 or the non-recycled for $6.28? As a pure economic rationalist you would go for the non-recycled paper every time.

I say that without any blush or fear of contradiction. The $5 million approximately that the government is going to put in place to encourage you to act against your best interests will not cause you to buy the recycled product. That is the argument. It is a very simple, straightforward, rational and economic argument. For those reasons I believe it should be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because we will not get home before Christmas if we do not hurry it along a bit, would honourable senators mind if I just indicated that I will be supporting this request for amendments. If they want to ask me why, they can do so at a later stage.

That the request for amendments (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 June, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is supporting these amendments which are basically designed to overcome very severe administrative failure within the Department of Industry, Science and Technology. It is very important to recognise the responsibility of ministers to ensure that the form of delegated legislation is complied with. In this instance the government failed to table guidelines, and thus properly bring into ongoing effect the guidelines under the powers in the principal act. The result was that these guidelines under the IR&D scheme became invalid. They became invalid in four different instances. The default dates back as far as 1988.

PARA.TAB: It is hard to imagine how the failures within the department could reach such proportions that it was not until 1994 that it was first recognised within the department that such errors had occurred. Regrettably, even when that came to the notice of certain officers, action was not taken. It was not until April of this year, from memory, that the seriousness of the omissions was recognised and the administration started to address the remedial action which should be taken.

It is not limited just to the IR&D scheme because, regrettably, in the course of this matter it was found that there were also omissions under the export market development grants scheme, which is now administered by Austrade. At the time, at least some of these administrative failures in that regard were administered by this department. When an investigation was mounted at the request of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) it was found that omissions had occurred in relation to the Bounty (Computers) Act. At the very least, what has been demonstrated is very severe administrative deficiencies within this department.

The minister, in the immediate term, sought to play down the consequences and accused us of beat-ups and all sorts of things. For a while he was hopeful that the making and tabling of further guidelines would resolve the difficulties. After further advice, he decided to take the sensible path, which was the more cautious path, which we advocated from the start, and this legislative change was made retrospective to cover the decisions made over the past years under invalid guidelines.

That was the course we suggested. I am pleased that the government and the minister came to the recognition that it was the sensible path to follow. Naturally enough, we on this side who are interested in providing confidence to those investing in the scheme and to industry are prepared to support the changes. They are changes which should never have been necessary. This bill should never have been necessary.

I still do not know whether the minister and the department understand the consequences of their default. They put in jeopardy very large sums of money. Investment applications have been made and have failed, at great expense to parties, on the basis of invalid guidelines. There are question marks over the validity of grants that have been approved. That was all basically because of the elementary failures within the department, occurring to such an extent that one might even refer to them as a systemic failure.

The question is: who takes responsibility? Following these embarrassing revelations, the minister caused an investigation to take place. Principally, the fault has been marked down to the bureaucrats, which is very comfortable for the minister. The bureaucrats appeared before the estimates committee and accepted responsibility for the errors. When the default occurs so often within the administration of a department; when it continues for so long, even when it default is discovered; and when the consequences of the default were not understood and remedial action was not taken, somewhere along that road the person in charge of the administration has to accept some responsibility.

This government has been marked by ministers who have been all too quick to pass the buck to their officers and have been reluctant to accept that they are ultimately responsible for the competent administration of their department. This minister is one of those who is not prepared to accept that responsibility. He is prepared to blame his servants rather than accept that the master occasionally has to have the stomach to accept that failure ultimately rests with him. I suppose, at the very least, we can say that after the Jacobs inquiry there will now be improvement within the systems in the department that hopefully will result in recurrence being much more unlikely. That is to some extent comforting.

I think it is important for ministers to recognise that delegated legislation is not just simply a matter of form. It is a responsibility to be accepted seriously. This responsibility has been passed from the parliament to the person given the power to make the rule, regulation or guideline—that subordinate legislation has the effect of law—and to ensure protection, as in this instance. Under the Acts Interpretation Act it is obliged to be tabled in parliament. We have the opportunity and the responsibility to consider it. In some circumstances we have the right also to move for disallowance. The law is such that it provides a safeguard. In this instance the safeguard was not given. The minister has therefore failed in meeting that responsibility to the Australian people.

So there was a failure of process—a process that has been taken far too casually by this minister and this department; there was a failure to those who invested in this scheme and who had a right to expect certainty; and there was a failure to the board and others who were given the responsibility to administer it for the department and who had the right to expect that the prerequisites to legality would have been complied with. All of these are failures for which the minister must take ultimate responsibility but for which he is not prepared to.

Nevertheless, we hope that some lessons have been learned. I think over 2,000 pieces of delegated legislation now become law each year in this country. If this is a precedent, one can only wonder in how many instances the requirements of the law have not been met. The consequences that would flow from that would be really quite astonishing.

I said the coalition will support this legislation to restore confidence to the industry and to investors. We have moved quickly to do that and to process this piece of legislation through our party room. The only reservation we have in doing so is that, whenever an attempt is made to pass retrospective legislation, obviously careful thought must be given to whether any party might be detrimentally affected by that retrospectivity.

In this instance it is not easy to see who might suffer damages as a result of our attempts to put the law right and to overcome the deficiencies in the minister's administration. Nevertheless, we believe it is better to err on the side of caution. We will propose at the committee stage an amendment that has the effect of ensuring that the legislation which gets passed tonight in an effort to overcome the administrative failures to which I have referred will not have any inadvertent consequence that is detrimental to any party. To save time at the next stage of the debate, I will read the terms of that amendment, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of anything in this Act, the validations provided for by this Act do not affect any right of action of a person in relation to:
(a)a decision of the Board; or
(b)an act or thing done by any person or body;
that was adverse to the person in relation to whom the decision was made or the act or thing was done and such rights of action may be pursued as if this Act had never been enacted.

I understand that that amendment has been circulated. I hope that it will be supported by all parties. I hope that it will also be supported by the government. I would be particularly concerned if it is not.

PARA.TAB: This is a night when, unfortunately, the minister cannot hold his head high. This is a night of embarrassment for him and his administration. Nevertheless, the consequences to the public, including investors, and industry are more important than the minister's embarrassment. I am pleased that, at least after tonight, the law will be made certain. Those who invest in this way will have certainty in their investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Industry Research and Development Amendment Bill 1995. The bill has two purposes: firstly, to implement the budget decision to extend the ability of the Industry Research and Development Board to enter into new grant agreements from the current expiry date of 31 December 1995 until 30 June 1996; and, secondly, to validate the guidelines for the 150 per cent R&D tax concession, which were not tabled in parliament two years ago and which were dealt with by Senator Hill at great length just now.

PARA.TAB: Since the guidelines became invalid, 14 companies have had their applications for concession rejected. Another 29 syndicates were withdrawn and 135 were approved. The Democrats are also concerned that this administrative oversight has occurred. We believe that the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) must take responsibility for it. However, the purpose of the scheme is too important to be allowed to suffer through this administrative oversight. Certainly the Democrats will lend their support to the amendments that will validate the guidelines.

We will also support the opposition amendment, which is very similar to the one that was moved in a similar situation which developed over the EMDG guidelines. We believe that the rights of those companies or syndicates which have been rejected must be preserved in a substantive way so that they do not suffer any disadvantage, should they wish to take action.

I am not aware in this case whether they have run out of time. I recall that, on the previous occasion, the minister made a commitment that, even if they have run out of time, any objections or appeals that they wish to lodge on substantive grounds will still be dealt with even though technically the time had elapsed during which those appeals could be made. I call on the minister to advise the chamber whether he is prepared to follow this precedent on this occasion. I am not aware whether any of those 14 companies wish to make appeals. But it is clear in this situation that the least the chamber can do is to preserve their rights, should they wish to do so.

I turn to the most substantive aspects of this bill. The Democrats are firm believers in the importance of research and development, which we believe is extremely important for the future of our economy and for our country as a whole. That belief is grounded in the understanding that, in the modern globally integrated economy, knowledge and skills rather than capital are the source of wealth. We are, therefore, strong supporters of the government's intervention to support R&D. In particular, we are supporters of this 150 per cent tax concession for R&D.

For many years economic policy has been dominated by believers in the traditional so-called neoclassical model of economic growth. In this model the only way to double the output of the economy was to double inputs into the economy of land, labour and capital. In this view of the world, governments were not supposed to intervene in the economy. Free markets would see resources find their way to those productive uses where they would be most efficiently used. So it was wrong for the government to attempt to push those resources in other directions through active policy. We may be reaching a stage where that policy has outlived its usefulness, if it ever had any. In that view of the world, technological progress was something that just happened. It was not something that was itself an outcome of economic activity.

More recently a group of economists led by American Professor Paul Romer have overturned this view of the world, with the insight that knowledge is what now drives an economy and generates economic growth. As Romer points out, in the age of knowledge you do not need to double all inputs to double all outputs. A new idea plus the same amount of material inputs can double output. Take the example of producing computers. You can measure the output of a computer company by the amount of computer power it generates. To double the number of computers a company produces you would indeed need to double the number of workers, double the materials, double the inputs of capital and power.

But if someone comes up with a new idea, a new technique, a new piece of knowledge which means that every new computer will, with some slight adjustment to chip design, produce double the computing power, then the same number of computers will be producing double the actual output of the company. Same inputs, one new idea, and output is doubled. Unlike other inputs, like capital and labour, if I make use of a new idea that does not stop you or anybody else from using it. Ideas do not get used up. That is why the generation of new knowledge is important for growth.

Romer's second insight was that there are many industries which produce new knowledge as a by-product of the main activities. The aerospace industry, for example, produced the knowledge that led to teflon and kevlar. This new knowledge coming out of such industries is often referred to as a knowledge spillover or as a positive externality. Most people acknowledge that manufacturing industry, in particular manufacturing industry based on advanced technology, tends to generate more of these knowledge spillovers than other industries.

Accepting Romer's view of the world, the hands-off approach to industry policy no longer makes sense. Letting the market direct resources wherever they might fall no longer makes sense. Resources devoted to an industry that generates new knowledge as a by-product are many times more valuable to an economy than resources devoted to industries which do not. But markets do not take this added value into account because the knowledge generated by an industry is not necessarily captured by that industry. To use my previous example, it was not the aeronautics industry which made the profit out of Teflon.

New growth theory tells us that the market left to itself will underinvest in industries which generate knowledge spillovers. Hence government intervention is required to encourage research and development to support venture capital to help commercialise new technologies and to divert resources toward the manufacturing sector. It is no coincidence that the high growth economies of the past decade, Japan, Korea and the other Asian tigers, have all followed policies of targeted government intervention to develop strategic positions in manufacturing, computers and other technologies.

For many years now the Australian Democrats have argued that the rapid dismantling of assistance to Australia's manufacturing industries has been poor and counterproductive policy. Because of the nature of political debate and the overriding interest of the Australian Democrats in social justice and equity, the public face of that criticism has been an emphasis that too rapid change was poor social policy; obviously it was. It has caused massive unemployment and dislocation, the virtual disappearance of job opportunities for blue-collar workers, rising inequality of income, suicides and family breakdown, and the death or near-death of many regional towns built around manufacturing. Hardest hit has been my own state of Victoria.

The point I am emphasising today is that those policies were also poor policies from the standpoint of maximising long-term growth. The disappearance of much of our manufacturing base is tied directly to the loss of the knowledge spillovers that we need to generate growth. The percentage of people employed in high-tech manufacturing has actually fallen by 10 per cent over the last 20 years, while in the OECD generally the proportion has increased by 23 per cent over the same period.

Our poor performance in private sector research and development—we still rank in the bottom half of the OECD league table—is directly related to the dismantling of our manufacturing base and the failure of our high-tech sector to grow at the rate of our overseas competitors; not forgetting the assistance that sector has had in other countries.

Another result of our short-sighted unilateral deregulation has been high levels of foreign ownership of Australian firms. This has meant that much of the R&D is carried out in head offices offshore, with the result that once again we lose the benefit of any knowledge spillovers. The deregulationist policies of the last two decades have not only damaged the very social fabric of our country but have also undermined our capacity to generate new wealth.

Recently, the government has appeared to grasp much of the rhetoric of new growth theory. It speaks at great length about the need to develop a culture of innovation and about the need to make us a clever country. To date, however, it has been just rhetoric. Apart from a few schemes, the government has generally failed to put its money where its mouth is and really get behind the development of a high-tech manufacturing base in this country. There is still no significant support for venture capital. There is still no commitment to industry planning for our strategic manufacturing industries. There is still a determination to drive more of our motor vehicle industry—long a major source of knowledge spillovers—out of the country through a program to reduce tariffs to 15 per cent, while we still do not get access to competitors' markets.

I look forward to the minister's forthcoming innovation statement. I trust he will use it to reverse the government's policy of non-intervention. I have had a look at the interim paper and I find it rather disappointing: it has more of the same and not enough strategic emphasis, which is what we need at this time in research and development and to generate investment. I commend to the minister, in particular, Derek Sicklen's proposals in his latest paper, `A Fresh Look at Industry and Trade Policy'. The idea of linking performance conditions to industry incentives has proved a winner in programs such as factor F, partnerships for development, and the industry innovation programs. It allows self-selection by industry, avoiding the government's ideological aversion to picking winners. I would have thought that the wrong thing is picking losers.

My aim today has been to emphasise the importance of research and development as a source of future growth, and the value the Australian Democrats place on such activities. Because of that, it is vital that the government's bill to correct its own administrative incompetence is passed, and passed quickly, to allow the important R&D tax concession program to continue in a climate of certainty and with minimal disruption to industry.

In the budget, the government removed private sector tax exempt bodies from access to the 150 per cent tax concession. In doing so, it unfairly wiped out many research projects which were already well into the process of putting the final touches on syndication arrangements. Moreover, the value of the research involved, particularly that being undertaken by some of our leading medical research organisations, suggests that the government has been very short-sighted. I signal now that when the government brings the relevant legislation before the Senate in the next session, the Australian Democrats will be looking for action to correct this apparent inequity.

In closing, may I reiterate that the Australian Democrats strongly support the continuance of this particular 150 per cent R&D tax concession program. We do believe that it can be improved. We do believe that it, as well as incentives for investment, should be increased and should be tied to performance criteria of industry to come together in a targeted and strategic program for the economic and industrial development of this country.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—We are debating the Industry Research and Development Amendment Bill 1995, and I am speaking to close the second reading of that bill. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, and a Democrats spokesmen, Senator Spindler, have addressed this bill. I thank both of the senators for their contribution. This bill is aimed at providing a speedy remedy for what is a case of administrative failure in order to restore certainty and to provide that the error that has been committed is remedied as quickly as possible so as to minimise any disruption the administrative failure may have caused.

PARA.TAB: When I and the senior officers of my department became aware of the problem that had been created by the failure to table these particular instruments, immediate remedial action was taken by us. At the instigation of the Secretary to the Department of Industry, Science and Technology, there has now been an independent inquiry into the events—what happened and how they arose. A second report has been filed as well stating what actions can be taken to ensure that administratively this problem is never repeated.

I refer the Senate to the statement I gave to the estimates committee on Monday night. It is probably the most full and complete statement from the government as to the nature of these things and what we have done to act thus far to repair them. I also note for the record that, with the names of particular officers referred to in the report blanked out, the report of the independent reporter, Mr Jacobs, has been lodged with the estimates committee and a full unexpatiated copy of the report has been lodged with the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill. The estimates committee which has been referred to here took evidence from a number of departmental officers as well.

In the case of this unfortunate and unhappy administrative failure my first obligation was to ensure proper investigation, analysis and recommendation of remedial action and to properly attend to my responsibilities as minister to this parliament by making available to it all the relevant documentation and, in the form of the estimates procedure, the relevant officers of the department as well for examination and consideration. That has been done. I believe that is an obligation on ministers. The secretary to my department has indicated to the estimates committee that he is taking a number of administrative steps to prevent this issue ever being before us again and to improve the systems operation of the department.

I have before me the report of Mr Jacobs, the independent reporter, and the comments on that report by the secretary. I have not yet this week been able to lend my mind to an analysis of that report from a ministerial point of view, but I intend to do that promptly—hopefully by the end of this weekend. I will make available, by note to the estimates committee, my further consideration as minister based on the actions that have been taken by the department so the estimates committee can be aware in full of the government's response to all of this.

This bill corrects the oversight and it does it in a most cautious and careful way. There are legitimate contending views as to how the oversight could have been corrected, but, in sum, it comes down to the fact that the one way that all the thinkers on the subject believe that it can be corrected so that it is beyond any doubt is the way we have corrected it. As a consequence, we have adopted this course of action.

In this debate, the questions of what is ministerial responsibility and whether I should take ministerial responsibility have been raised. I take ministerial responsibility for my actions. I think the facts of this matter show that my actions have been immediate and proper in all of the circumstances. This has been described colloquially `as a model cock-up'.

I know that the department has directed its attention, as I have, to making sure we put in place a model remedy. While life is an experience that is not lived without mistakes—and one regrets and is always chastened by mistakes when they occur—I think the true measure is to admit them frankly and openly, allow independent investigation, be satisfied from outside advice that you have acted properly and also remedy the situation as quickly and fully as possible. That is what we have tried to do on this occasion.

An amendment has been foreshadowed for the committee stage of the bill. I have had a look at that amendment. I say for the record that the government invited comment on the bill from all parties before it was lodged to make sure that the form of the bill was appropriate. I have sought opinions from various parties as to whether or not there would be amendments and until tonight I understood that there would not be any and that the bill did meet the purposes for which it was framed.

I have been given no notice of the amendment. Nonetheless, it is an amendment to which I have to respond. Produced on the spot as it is, it seems to be similar in terms to an amendment accepted by the government in relation to the EMDG scheme. It appears that this amendment does not do anything new in terms of the bill. The purpose of this amendment is encompassed by what is already included in the bill. However, it can be held that this amendment more clearly expresses that purpose and for that reason the government will accept it. I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.
Amendment (by Senator Hill) agreed to:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Saving of rights of action for adverse decisions or acts etc

PARA.TAB: "5.(1) In spite of anything in this Act, the validations provided for by this Act do not affect any rights of action of a person in relation to:

TAB.TAB: (a)a decision of the Board; or
(b)an act or thing done by any person or body;

PROCTEXT.PARA: that was adverse to the person in relation to whom the decision was made or the act or thing
was done and such rights of action may be pursued as if this Act had never been enacted.
