PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the amendments made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate a week or so ago, the opposition and the Australian Democrats supported a number of amendments to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 [1995]. There were very good reasons for our supporting those amendments. They predominantly recognised that the tourism industry, particularly the inbound tourism industry, was a very major industry in Australia. It is up there with primary industry, mining and manufacturing. In fact, it brings into this country in the order of $11 billion a year in foreign currency.

PARA.TAB: During the debate on that bill in the Senate, I mentioned that Senator McMullan, who is here tonight, has been one of those who have proclaimed the tourist industry as being the biggest part of the service industry not only because of the foreign currency it brings in but also because of the number of people it employs in Australia, particularly young people. It has the potential to employ a lot more.

In the House of Representatives, the government with its numbers rejected the amendments passed by the Senate. I could not help looking at the reasons why the government in the House of Representatives rejected those amendments. I will touch on those amendments.

The first of those amendments by the Senate was that the government allow the tourist industry to claim the cost of samples of tourism services given away to overseas visitors. There is a very good reason for that. Any other person or business in the exporting business is able to take their samples overseas so the customers can see them, feel them, touch them, eat them or whatever they do with them and thus promote their particular industry. That is impossible with tourism. With the tourism industry, the customer must be brought to the product.

The government in the House of Representatives said, and I quote from the explanation of reasons, `No industry sector is allowed to claim free samples given away in Australia.'That is either deceptive or shows a total lack of understanding, because samples given away overseas for exports are allowable when claims are put together for export market development grant purposes. I thought we made it very clear, both ourselves and the Democrats, that there was only one way that sampling could be provided for tourism and that was to bring the customers, the wholesalers from overseas, to see what product was being offered and then market it in an overseas country to attract overseas tourists to Australia.

The second amendment related to allowing joint ventures, consortia, to get together to apply for export market development grants. We gave very good reasons for that. The reasons were that this was of great benefit to regional Australia. Farming communities, whether they be small bed and breakfast places or small resorts, would be able to get together as joint ventures and market their particular region.

I could not help but note, and again it shows a complete lack of understanding by the government of what tourism is about, that the government says the export market development grants scheme should promote things which otherwise would not occur. A classic example of how to achieve that is to allow joint ventures. You must allow joint ventures for those small operators. There are lots of parts of Australia where there are small operators who do not have the money at their disposal to promote their particular resort. Yet if they join together they are able to do so.

Some of those places in Australia are, for example, the Yarra Valley in Victoria, some of the Hunter region in New South Wales, the wine growing areas of South Australia and other parts of Australia. In my own state, the various farm holiday facilities that are available, particularly when you get out towards places like the Longreach Hall of Fame, could go together with the Hall of Fame as joint venturers and try to attract people from overseas to come to their facilities.

So the arguments do not hold water. The claim is made that it would cost in this particular instance about $2 million per annum down the track. That ignores the fact that this is the classic economic industry—the one we all learn about, that really does not apply in most practice. This one does apply. It is an industry in which if money is to be earned money has to be spent on promotion.

It is the classic industry in many respects. You have to have a good product, you have to give good service but you must promote it. Assuming you have a good product and you give a good service, which most Australian tourist industries do—and I think everyone would agree with that—it must be promoted. If you do not promote it, you will not get anywhere. Even having succeeded, if you do not continue to promote it, you will not survive. It is the classic industry.

A good example was given to me last year when I was overseas in Japan. I was given the analogy of a very well-known beer, I think it was Kirin beer, that had 70 or 80 per cent of the market and it did not think it had to continue advertising. It cut its advertising right back and I think the share of the market dropped from 70 per cent to 40 per cent in a very short period of time. That is basically what tourism is about.

Still, the government does not see it that way. It is claiming a $2 million cost to export market development grants. It is not really $2 million or $3 million. Assuming these businesses make a profit, they probably give 36 per cent back to the government, anyway. It is just a method of enabling them to get together and promote their industry.

I refer to the last of the amendments the government will not accept. I think this shows the great discrimination of the government. The House of Representatives committee that looked at tourism found that inbound tourism is an industry, the same as every other industry in this country. In fact, it has more benefits.

With the mining industry, for instance, minerals have to be mined out of the ground, processed and sent overseas. In return, in comes foreign currency. But you had to take a bit out of Australia and give it away to get the foreign currency in. With tourism, people come here, they stay in hotels and motels, they view the things they wish to see—the great splendours of Australia—and they leave their foreign currency behind. They leave it in the region. It is a wonderful way to actually distribute income into areas that really need it.

I think we have seen the benefits of that in places like Far North Queensland, parts of Western Australia and the Gold Coast of Queensland. I have often said that Sydney is a lucky city because people tend to feel that if they are coming to Australia they either come in or go out through Sydney. The Sydney region has the benefit of that, but other parts of Australia do not have that benefit and they must be able to market.

This particular amendment would have treated tourism in exactly the same way as every other industry. It would have enabled single tourist operators to claim a grant of 50c for every dollar they spend on marketing their product overseas. The government in its original legislation allowed that industry to get only 25c in the dollar, which means it was half recognised.

I said in my speech at the second reading stage that at least it was a step in the right direction. It was a step in the right direction because it recognised single tourism operators. Up until now, the single tourism operators could not make any export market development grant claims at all. The multiple tourist operators, the big ones, were able to claim and they still can. The multiple tourism operators still get 50c in the dollar; the single tourism operator does not. We tried to rectify that situation.

I indicate that, notwithstanding those arguments, the coalition will not be opposing the government's amendments. The reason we will not be opposing the government's amendments, I am sad to say, relates to the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee). The minister claims to be the friend of tourism until the chips are down. He is very quick at claiming credit for what the industry does. If the number of bed nights goes up, he puts out a press release almost claiming he did it. If international tourism figures rise, he is there with a great press release. But when the chips are down he is not there.

The minister was not there when the Port Hinchinbrook fight was on with Senator Faulkner. Irrespective of the rights or wrongs of that, he is supposed to be the Minister for Tourism and he should have been in there battling to make sure that the fiasco that occurred at Port Hinchinbrook did not occur. He was not there when this particular legislation was brought in by the government and he was not there when the government amended it in the House of Representatives to reduce the benefits available to the industry.

Sadly, the reason we are not opposing the amendments is that the minister has been running around the industry with threats. Those threats are that if the Senate continues to support the Senate amendments which gave the tourism industry the same recognition as applies to every other industry, he would withdraw the recognition of single tourism operators. We are not prepared to put that at risk.

Eighty per cent of the tourism industry is classified as small business. There is no justification for not accepting the amendments passed by the Senate previously. There is no logic in the government discriminating against one of our few growth industries, which brings in $10 billion a year in foreign currency.

This government has shown by its actions that it has discriminated against the industry. It has never ever, even as yet, recognised it as a real industry, notwithstanding the comments I have seen in the past, including those in the recent past from Senator McMullan congratulating them on their achievements as the major service industry in Australia, a major income earner and one which, in fact, has the potential to take up a lot of the unemployed, particularly the young unemployed.

Finally, I would state on behalf of the coalition that, on election to government, the coalition would recognise tourism as our largest single earner of foreign currency; and it will give tourism the same access to export market development grants and to any other facilities as are applicable to any other industry. This is a coalition commitment which will be delivered; it is not an empty Labor promise which no-one believes anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again. We have had a very well argued case by the opposition for the two amendments that the Democrats have supported. But when it comes to the point, the opposition goes to water. The minister has called the opposition's bluff by issuing a threat, and it has caved in.
—To the industry.

—Senator Parer says, `To the industry.' I would have thought that senators in this chamber have a responsibility to make decisions on what they believe is right, not on what they think outside people do or do not expect.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we have been elected to make decisions that produce the best results for the country and for industries. We did not support the opposition's amendment because we appreciated Senator Parer's blue eyes, his well-cut suits or the flow of his rhetoric. All of these are appreciated and make it a pleasure to work with him. However, it was not for that reason we supported the opposition. We supported it because we thought there was a very good case made on behalf of the tourism industry. Now what has changed? The minister has called Senator Parer's bluff; the coalition has caved in.

I would inform Senator Parer and the minister that the Democrats will not cave in; the Democrats will not accept the government's rejection of these amendments. I will not go through those two amendments again and the reasons why they should be supported. We have put those reasons once and Senator Parer has repeated them twice. I will not delay the chamber.

Let me just address the third one. The third amendment was to make sure that the tourism industry gets the 50 per cent reimbursement, just as does every other industry. Here we have a case which, again, has been very ably made by Senator Parer, very ably put forward by the coalition as a whole and very strongly made by the Australian Democrats. In fact, the history is that we announced that particular amendment before the opposition did. We made a commitment to it before the budget. I believe that this is an important amendment.

We have heard that the tourism industry is one of the growth industries of Australia; that it produces significant—in fact, of any industry, just about the highest—foreign revenue compared to investment in industry. It is something that is a matter of equity; it is also a matter of economic policy. Now, because the minister said he will treat the industry even more unjustly, to simply say that we should give up an amendment that equalises that industry to other industries is simply unacceptable.

I do not believe that the opposition has covered itself with glory in this particular case. It has simply gone to water, unjustifiably. It has left the tourism industry in the lurch. It has not stood up to the government. I am afraid we will not follow the opposition down that particular slippery slope. The Australian Democrats will be opposing the government's position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me respond briefly to the substance of the points made by Senator Parer and Senator Spindler. Both those senators were properly succinct in their arguments because this is a reiteration of a debate we have had before and, at a time when the chamber is under time pressure, we do not wish to reiterate known positions.

PARA.TAB: Let me make it clear that what we are trying to do here is strike a balance—a balance between the legitimate interest of the tourist industry, which was not previously being recognised because it was getting zero, and the legitimate concern of the taxpayers over whether their dollars were being used responsibly and, in my view, equitably.

The key amendment is the third amendment. The arguments about the first two were made in the last debate and again in the House of Representatives. I would just waste the chamber's time if I mentioned them again, although I do not want to brush everything aside so quickly that the government's arguments are not heard at all.

There was a major review of the EMDG scheme, which was at the core of the government's decision to extend the scheme. The first thing to remember is that the central feature of this piece of legislation is that it continues this massive support for our export industry for a further five years—about $250 million a year worth of exports. That is the core of this bill and is not in contention. The overall majority of senators support it.

The report which recommended the continuation of the EMDG scheme suggested that it be extended to the whole tourism sector in view of its high export earnings potential. However, it also said that, in view of there being an element of promotion by tourism companies to a captive market and the interrelationship between the generic and single service promotional activities, the government might choose to lower the grant payable to tourism claimants.

What that means when you cut away the jargon is that a massive amount of taxpayers' money is already being spent in our major markets to attract people to Australia. Much of the expenditure by tourism companies is competition between them to determine the destination of people once they have made the decision to come to Australia. That is a perfectly proper legal expense. I am not criticising them for spending their money like that, but it does not add to our exports. The fact that so much money is spent is obviously true as soon as you look at any of the advertising that takes place. It is self-evident. It is a sensible thing for an individual company to do, but not necessarily a sensible thing for a government to subsidise. It is not a point I want to argue at length, because I did so in the second reading debate and the committee stage when the bill went through the Senate the first time.

Let me say two things. First of all, the 25 per cent extension is a very major victory for the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee). We have been debating this question for a long time, and the government had not been able to find the funds to proceed in this direction and had not even decided to proceed in this way. Minister Lee has succeeded where no-one before him had. It is a very major victory for him and, through him, for the tourist industry.

Secondly, once again, we have an opposition which has an overall economic policy of commitment to massive cuts in public spending, but the only thing it ever says is where it is going to spend more money. The whole equals the sum of the parts—if you keep saying that you are going to spend more money in every area, you cannot wind up with a conclusion that says you are going to spend less. It is just a bit of a stunt by the opposition. Somehow or other, at the end of the day, the opposition arithmetic will have to add up. For that reason, the government welcomes the indication of support for the legislation and is proud to propose it. The bill will extend this important assistance to our tourism industry for another five years and open up a new area of assistance to the tourism industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—I inform the Senate that the President has received a letter nominating a senator to be a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.
Motion by (Senator McMullan)—by leave—agreed to.

That Senator Wheelwright, having been duly nominated in accordance with the provisions of the National Crime Authority Act 1994, be appointed a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority.
Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in the Senate's consideration of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1995. The bill replaces the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986 under which federal financial assistance grants are approved to local government.

PARA.TAB: The bill continues current arrangements under which the grants are provided to councils in two separately identified categories. The first of these is general purpose grants which are paid on a per capita basis to each state and territory and distributed between councils on a horizontal equalisation basis. The second category is identified local road grants which are distributed between the states and territories according to an historical formula based on their relative road needs.

This is one of the most important pieces of legislation affecting local government to come before this chamber in many years. It contains a number of useful features which improve on current arrangements. The introduction of national principles to govern the intrastate distribution of financial assistance grants is a welcome attempt to introduce more consistency in the allocation of these funds.

The draft principles, which may or may not be the version finally declared by the minister, do seem, however, to have been framed with a view to ensuring that there is as little change as possible in the current distribution of funding. While this has the support of the states and local government, it does appear that the national principles are essentially just a continuation of the current arrangements.

The coalition is pleased that councils will now be receiving earlier advice of their annual allocations which will only assist them in forward planning and framing their own budgets. This is a long overdue reform.

For the first time, funding for the Australian Capital Territory will be included in the local government financial assistance arrangements. This will replace local government type funding for the territory currently provided through other legislation.

The coalition is also pleased that the government has seen the light and decided not to propose the absorption of the untied local road funds into the general purpose assistance grants. Absorption of the local road funds, which would have automatically occurred under the current legislation, would have meant that for the first time interstate distribution of the road funds would have been made on a per capita basis. This would result in major reductions in the proportion of local road funding provided to Western Australia, Queensland, Tasmania, the Northern Territory, and the Australian Capital Territory. In the Northern Territory's case this would have meant a cut of nearly $5 million, or nearly 60 per cent, in the territory's share of federal local road grants.

The government has accepted the advice of the recent review of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986 which found that absorption of local roads grants into the horizontal equalisation process would cause major disruption. However, while recognising the positive features of the legislation, there are a number of aspects of the bill which do concern the coalition. Indeed, they are of great concern to local government itself.

The various state local government associations have recently written to federal members of parliament to voice their concerns about the bill. According to the councils, `the bill is seriously flawed in a number of respects.' Some of these concerns relate to the omission of consultative requirements in the bill. To the government's credit, some of these concerns have been dealt with in the other place, where the minister accepted a number of coalition amendments.

These were designed to require the government to consult with local government on the preparation of the national principles for the intrastate distribution of financial assistance grants and to consult with the states and local government in the preparation of the report to parliament on the operation of the legislation. We expect this will have resolved many of the concerns raised about the consultative and reporting framework enshrined in the bill and ensure the minister honours at least the spirit of the undertakings reached with the other levels of government.

Regrettably, the government did not accept an amendment designed to enable parliamentary oversight of the federal minister's power to declare the national principles. I am pleased, however, that the government has reconsidered its position on this issue and will itself at the committee stage move an amendment designed to correct this defect in the bill. The coalition, with the support of the Australian Democrats, had already resolved to insist on the passage of such an amendment. The government is, in a sense, just recognising the inevitable.

Turning now to the remainder of the legislation, it is apparent that the bill still has many flaws. Firstly, it will do remarkably little towards achieving its stated objectives. The second reading speech of the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe) is long on rhetoric but, when you read the bill, we quickly discover that the cupboard is bare.

A major failing of the bill is that it continues the parlous level of funding for local councils that local government has become used to. In 1983, when the government came to office, the federal general purpose assistance grants to local councils comprised 1.03 per cent of total Commonwealth tax revenues. By 1995-96, this share will have declined to 0.67 per cent. While total federal tax revenues increased by 49 per cent in real terms over this period, the real level of financial grants fell by three per cent.

The fundamental problem which confronts councils is that the present government has built into the budgetary framework a level of funding for local government which will be difficult to retrieve in the short term. Although the government has foreshadowed a real terms per capita maintenance of local government funding commencing 1997-98, this has not been enshrined in the bill. The impact of the funding decline is most felt by rural councils which struggle to be able to provide the essential services that their ratepayers come to expect.

The worsening condition of our local road network, declining standards of community services and rising property rates are all consequences of the federal government's shabby treatment of Australia's third sphere of government. Other federal programs which assist local government in carrying out its functions, such as the road safety black spots program and the federal urban public transport program, have been abolished since Mr Keating became Prime Minister.

A major feature of the bill is the inclusion for the first time of specific objects. These objects include improving the provision by local councils of services to Aboriginal communities and improving the efficiency and effectiveness of local councils. No senator could disagree with these aims.

When one reads the legislation to try to discover how these objectives will be achieved, one is left none the wiser. The bill provides no strategy to promote the achievement of these objectives. However, the minister will be required to report to the parliament annually on how councils have met these objectives specified for them in the bill.

For the first time in relation to local government payments, the federal minister will be required to table in parliament an annual report on the operation of the financial assistance grants legislation. This will include the extent to which the funds have been allocated on a horizontal equalisation basis and on the performance by councils of their functions, including their efficiency and provision of council services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

The Australian Local Government Association and the state and territory ministers believe that the government has breached a firm undertaking that any reporting arrangements are to be made to the local government ministers conference. The government had agreed that reporting on councils' performance would be dealt with under the auspices of the regular local government ministers meetings, rather than to parliament in the first instance. Moreover, these issues were to be the subject of further investigation by officials and advice to ministers the next year.

In relation to the issue of improved services to Aboriginal communities, the local government ministers conference decided that agreements would be negotiated between the states and territories, state local government associations and the Commonwealth on how best to deliver improved council services to Aboriginal communities. These agreements would involve complementary action by other spheres of government where necessary and additional assistance provided to councils identified and as needing to improve their performance.

None of this, however, is reflected in the bill, which puts the onus on councils to redress problems of many years standing without one cent of additional federal funding. It is tragic that the government has sought to pass the buck in this way. The problems faced by Aboriginal communities require an expanded whole of government effort. Local government does not have the capacity to do a great deal more without substantial additional funding, none of which is provided in this bill. It is also not appropriate to focus on just one disadvantaged group in the community. Other groups with special needs could have been singled out for attention, such as migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds, people with disabilities, people in remote communities, the unemployed and so on.

This bill also runs the risk of compromising the whole basis of federal local government funding. Federal grants to local government are currently untied. The principle has always been until now that what councils do with the money must remain a matter for the democratic process at the local level. Instead, this bill, in effect, converts the general purpose funding to tied funding, rather than establishing a targeted program to achieve the sensible objectives specified in the bill. To quote the Australian local government association, this aspect of the bill `seriously undermines the concept of untied, general purpose grants'.

To address these issues in the bill would require substantial amendments and an additional funding commitment, neither of which is likely to be acceptable to the government at this stage. We are also conscious of the need to ensure passage of the bill by 30 June to guarantee the continued separate identification of the local roads grants.

The broken promises I have referred to cast in a poor light the special arrangement between the federal government and local government supposed to be heralded by the proposed Commonwealth local government accord. It is ironic that, in the same week the minister announced his intention to develop the accord, local government was telling the world that the government had broken key agreements on the content of this legislation, including failure to incorporate key consultative mechanisms in the bill. In the words of the Australian Local Government Association:

SPEECH.PARA: The bill fails to implement agreements reached at conferences of local government ministers, including the ALGA President.

But this is symptomatic of the government's whole approach to this portfolio. On so many issues of concern to Australia's 741 municipalities, the government's promised consultation is revealed as just empty promises. It would be bad enough if the government's dismissive treatment of local government were confined to this bill. But it is just one of a long series of occasions on which the government has ignored or disregarded the interests of local government.

PARA.TAB: The coalition notes that the proposed accord is likely to address local government's role in progressing the national competition policy. It seems to us that the government's position on this issue is pretty well fixed and local government does not fare well. Local government has not been included in the system of competition payments agreed at the Council of Australian Governments. Moreover, the intergovernment competition principles agreement does not provide for state and Commonwealth government business enterprises to pay local government rates and charges.

The threshold problem is that the government refused to allow the Industry Commission to investigate the extent of local government's contribution to the benefits flowing from the competition policy reforms or to examine the impact of the reforms on local communities. It is also reflective of the shallowness of the government's commitment to consultation that local government had an enormous battle just to gain representation on the intergovernmental working parties set up to progress a mechanism to implement the Hilmer initiatives.

I note the belated announcement a couple of weeks ago by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), in response to coalition pressure, that he will seek a parliamentary inquiry into how community service obligations can best be continued under the Hilmer regime. This is a sign that the government is starting to listen to the concerns of local, particularly rural, communities' concerns on how the benefits of national competition reforms can most fairly be distributed.

The government would have been better advised to have consulted with local government much earlier about the Hilmer reforms and this could have allayed some of the anxiety felt in local communities, particularly in rural communities. With this background of official neglect, councils could be forgiven for being more than a little cynical about the government's wish that the accord establish common ground between the Commonwealth and local government on competition policy.

One of the difficulties faced by the coalition in considering its approach to this legislation is the complete lack of any explanation provided by the government on the rationale for many of its provisions. The whole question of federal funding for local government was addressed in two recent reports by the Australian Urban and Regional Development Review, namely, Financing local government and local government funding methodologies. These reports made a whole series of recommendations, some of which have apparently been adopted by the government; many of which have not. This is of more than academic interest.

At a local government ministers conference last year, the Minister for Housing and Regional Development was advocating arrangements to encourage and improve local council efficiency which were very different from the damp squib presented here today. These recommendations float out of the first of the reports I have just mentioned. However, the minister was comprehensively rolled by the states and local government on these proposals. They have since vanished without a trace and without any public explanation by the minister of why.

The government has had before it for more than 18 months now the findings of a House of Representatives standing committee on road funding, to which it has still not provided an official response. This report entitled Driving the road dollar further was prepared by the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. The report made a number of recommendations about federal untied local road funding, most of which have not been incorporated by the government in this bill.

I understand that primary responsibility for tabling the government's response rests with the Minister for Transport. The coalition is also concerned at the apparently fragmented nature of the government's local government assistance programs. We commend the government for incorporating a number of these disparate programs into the local government development program but the cost has apparently been a substantial increase in staffing levels in the Office of Local Government.

Scarce local government resources should be devoted to providing services at local level, not expanding the Commonwealth bureaucracy. Some local government associations have expressed the view that this represents a further attempt by the government to extend its control over the activities of local government. The coalition finds it difficult to disagree with this assessment. We also have concerns about the local government development program which, as it is funded under a one-line entry in Appropriation Bill (No. 1), is administered with very little parliamentary supervision.

It is not clear why the funding for and administration of this program would not be more effectively dealt with in the local government financial assistance legislation. This is a matter the coalition intends to pursue. The opposition will support the passage of this bill and the amendment which has been circulated by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also support the passage of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1995 and the amendment which has been proposed by the government. We are aware of some of the matters that Senator Tambling has raised tonight that the Australian Local Government Association and individual local governments have been concerned about some aspects of this proposed legislation. There was concern about the omission of a consultative process. As we understand it, a number of amendments were proposed during the negotiation process, and the Minister has accepted some of those suggestions which, as Senator Tambling says, have gone some way to alleviating those concerns, especially the parts which require consultation with local government and the states in preparation of the report that the minister is required to present to parliament.

PARA.TAB: Quite rightly, Senator Tambling revealed that the government's own amendment is a recognition of the reality of the numbers in this place—numbers which now require that parliamentary scrutiny be considerably more thorough than what had originally been planned. Having agreed with Senator Tambling on a number of matters, I would like to refer to some other matters that he raised in his address tonight. I picked up one mention of the worsening of road conditions in Western Australia and the declining standards of community service. It surprised me to hear that tonight, when yesterday the coalition was unable to see, as the Australian Local Government Association had been able to see, that this bill was a direct threat to local governments' capacity to deliver in these areas—areas of community service and the maintenance and provision of roads.

I mention this briefly in passing because I rehearsed this completely yesterday. For the sake of those who did not participate in the debate yesterday and who were glorious in their absence, I will repeat it. One example which immediately comes to mind is the concept of a preferred local supplier to local government—a concept with which I am sure my Tasmanian colleague Senator Calvert would be familiar. That concept can be deemed anti-competitive under the new legislation which the coalition supported. Such a policy, which in many communities has enabled the survival of local contractors, would now no longer be possible.

Once local contractors have disappeared, councils will be at the mercy of larger enterprises, with their larger overheads and reduced capacity to meet the sorts of needs typical in local councils—needs which require immediate attention or emergencies to be met and which arise particularly in local areas. If a protective rail around a remote hillside has been subject to an accident, you will need a local contractor to prepare it overnight or during the weekend. With the disappearance of favoured local contractors, imagine the plight of local government in not being able to get a flexible, immediate and properly costed response from the larger enterprises which will remain. Therefore, services will decline and Australia's rural communities will suffer and decline. These are the very communities which the coalition would purport to support.

While making these sorts of points yesterday, I was astounded to see the lack of speakers from the opposition. Now we hear Senator Tambling speaking of Hilmer, but yesterday he supported the whole package without a squeak. To hear him speak tonight in support of the Australian Local Government Association makes a mockery of its direct approach to the coalition, an approach which was ignored in yesterday's debate.

But that is another matter. I did want to reiterate it. I do not want to delay the passage of this legislation, because we support it. More particularly, we support it now that it will be accompanied by the amendment which the Local Government Association requested, anyway. With that amendment, and foreshadowing that the Democrats are favourably entertained by the amendments which are being circulated by Senator Margetts which we believe will make this even more equitable, we will support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in this debate tonight with some pleasure because of the 13 years that I spent in local government. Many senators on this side of the chamber have spent time in local government. Basically, the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill replaces the previous arrangement that we had for 10-odd years which was passed in 1986 to provide financial assistance to local government, generally known in the trade as FAGs.

PARA.TAB: Finance was distributed under two categories: one was by way of a general purpose grant on a per capita basis. That was on a fully horizontal equalisation basis; that is, to give everyone the same sort of standard of service right around Australia. The other category was by way of identifying local road grants. These were distributed around the country according to a historical formula based on their relative road needs.

Until 1990-91, road grants were tied to roads. Then, from 1991-92, they were untied, although they were expected to be spent on roads. Some local councils then treated that sort of assistance rather differently. But I am happy to say that in my state of Western Australia, country shires, especially, did keep spending it on roads. If any blame could be attributed to some country shires, it would be that they spent too much on roads, but there is nothing wrong with that.

This bill gives a total amount of financial assistance of $1.165 billion, made up of $807 million in general purpose grants and $358 million for local roads, identified but not tied. I have said plenty of times in this place that I believe grants for roads should still be tied but that is quite an area of debate in my party room, let alone in this place.

At this hour of the night I would like to concentrate on putting on record the fears of the Western Australian Municipal Association with regard to this legislation. They said in a letter to me that they welcomed the bill and acknowledged the extent of consultations that had occurred with local government during the drafting. They continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably, however, the Bill is seriously flawed in a number of respects. It fails to implement various agreements reached at conferences of Local Government Ministers held in October 1994 and this April, and contains provisions which are inconsistent with a system of untied, general purpose grants.

I will read into the record the objects of the new legislation. They are: improving the financial capacity of local councils; improving the capacity of local governments to provide their residents with an equitable level of services; improving the certainty of funding of local councils; improving the efficiency and effectiveness of local councils; improving the provision by local councils of services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders—and I will come back to that a bit later; improving the transparency and accountability of the states in the allocation of FAGs to councils; and promoting consistency in the methods by which grants are allocated.

PARA.TAB: Those are very nice words indeed. But does that occur in practice? After all, a lot of agreements that were reached at the ministerial council have not been translated into legislation.

The Western Australian Municipal Association said that the following sections of the bill cause grave concern: the procedure to establish national principle guidelines to guide the allocation of grants amongst councils; annual reports to parliament, which does not sit too well with the WA Municipal Association; and the intended objects of the legislation.

In principle, local government ministers, both state and federal, agreed at the conference that I spoke of last year that the principle should be formulation in consultation with state ministers and the Australian Local Government Association to take the form of a disallowable instrument. The bill failed to get anywhere near this agreement. I could find nothing in the bill on consultation with the ALGA and, on my reading of the bill, the minister can simply formulate, revoke, or vary principles in writing. In other words, it is up to what the minister thinks. There is no requirement for consultation at all when the minister revokes or varies a principle.

So the basis around which they reached agreement has fallen far short. The idea is that the federal minister can set the principles for local governments in faraway states. Although groups of local governments in a regional situation are able to sort out the allocation of grants amongst themselves, the minister is able to come in with his overriding principles.

In this case I can see another Ros Kelly whiteboard situation. A minister at this distance setting principles for my state of Western Australia does not sit well with me. The minister may have great objectives of his own that may work in the more populous states, cities or whatever but at that distance—and I do not think many on this side of the chamber or on that side of the chamber will argue with me—it should not be up to a federal minister to have such powers.

The requirement to report to parliament at a federal level seems far out of kilter with what should occur. The ALGA and the states took the view that reporting on the performance of councils should be to the local government ministers conference—in other words, the ministerial council of local government and not to parliament. I have no problem with that. As yet there has been no agreement on the form which such reports should take and the issue was to have been the subject of further investigation by officials and advice to ministers next year. As WAMA, the Western Australian Municipal Association, says, the provisions of the bill are therefore at best premature.

Under these guiding principles, local government will have to adhere to the spending of ATSIC councils and communities. The association does not disassociate itself from the need to improve the situation with ATSIC communities. They reached that agreement last April, according to the Western Australia Municipal Association.

They believe there is simply no reason why that should be addressed in the bill. After all, ATSIC communities are the same as any other community. As disadvantaged as they may be, there are other disadvantaged communities in Australia as well. ATSIC communities believe that should not be part of the bill. Once we set a precedent that it is part of the bill, other disadvantaged groups may believe they have the same need and in no time we will have four or five more disadvantaged groups. The same can be said for remote rural communities, so it is not only Aboriginal communities that are in this situation.

I return to the issue of general purpose grants. They are untied. That is the principle behind them. Why all of a sudden has the government brought in a bill which will direct, in relation to ATSIC communities, local councils to do so much beyond what they normally do for everyone else? If the government thinks it needs to allocate further funds to overcome its problems—in this case it may be to do with the supply of roads, sewerage, water and maybe electricity in certain remote areas where communities believe they meet the special need clause—why can the government not make a special allocation perhaps via local government? Local government is the most efficient government that can handle finance. By all means it should do so, but why try to direct an untied general purpose grant in any particular direction?

The government did exactly that. We have not dealt with the relevant legislation, which relates to the diesel fuel levy being imposed on remote communities which generate their own electricity. The government has done just that and made a special allocation to Aboriginal communities that will be hard hit by having to now pay the diesel fuel levy in generating their own power. The government could quite easily have done that. After all, only a very small part of what is allocated to councils by way of general purpose grants is to go towards those communities. If we want to make a marked change in any community, I believe there has to be a special purpose grant rather than a general purpose grant, which is untied.

Those are the main concerns of the Western Australian Municipal Association regarding this bill. I believe a couple of amendments are floating around in relation to them. Before I close, in a general context I point out again the decreasing amount of funds going to local government. With the ever increasing revenue this government is collecting, in real terms less and less seems to go to local government. That is all I have to say in relation to the concerns of the Western Australian Municipal Association. I will be happy to listen to what my colleagues have to say. I listened to the shadow minister for local government speak. I will listen with interest to the shadow minister for regional development and infrastructure, who will be speaking next.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that in the brief contribution I want to make to this Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1995 I can give a Queensland focus to it as my colleague Senator Panizza has given a Western Australia focus. I also want to briefly mention the importance of local government to the regional development of our nation. As Senator Tambling, who led this debate for us, indicated, local government is the sphere of government that is absolutely closest to the people. It is the most democratic form of government and one that really represents to the minutest degree the wishes of the constituents it serves.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has always been very committed to local government. I suppose one does not have to look further than the people taking part in this debate. Senator Tambling, who led the debate, was for many years an elected member of the Darwin City Council, which is the local authority looking after Darwin. My friend and colleague Senator Panizza, who preceded me, was for many years the shire president of a council in Western Australia. Senator Calvert, who is to follow me, was for many years the warden of the Clarence council in Tasmania.

In this coming election, a number of our candidates are currently serving councillors. Their credentials are in local authority. They have been elected and have a real community understanding. Les Glover is our candidate for Franklin. He is currently the deputy mayor of the Clarence shire council in Tasmania, which is Senator Calvert's old council. Certainly Les Glover, the deputy mayor and our candidate in Franklin, will be an excellent representative for his part of Tasmania when he joins the House of Representatives, as he surely will, as the next member for Franklin. I know that Joanna Gash, our candidate for Gilmore, is currently a serving member of a council in the electorate of Gilmore. She is another person who is well respected in her community. She has the support and trust of her community from the work that she has already done there. The coalition has always had a very great commitment to local government in Australia.

Labor has used local government in a fairly crass political way. I remember before the last federal election when I was the shadow minister for local government that the Labor Party made a lot of political capital about the fact that it had a minister for local government. I used to appear with Mr Simmons. He is a lovely fellow; it is a pity he is not hanging around with the Labor Party. As with most of the good Labor Party people, he has seen the writing on the wall and he is getting out. He has given it away. He knows that the Labor Party of today is made up of right-wing thugs from New South Wales. He wants to get out. Mr Simmons is a good man.

Everywhere we used to go, he would ask whether the coalition was going to have a minister for local government next time. I would say yes, that of course we would. He would say that the Labor Party would have a separate ministry for local government. What happened? No sooner was the election over than local government disappeared from the ministry line-up in the Labor Party.

The department that Mr Simmons used to head—the ministry of local government—disappeared. It was not even mentioned. It became a very minor office within the mega-department of housing and regional development and a multitude of other things. It was taken over by the then Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, who has also retired. He has seen the writing on the wall. Mr Howe, a fairly genuine sort of fellow in his own area, has no interest in local government. He never knew local government, never really understood it and never had much commitment to it.

It was interesting that this great commitment that the Labor Party had to making local government a separate ministry before the election, like its l-a-w tax promises, just disappeared after the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just became a marginal seats strategy.

—Senator Tambling is quite right; it was a marginal seats strategy. All the way through its career, the Australian Local Government Association has been a very responsible and mature organisation that gives considered responses. It went through a period where it was controlled by my old mate, Peter Woods. He is not a bad fellow, but he was a real left-wing Labor man, so much so that he was expelled from the Labor Party. But he never gave away his Labor Party credentials.
—Was he a Democrat?

—Perhaps he was a Democrat. He was even further to the left than Senator Bell. He was a nice fellow. He got a job as a member of the Kelty committee. He was a good fellow, but he unfortunately turned the Australian Local Government Organisation—
