DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night in the adjournment debate Senator Tierney launched an attack upon my friend and colleague Senator Carr over Senator Carr's role on Senate committees. Senator Carr is big enough to look after himself, but tonight I want to respond to some of the remarks made by Senator Tierney last night, particularly his comments about the conduct of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which Senator Tierney is the chairperson of the references committee. I want to bring to the attention of the Senate the lack of responsibility and the lack of objectivity adopted by Senator Tierney, in particular, in his role as chairman of that committee and also by other members of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: In his speech last night in the adjournment debate Senator Tierney referred to some proceedings of the committee that took place in Tweed Heads and in Campbelltown, New South Wales, on 3 and 4 May. At the hearing of the committee in Tweed Heads on 3 May there were three senators present: namely, Senator Tierney, Senator Troeth and me. During the day we received advice that unfortunately Senator Denman, who was originally going to attend the hearing scheduled for the following day, could no longer attend the hearing and that as a consequence of her absence there would be a lack of a quorum for that hearing the following day.

The committee met in a private session. I still have some doubts about the efficacy of that, given the way the meeting was called, at such short notice and without advice to any other members of the committee, but anyway a private meeting was held. At the private meeting a proposal was put forward to establish a subcommittee comprising Senator Tierney, Senator Troeth and me. I objected rather strongly to this proposal. I particularly objected to being included in the resolution as a member of a subcommittee when I was not available to attend the hearing the following day, and when that was well known to the members of the committee.

I pointed out that subcommittees should be appointed in a proper manner and clearly should not comprise senators who are not able to attend hearings. After all, the purpose of a subcommittee is to enable the committee to function with a smaller number of members and certainly where those members of that subcommittee are able to attend. In any event, this proposal was railroaded through despite my objections and I was actually included as a member of this subcommittee in the full knowledge of the other members of the committee, Senator Tierney and Senator Troeth, that I would not be able to attend the hearing the next day and that only two senators would be present, both opposition senators.

The hearing went ahead the next day with Senator Tierney and Senator Troeth in attendance. Subsequently on 9 May a meeting of the full committee, its normal weekly meeting during sitting weeks, was held here in the House. The minutes of that meeting in Tweed Heads were presented. I pointed out that my objections to the subcommittee that I had earlier raised had not been incorporated into the minutes. There was much discussion at that meeting, which I will not go into, except to say that as the discussion ebbed back and forth recollections of Senator Tierney and Senator Troeth as to what had actually occurred at that meeting changed.

The actions adopted by Senator Tierney on that day in Tweed Heads were most provocative. They were completely contrary to the concept of procedural fairness and to the proper functioning of committees and subcommittees. It was nothing more than the brutal use of numbers to establish a subcommittee in the full knowledge that only opposition senators would be in attendance when that subcommittee met. It was done without the knowledge of other members of the committee and no notice was given to any member of the committee that the meeting would be called.

I was quite content to leave this matter rest with the committee because it did occupy some time in discussion. But last night Senator Tierney came along here and waxed lyrical, professing pious indignation over Senator Carr's membership of that committee and his non-attendance at a particular hearing in Melbourne. I point out that at an estimates hearing of the same committee on 26 May, here in this building, Senator Tierney and Senator Troeth walked out of the meeting and deprived it of a quorum. The minister was in attendance, government members of the committee were in attendance, and an array of departmental officers were in attendance but Senator Tierney and Senator Troeth walked out, depriving the committee of a quorum. Then Senator Tierney comes into this chamber and complains about people not attending committee hearings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not normally take points of order in the debate on the adjournment—I think people should have a free run—but if Senator Carr feels aggrieved about something, it would be more appropriate if he came in to defend himself rather than relying on Senator Forshaw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also point out—Senator Bell would well remember this—that, when this same committee visited the Aboriginal settlement at Yuendumu in the Northern Territory last year, not one opposition member of the committee bothered to attend that hearing. That committee hearing was held to look at the issues of education for Aboriginal people and the availability of open learning. The visit occurred in the very same week as the then Leader of the Opposition, Alexander Downer, was lecturing the government and the country about Aboriginal education. Yet when there was a specific meeting of the committee to look at the same issue, the opposition members of the committee could not be bothered to attend.

PARA.TAB: I raise another matter. Last Friday, a private visit by the Senate Select committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney took place. During those proceedings—of which there was no Hansard record because it was a private visit—there were two occasions when the chairman allowed the media to take over the proceedings. We had a resident outside his house in Kurnell answering questions from the media on television. This was supposed to be a visit by the committee to look at the issue of aircraft noise—a very important issue for the residents of Kurnell and a matter I have particularly taken up in representations to the minister.

The chairman of that committee, Senator Parer, should have conducted those proceedings properly. He should not have allowed them to be taken over by the media and turned into nothing more than a political stunt whereby the opposition candidate for the seat of Cook, Stephen Mutch, spent most of his time standing in front of the camera endeavouring to ensure that he got on TV. It may have suited the opposition's purpose but it clearly meant that the committee's function in visiting the residents' houses and talking to those residents became a bit of a farce. So before we get these hypocritical tirades from the opposition, it should have a good look at its performance on committees.

The government is prepared to cooperate with the proper functioning of committees. We are prepared to do that recognising the clear disadvantage the government has because it has fewer senators available to serve on committees than the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't get any elected.

—When you have quite a number of ministers as we do in the Senate, because we happen to be in government and not in opposition, it means we have fewer senators available from the back bench to serve on committees—a situation that will continue after the election, I have no doubt. It is about time the opposition stopped its whingeing and got on with the real business of the Senate and the committees of this chamber. (Time expired)

—As chairman of the coalition's waste watch committee, tonight I wish to highlight yet another area of government waste: ministerial consultants. What does this government spend on consultants in general, specifically ministerial consultants—that is, those appointed by ministers for which, for the public, there is little or no accountability of the work they do?

PARA.TAB: We know the government has just appointed half a million dollars worth of new ministerial staff, at the same time reducing the budget in the Senate by $1.6 million. We know all that, but that is another story. Tonight I wish to highlight one member of this special class of ministerial consultants, which my waste watch committee has been tracking over the last couple of years.

Brian Courtice represents another classic case of waste by this Labor government for its own political ends. Brian Courtice was elected to the House of Representatives in 1987 and 1990 as the federal member for the Central Queensland seat of Hinkler, one of the most marginal in Australia. At the March 1993 election, Mr Courtice was defeated by the National Party's Paul Neville. After the poll was declared, the former canefarmer and failed politician was out looking for a job. He did not have far to go to find one.

He turned to the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, the member for Maribyrnong, Mr Griffiths, for a job. On 24 May 1993, Brian Courtice commenced work as a consultant to the minister on regional development issues. His initial term was to 23 September 1993. However, it was soon extended to take him through to 23 August 1995. Mr Courtice received an annual salary of $73,360, or over $1,400 a week, which at the time was more than a backbencher's salary.

As we all know, the member for Maribyrnong's ministerial career was cut short by the embarrassing sandwich shop affair when he resigned in December 1993. So valued was Mr Courtice's advice that the new minister, Senator Cook, did not take on Mr Courtice, and his consultancy on regional development was ceased a month or so later on 21 January 1994. However, during his eight months with former Minister Griffiths, Brian Courtice managed to clock up travel allowance worth $16,773.30, air fares totalling $23,472 and extras including taxi fares and mobile phone charges totalling $2,685. If we annualise Mr Courtice's salary and expenses over a 12-month period, we see that his consultancy would have cost the Australian taxpayer around $137,000.

Despite his highly paid advice, Senate estimates also revealed that Mr Courtice had little or nothing to do with two major investigations into regional development, even though he was supposedly a highly prized consultant for that area. He had little or no input to both the Industry Commission's inquiry into impediments to regional industry adjustment or the government's own Kelty task force inquiry and report on regional development, headed by ACTU Secretary, Bill Kelty. Quite extraordinary when you consider he was the minister's regional development expert.

After being dumped by the disgraced Griffiths, Brian Courtice did not have to wait long to pick up another ministerial job. On 21 February 1994, Mr Courtice commenced work with his old Queensland Labor mate, the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall. Literally overnight, Mr Courtice went from being an expert on regional development to being an expert on resource issues. Mr Courtice was initially employed from 21 February 1994 to August 1995. However, it, too, was later extended to 7 February 1996, taking his term out to about a month or so before the latest possible federal election date.

His salary was listed at $73,360 per annum, which has now risen to $74,460. Examination of his travel records show that Mr Courtice spends a lot of his time outside parliamentary sittings back in Bundaberg and, presumably, unsupervised. How does Mr Courtice spend his time? Roaming the electorate of Hinkler of course, playing the ALP candidate—attending functions, turning up to meetings, being photographed with other visiting ministers who have nothing to do with his portfolio duties, yet we were told in Senate estimates that the position is considered the equivalent of a full-time posting. Interestingly, Mr Courtice continues to be based in his home town of Bundaberg, but his minister is in Brisbane.

To help him get around his important functions, the Commonwealth has also provided him with his own personal car also based in Bundaberg. In fact it was granted from 5 March 1994. Nothing less than a Falcon GLI. Car costs, up to mid-June 1995, have so far amounted to $9,233.81.

Senate estimates have also revealed that since starting with Minister Beddall, Mr Courtice has rung up the following expenses with his new minister, up to 16 June this year: travel allowance worth $20,027 and airfares worth $32,500. So over the last 16 months with Minister Beddall, Brian Courtice's salary and expenses have cost the taxpayers of Australia around $161,042. If we project Mr Courtice's salary and expenses through to the end of his term with Mr Beddall, 7 February next year—a total of 23 months—we find that his consultancy will conceivably cost taxpayers around $231,498—almost a quarter of a million dollars.

Senate estimates also revealed that between March and August 1994, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy supplied Mr Courtice with a mobile phone, faxstream access, semi-official telephone, modem line, laser printer, computer and modem—that is not bad for a self-confessed non-typist—and a very handy taxpayer funded campaign office.

On 24 October 1994, ALP nominations for the seat of Hinkler closed. It was no surprise that our consultant Mr Courtice was preselected unopposed. From that date—some eight months ago—Mr Courtice was the official ALP candidate for Hinkler, though one could say that he had spent much of the previous 18 months masquerading as one.

Since then we have seen Mr Courtice quoted in the Hinkler media—newspapers, radio and television—commenting on everything from road funding, water, employment, local industry, youth, university places, the budget, the drought, the environment and, most particularly, attacking the coalition and the local member. But then Mr Courtice may have been too busy being a candidate rather than a consultant.

The worse three embarrassments around this place in recent times have been the miners' rally, the timber demonstration and the pig producers' protest. They have all affected resources and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It invites the question: what sort of advice was Mr Beddall receiving from his highly paid consultants? Was it that Mr Courtice was too busy being a candidate and not a consultant?

In conclusion, let us look at the total projected cost of Brian Courtice's career as a ministerial consultant. Between when he first started with Mr Griffiths on 24 May 1993 and the end of his proposed term with Minister Beddall on 7 February next year—a period of some two years and eight months—Mr Courtice will have milked the public purse for around $323,335 in salary expenses. That does not include the car, the mobile phone, the computer, the fax and the other perks, provided by the Commonwealth.

This is quite extraordinary when you consider Mr Courtice's own rhetoric. As a member of the parliament, Mr Courtice was scathing of the federal coalition and the Queensland National Party and on many occasions accused them and others in the rural community, including industry leaders, of jobs for the boys, cronyism and the rorting of public funds. It seems Mr Courtice has failed his own test—or is it that there is one rule for the Labor Party and another rule for everyone else when it comes to accountability of government.

Like the Kevin Rudd affair, which recently embarrassed the Queensland Goss government, this sort of misuse of public money appears to be rife in the ALP at all levels. Such over-indulgence of this Keating government in ministerial consultants is a terrible and blatant waste of taxpayers' money.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pork producers came to Canberra today to voice their concerns. The Australian Democrats welcome them and say, `Good on you.' One of their purposes was to urge the government to move on stronger origin labelling laws, and they were totally right in doing so. This government has gone weak at the knees on labelling. Australians want to buy Australian. City and country people are strongly united on this. We all know of the quality of Australian produce and recognise the improvements that producers have worked for in the last few years.

PARA.TAB: As consumers, we are prepared to pay extra for an Australian produced product when we know that the higher costs are due to droughts and the like. But Australian consumers need the chance to give Australian producers a fair go. They need proper, honest and clear labelling of Australian produce. The Democrats have supported toughening of the labelling regulations for a long time. We trialled our own proposal in South Australia in the Foodland stores and we discovered that, when Australians know clearly what Australian products are, they will buy them. We proposed a four-tiered labelling program—A, B, C and D—in which A represented totally Australian products and D represented totally imported products.

We distribute—Senator Bell is probably almost a champion in this area—a booklet that lists products and brands that are made in Australia to help make up for this inadequacy of labelling. We are ready right now to change the laws on labelling. The Democrats fully support what the pork producers were asking for today and have been pro-active in working to change not only Australia's origin labelling laws but also GATT related trade laws.

The time has come for leadership on this issue. I wish it was not the case, but the coalition and the government have deserted primary producers on this one. When they had the opportunity to vote for amendments to the World Trade Organisation legislation that would have improved the situation, they refused to even listen to the arguments put to them.

The Democrats pushed for a Senate inquiry to define how adversely affected producers would be compensated. We explained to them that, if they wanted to have a level playing field, it would have to be a commonsense level playing field. The playing field would have to take into account that some of the world's major trading nations were, and still are, not prepared to remove some of their own subsidies. In some cases they are not prepared to remove any of them. Other nations would have extremely long phase-in periods for subsidy reduction programs. But I am afraid that rational argument could not persuade those who were set on implementing an ideological agenda. Unfortunately, Australian farmers were chosen as the lambs for slaughter. Australia was to be one of the first nations to pass legislation allowing GATT to come into force. Both the coalition and Labor voted in favour of that unamended legislation.

I might just digress to reassure you of that. I recently heard of a parliamentarian who attempted to make out that the level playing field was created by a treaty that they and their party had no real chance to vote upon. This parliamentarian is a member of a party that, along with the Democrats, is opposed to the ridiculous and undemocratic process of allowing signatures on a range of international treaties without any parliamentary scrutiny.

However, let me make it clear that the World Trade Organisation legislation was just that—legislation. It was not a treaty. In the House of Representatives and in the Senate, all the major parties voted for the World Trade Organisation legislation. The problem was that National, Labor and Liberal parties passed this legislation and ignored the amendments that were put up to make it more realistic. They rejected the claims the Democrats made about how some primary producers would be affected by bringing GATT in too soon. Now the people who are being forced to suffer the consequences of this legislation, the very people who worked so hard to improve this country's balance of payments, are coming to Canberra to haunt those parliamentarians who voted for the unamended GATT legislation. It is difficult for us not to say to those parliamentarians, `I told you so.'

TALK.START.PARA: —You voted for tax increases on them.

—It simply does not make sense, Senator Kemp—and I am glad you are listening. In fact, I would say that it is naive to open Australia's markets to nations that are neither opening their markets to overseas producers nor reducing subsidies to their producers. Why are the coalition and the government blindly following this policy? I do not know why. I would like to know why. It simply does not make any sense.

PARA.TAB: Like the pork producers, the Democrats can see the argument for levelling off the playing field, for reducing subsidies when we are trading with countries that are also reducing theirs. But it is simply farcical and plain stupid to allow subsidised overseas products unnaturally to force down the price of Australian products in our home market. I urge pork producers to join the Democrats and keep on asking why the coalition and government are doing this. The Democrats will continue working to ensure that governments take into account the real situation of Australian people to implement commonsense laws and to ensure a fair go for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say I am intrigued to hear Senator Woodley in this new role. I was particularly intrigued to see the ABC news tonight when, despite the fact that there was a great gathering of coalition members and senators at the pig rally outside—and I must say I wore an appropriate tie for the occasion—the only politician shown on the ABC news attending that rally was someone called Senator Woodley, that well-known rural expert. This was despite the fact that, as I said, there was a whole host of Liberal and National Party members and senators there. I must say I did not see any government members and senators there at the time, but no doubt they had other business to attend to rather than to spend their time talking to pig farmers.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that what the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, had to say at that rally would have been of slightly more substance than the meanderings of Senator Woodley, at least judging by tonight's speech. Still, that is a journalistic judgment that the ABC has made, and I trust it is of the same high standard of so many of its journalistic judgments.

However, I met a friend of mine at that rally who is a chicken producer. He pointed out to me that there are problems affecting that industry as well as the pork industry, relating to threatened changes and problems relating to quarantine matters, particularly the question of whether or not imports of cooked chicken meat should be allowed. Senator Crane pointed out today that there is a change proposed in the protocol relating to the freezing of pork imports, which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins, did not know anything about, which naturally concerned pig producers and certainly Senator Crane.

The point made to me by my chicken producing friend was that, if we allow in cooked chicken meat from some Asian countries, we run a series of real risks because the residues of chemicals and other types of material left in the chicken, even after they are cooked, may well, in the view of some experts, create a risk. He gave me a little dodger which says:

SPEECH.PARA: It doesn't make sense to allow imports of cooked chicken meat into Australia from countries such as Thailand where health officials don't even know the full extent and status of dangerous diseases such as Salmonella enteriditis in poultry flocks.
It doesn't make sense to import foodstuffs from countries where therapeutic drugs which are banned in Australia for public health reasons have been used in the growing process.
It doesn't make sense for the National Food Authority to class cooked chicken meat imports as "high risk" and then for the Government to allow such products into the country.
Public Health is a key issue in the opposition of Australia's chicken growers to the lifting of bans on imported cooked chicken meat.
If it's a choice between international trade agreements such as GATT and protecting the Public Health of Australians—then there is no choice at all. The bans on imports must stay.

I am no expert in this matter. I have no knowledge of the technical matters involved. All I want to relate here tonight is the fact that this is an industry which is expressing the same sorts of concerns relating to health matters as the pig industry expressed today.

PARA.TAB: I now deal with another matter altogether. That relates to the Election funding and financial disclosure report for election 1993, details of which were presented to the Senate this week. We did not get the opportunity to deal with it. I am particularly interested in the return of electoral expenditure which is by third parties—in other words, someone taking part in the election campaign if expenditure of more than $200 is incurred while not in fact being one of the political parties or a candidate.

It is without the written authority of a registered political party, a state branch of a political party, a candidate or a member of a group. This is expenditure by people like trade unions, for example, who took such an enormous role in the last election—putting in their own advertisements, pushing their own barrow which, of course, came back full of sandwiches after the election when the ACTU, having bought the right to dictate to this government, received the benefits from this government.

This return includes broadcasting of an advertisement relating to the election; publishing in a journal of an advertisement; display at a theatre; production costs of advertisements broadcast, published or displayed; consultant's or advertising agent's fees in respect of services; or carrying out an opinion poll or other research in relation to the election.

What intrigued me significantly—apart from such quaint matters as the Eros Association spending $10,000 on somebody's behalf; I am not quite certain what that was all about—is that the ACTU and ACTU Future Strategies, according to this document, spent $600,000 as a third party on electoral advertising. It was not for the Liberal Party. It was not for the National Party. That was all for the Labor Party, in addition to whatever donations it made.

It the interesting to see that the ACTU did not give any donations—you will be shocked to know this—to the Liberal and National parties. But it did give a $10,000 donation to the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—Yes—$10,000 from the Australian Council of Trade Unions to the Australian Democrats for their election campaign. A former colleague of mine once said that it is wrong to allege you can buy the Australian Democrats when in fact you can only lease them by the hour. I do not know how many hours $10,000 buys, but it seems to me that it does explain some extraordinary decisions the Australian Democrats may well have taken over time. Of more concern to me is a company called Australis Media Pty Ltd, which does not seem to like the coalition very much. It donated $15,000 to the Australian Labor Party, Western Australia branch.
—Eh?
—Yes, Senator Panizza. I don't think you got any of that.
—No.

—Australis Media is an interesting company because not only is it into cable TV but I think in conjunction with Galaxy it has done a deal now with Foxtel and Telecom. I am not suggesting that there should be any link between donations to the Labor Party and that kind of association. But it is interesting, particularly when we see that Australis Media Pty Ltd spent $148,366.20 on electoral expenditure—certainly not on behalf of the Liberal Party—at the 1993 election. Of that amount, $135,000 was in publishing and $12,500-odd was for research.

PARA.TAB: These matters might be of some interest to many people. Perhaps there are some who would say, `Well, we oppose this kind of revelation.' They may ask why I am revealing it. I want to dramatise how serious the consequences are for many people of the exposure of this kind of information.

If we look through this document, we get a clear view of the enormous contribution that the Maritime Union and the union movement overall make to the Labor Party. This is done not by giving donations to the Labor Party but by advertising on its own behalf. The list of these parties includes the Maritime Union, $40,000-odd; the Public Sector Union, $16,000; the Public Service Association, $16,000-odd; the Queensland Teachers Union, $17,000-odd—and the list goes on and on. There is also the Victorian Trades Council, $33,000; the United Trades and Labour Council of South Australia, $112,000; the Trades and Labour Council of Queensland, $152,000. This is on top of donations to political parties.

This is the activist involved role of people who appear, one way or another, to have been able to influence this government, too. It is quite reasonable for people to contribute to political parties; I have no objection to that. All I am saying is that there is the fear that in many of these instances there might be an expectation, particularly when it is in connection with the Labor movement itself, the industrial wing of the Labor movement. I would think in many unions the bulk of the members are not Labor Party members or supporters.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—I call Senator Wheelwright.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Can details be provided of the use of VIP aircraft by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his staff since 1 March 1995, including: (a) dates of flights; (b) airport/airfield of departure and destination; and (c) type of aircraft used.

(2) Have any VIP aircraft used by the Prime Minister landed at, or departed from, any of the following airfields near Melbourne: (a) Point Cook; (b) Laverton; and (c) Avalon; if so, what were the dates of those flights and the type of aircraft used.
(3) What were the reasons for using Point Cook, Laverton or Avalon airfields on those occasions.

(4) Have any VIP flights used by the Prime Minister changed their destination from Tullamarine or Essendon airports to Point Cook, Laverton or Avalon during the course of the flight; if so, on what dates and for what reasons.
(5) What is the state of operational readiness for aircraft arrivals at Laverton, Point Cook or Avalon airfields.

(6)(a) Is it normal procedure for VIP flights to change their flight plan and destinations during the course of the flight; and (b) are these changes shown in the published special purpose flight schedules.
(7) What problems and safety risks does this practice pose for other aircraft and air traffic controllers responsible for the air space in which VIP flights are operating.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The information relating to RAAF VIP flights is tabled in Parliament every six months. Details relating to VIP flights by the Prime Minister and his staff after I March 1995 will be

ANSWER.PARA: included in the Schedule of Special Purpose Flights tabled in Parliament in December 1995, after all records have been recorded.

PARA.TAB: (b) Yes. A Falcon 900 aircraft from Canberra to Melbourne on 31 March 1995.
(c) Yes. A Falcon 900 aircraft from Avalon to Canberra on 4 June 1995.
(3) The Prime Minister was attending functions which were significantly closer to Laverton and Avalon airfields than either Essendon or Tullamarine.
(4) Yes. See answer to question 3.

(5) Laverton airfield, located at RAAF Base Williams, is no longer maintained at full operational readiness. Occasional RAAF flights to Laverton are made following local inspection of the airfield and its facilities. Point Cook airfield has the same state of readiness as Laverton and could be used under the same conditions. However, the short runway makes this option unlikely. Avalon airfield is a privately owned, fully-operational airfield used for airline training and regular passenger services. It is suitable for military and civil operations.
(6)(a) While in-flight changes to VIP flights are not a routine occurrence, they do occur and can be accommodated by aircrew, providing appropriate authority for the change is obtained.
(b) Yes.

(7) Diversions to alternative airfields, for reasons including changing weather conditions, equipment malfunctions, illness or other authorised reasons, are a normal feature of flying operations for RAAF aircrew and air traffic controllers. There is no safety risk involved, providing the aircraft captain is aware of the conditions at the new location. Some extra workload for the aircrew may occur, but this is not a safety risk.
